<k>tirar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to draw, pull, tug; <ex>(of chimneys)</ex>
to draw; (cf. <k>tranar</k>, <k>haular</k>, <k>vindar</k>, <k>tensar</k>, <k>cherpar</k>, <k>extraktar</k>); <k>tiretar</k> to twitch; <k>tir</k>(<k>ad</k>)<k>o</k>
pulling, drawing, towing; draught <ex>(of chimneys)</ex>; <k>tiresforco</k>
drawing power, traction; <k>tirkordono</k> draw-string; <k>tirkordo</k>
tow-rope; <k>tirkesto</k> drawer; <k>tirkestaro</k> chest of
drawers; <k>ektirar</k> to put out, pluck out; <k>tirkavalo</k>
draught horse: <k>korktirilo</k> corkscrew. Ex.: Kavali tiras
veturi. Ektirar l’espado, sua horlojeto.

<k>tirado</k> <ex>(lit. and fig.)</ex> tirade. Def.: Teknikal
termino di teatro: longa peco (generale brilanta od eloquenta),
quan un persono dicas sen interrupto; III-268.

<k>tiraliar*</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to engage in desolutory firing;
to bang away; to skirmish fire; <k>tiraliero</k> (F.army) tirailleur;
a soldier placed so as to harass the enemy; sharpshooter.

<k>titilar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to tickle, titillate; <k>titileso</k>
t. sensation; <k>titilsentema</k> ticklish.

<k>titrar*</k> <ex>(tr., chem.) </ex>to titrate: determine the
standard, the dosage of (a solution, a substance); <k>titruro</k>
standard of fineness (of coins, etc.).

<k>titulo</k> title (of a book, article, person); <k>titulizar</k>
to entitle: give a title to (cf. <k>nomizar</k>); <k>tituliera</k>, <k>titulo</k>
titular; <k>nobeleso titulo</k> t. of nobility; <k>titulpagino</k> t.
page; <k>li titulizis il kom profesoro</k> they gave him the t.
of profesor. V. exp.: vid. <k>rubriko</k>.

<k>toko</k> toque: a flat cap; a close fitting bonnet; <k>toko
 velura</k> velvet t.; <k>chas toko</k> hunting cap, jockey cap.

<k>tolo</k> sheet-metal; <k>tolifisto</k> sheet-metal worker; <k>fer
 tolo</k> sheet-iron; <k>stal tolo</k> sheet-steel.

<k>tolerar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to tolerate, put up with, suffer,
allow, bear, endure (<k>ulo</k>, <k>de ulu</k>); <k>tolerebla</k>
tolerable, supportable; middling, passable (cf. <k>pasabla</k>); <k>tolerema</k>
tolerant.

<k>tomo</k> volume, tome; (cf. <k>libro</k>); <k>tomonumerizar</k>
to number (into volumes); <k>tomonumero</k> number of a volume.

<k>tombo</k> tomb, grave, sepulcher (sepulchre); <k>tombala</k>
sepulchral; <k>tombala petro</k> tombstone; <k>familio tombo</k>
family tomb or vault; <k>tombeyo</k> place of burial; graveyard,
cemetry; <k>tombisto</k> grave-digger, sexton; <k>tombo masonita</k>
vault (for dead).

<k>tono</k> tone, pitch (of voice) <ex>(mus.)</ex> tone; degree,
pitch of sound; <ex>(med.)</ex> tone: condition of an organ; <k>tonala</k>
tonal; <ex>(mus.)</ex> tonic; <k>tonala noto</k> <ex>(mus.)</ex>
key-note; <k>tonizar</k> <ex>(med.)</ex> to give tone to; <ex>(photog.)</ex>
to tone: bring as a print, to a required color (colour); <k>tonizivo</k>
<ex>(med.)</ex> tonic; <ex>(photog.)</ex> toning solution or reagent.
Ex.: Altigar, basigar, chanjar la tono. Tono kordiala, iracoza.
Ica medikamento agas kom tonizivo por la stomako, o donas tono a
la stomako. On dicas, ke ula melodio, o muzik-peco esas skribita
o kompozita en ca o ta tono. On kustumas indikar singla tono per
lua fundamental sono. V. exp.: Muzikal tono ne esas un sono, ma
esemblo de soni qui kompozas o povas kompozar melodio; IV-467.

<k>tondar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to shear: clip from surface with
shears, etc. (cf. <k>rekortar</k>); <k>tond</k>(<k>ad</k>)<k>o</k>
shearing, clipping; <k>tondajo</k> shearings, clipping(s), flock; <k>tondotempo</k>shearing time; <k>tondero</k>, <k>tondisto</k> shearer; <k>tondilo</k>
clipper, shears.

<k>tondrar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to thunder; <ex>(fig.)</ex> to
inveigh (against); (cf. <k>sturmo</k>); <k>tondras</k> <ex>(impers.)</ex>
it thunders; <k>tondrostroko</k> clap, peal of t.
<k>tonsuro</k> tonsure; <k>tonsurizar</k> to give the t. to (<k>ulu</k>).

<k>tontino</k> tontine. Def.: Sistemo di mutuala asekuro,
inventita da Tonti (1653); IV-643.

<k>topo</k> <ex>(nav.)</ex> top; <k>topo granda</k> main. t.; <k>topmasto</k>
t.mast; <k>topseglo</k> t.sail; <k>topisto</k> topman.

<k>topika</k>, <k>topiko</k> <ex>(medicine or treatment)</ex> applied to, or
used for, a particular spot; <ex>(rhet., log.)</ex> general head;
argument drawn from the several circumstances and places of a
fact. Ex.: Remedio topika. Topiki da Aristoteles.

<k>tordar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to twist, wring, contort; <ex>(med.)</ex>
to strain, sprain; (of wood) to warp; <k>tord</k>(<k>ad</k>)<k>o</k>
twisting, wringing, torsion, sprain; <k>tordita</k> twisted, wry,
crooked; <k>tordita gesto</k>, <k>posturo</k> contortion; <k>tordar sua pedo</k>
to sprain one’s foot, or, to twist one’s foot.

<k>torefaktar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to torrefy: to dry, parch, roast
(by exposure to heat). Ex.: Torefaktar la kafeo-grani.

<k>torento</k> torrent: rushing stream (of water, words,
people, etc.); <k>torentala</k>, <k>atra</k> torrential; <k>lakrim torento</k>
flood of tears.

<k>torono</k> <ex>(nav.)</ex> strand (of a rope); (cf. <k>brino</k>).
Def.: Una de la kordi, qui kuntordita kompozas plu grosa kordo;
V-157.

<k>torpedo</k> (explosive) torpedo; <ex>(ich.)</ex> cramp-fish,
electric ray, torpedo(-fish); <k>torpedagar</k> to t. (<k>ulo</k>); <k>torpednavo</k>
t.-boat;

<k>torporar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to be benumbed, or in a state of
torpor (as from cold); <k>torporo</k> torpidity, numbness; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
dullness, inaction; (cf. <k>letargio</k>); <k>torporigar</k> to make
(<k>ulu</k>) t.
<k>torso</k> torso: trunk, chest, bust (of a person or statue).

<k>torsado</k> twisted fringe or cord; bullion (as of
epaulets).

<k>torto</k> pie (English sense) (cf. <k>tarto</k>); <k>tortuyo</k>
p. dish; <k>kolombo torto</k> pigeon p. Def.: Alta, cilindrata
kukajo plenigita per diversa (karnatra) manjaji kun sauco;
IV-642.

<k>tortikolo</k> <ex>(med.)</ex> torticollis: rheumatic pain
causing wry-neck; <ex>(fig.)</ex> stiff-neck, crick in the neck.

<k>tostar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to give a toast (<k>ad ulu</k>),
to drink a friend’s health; <k>tosto</k>toast(ing): drinking
(<k>ad ulu</k>) the health, the prosperity.

<k>tota</k> entire; whole (of one thing; cf. <k>omna</k>); <k>tote</k>
wholly, entirely; <k>toto</k>, <k>toteso</k> totality, entirety, whole; <k>totajo</k>
<ex>(objective)</ex> entity, entire thing; <k>entote</k> on the
whole, in the main; <k>dum la tota nokto</k> during the whole
night, throughout the night; <k>me es tote vua</k> I am totally
yours; <k>tote sola</k> entirely alone; <k>la toto esas plu
 granda kam una de la parti</k> the whole is larger than one of
its parts; <k>plura totaji tote distingata la una de la altra</k>
several entire things quite distinct from one another; <k>ne
 tote</k> not entirely (not quite); <k>tote ne</k> not at all.

<k>tra</k> (adv. <k>trae</k>)<k /> through, across (noting
passage or motion in crossing); <k>irar tra la urbo</k>, <k>tra la
 pordo</k> to go through the city, through the door. V. exp.: <k>tra</k>, <k>trans</k>, <k>transversa</k>Trans-irante la urbo, ni tra-iris turbo
di la habitanti ante ke ni povis tra-irar la urbo-pordo qua jacis
quale barilo transversa a ni voyo. E.: Crossing (to the other
side of )the city, we had to pass through a crowd of the
inhabitants before we could get through the gate of the city
which lay like a barrier across our path.

<k>trabo</k> beam, girder; (<k>trabeto</k>) joist, rafter; <k>trabizar</k>
to line (<k>ulo</k>) with b.s; <k>trabapogar</k> to shore, to prop
up; <k>trabaro</k> framework (of a building, ship).

<k>traborar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to bore through (as with a
gimlet).

<k>traco</k> trace: mark left by foot of man or beast; track;
footprint; <ex>(hunt.)</ex> trail; <k>sequar</k> (<k>ulu</k>)<k>per la traci</k>to follow by the track; <k>hike esas lua
 pedotraci</k>here are his footprints.

<k>tradicionar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to transmit, hand down (<k>ulo</k>)
by tradition; <k>tradiciono</k> tradition; <k>tradicionala</k>, <k>ata</k>, <k>tradicionita</k>
traditional; <k>tradicionalismo</k>traditionalism; <k>tradicionalisto</k>
traditionalist; <k>tradicionar ula fakti</k> to hand down certain facts.
Ex.: Ci esas la fakti traditionat a ni. Legi tradicionita.
Tradicionala expozado di la santa skriburo.

<k>tradukar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to translate (<k>ulo</k>, <k>de</k>...<k>ad</k>);
<k>traduko</k>, <k>tradukuro</k> <ex>(act, result)</ex> translation; <k>tradukanto</k>, <k>tradukinto</k>, <k>tradukero</k>, <k>tradukisto</k>translator; <k>tradukebla</k> translatable; <k>tradukendo</k>
article, exercise to be translated; <k>mis tradukar</k> to translate
wrongly. Ex.: Tradukar artiklo de la Angla a la Franca.

<k>traduktar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to lead across, through; (an
animal, a person).

<k>trafiko</k> traffic: movement of persons, goods, etc. Def.:
Movado o cirkulado en komunikilo (voyo, telegrafala lineo, e.c.);
III-328. Ex.: La trafiko ye ca strad-angulo esas tre densa.

<k>tragedio</k> <ex>(dramatic and fig.)</ex> tragedy; <k>tragediala</k>, <k>tragediatra</k> tragic; <k>tragediisto</k> tragedian; <k>tro tragediatre
 konsiderar ulo</k> to take a thing too seriously. Ex.: La
tragedii da Cornielle. La milito esis tragedio.

<k>trahizar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to betray, be false to; <k>trahizo</k>
betraying, treason; <k>trahizanto</k>, <k>trahizinto</k>, <k>trahizero</k>, <k>trahizemo</k> betrayer,
traitor; <k>trahizema</k> treacherous, perfidious; <k>trahizajo</k> act
of treason; <k>stato trahizo</k> high treason; <k>trahize</k>, <k>trahizante</k>
treacherously. Ex.: Trahizar sua patrio, la fido di ulu.

<k>trairar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to go, travel through (cf. <k>transirar</k>).
Ex.: Trairar torento, lando, urbo, pordo.<k />

<k>traito</k> feature (of the face), lineament; trait,
characteristic; <k>el havas mikra traiti</k> she has small
features; <k>to esas la traito karakteriziva di ta epoko</k>
that was a characteristic (trait) of that age.

<k>trajetar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to traject (light); to throw (<k>ulo</k>)
through or across.

<k>trakar</k> <ex>(tr.)(hunt.)</ex> to drive game, to beat up (a
wood); <ex>(fig.)</ex> to ferret out, close in on; hem in; cut off
on all sides; <k>trako</k> hunting out; <k>trakanto</k>, <k>trakero</k> a game
driver, a beater; <k>trakar la furteri</k>to hunt out, or close in
on the thieves. V. exp.: Trakar indikas specala modo di chaso: on
ne nur cirkondas e forpulsas la vildo, ma on kontinue diminutas
la cirklo en qua ol esas enklozita, tale ke ol ne povas eskapar.
Ica vorto esas tre expresiva ed energioza en mataforal uzo;
IV-512.

<k>traktar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to treat: behave to, or toward (<k>ulu</k>);
deal with; handle, discourse on (a subject); <ex>(chem.)</ex> to
subject (<k>ulo</k>) to the action of; (N.B. not medical; cf. <k>kuracar</k>);
<k>trakt</k>(<k>ad</k>)<k>o</k> treatment: manner of acting;
handling. Ex.: Traktar ulu quale o kom amiko. Trakto di problemo.

<k>traktato*</k> treatise; <k>traktato pri kemio</k> t. on
chemistry.

<k>tramo</k> tram-, street-car-rail; <k>tramvoyo</k> tramway,
street railway; <k>tramveturo</k> tramcar, street-car.

<k>tramplar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to stamp (the feet); <ex>(of
horses)</ex> to paw (the ground). Def.: Frapar la sulo per la
pedi, sen avancar; VI-115. Agitar la pedi pro nervozeso od altra
sentimento: nepacienteso, iraco, e.c.; IV-587.

<k>tranar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to draw, drag along, trail (<k>ulo</k>, <k>dop su</k>)<k>;</k> <k>su</k> to creep along, crawl; <k>tranajo</k>
anything which drags; trail, train (of a dress); <k>tranata voco</k>
<ex>(fig.)</ex> dragging voice. Ex.: Elua robo tranesas. Du kavali
tranis la glit-veturo. Tranado di la pedi. La chasero tranis su
alonge la sulo por proximigar su ad la vildo. <k />

<k>trancar</k> <ex>(intr., hypnotic, epilep.)</ex> to be in a trance
or in a hypnotic state; <k>tranceskar</k> to go into a t. Def.: Esar
en stando nekoncianta dum epilepsio, hipnoto, e.c.<k />

<k>tranchar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to cut (completely) through, cut off,
carve (meat); (cf. <k>detranchar</k>); <k>tranch</k>(<k>ad</k>)<k>o</k>
cut(ting); <k>tranchiva</k>, <k>tranchema</k> tranchant; cutting, decisive
(tone); <k>tranchilo</k> a cutting instrument, as a knife, etc.; <k>tranchilvendisto</k>
edged-tool seller; <k>tranchantajo</k> edge of a knife, etc.; <k>tranchar
 la pako</k> <ex>(at play)</ex> to cut the cards; <k>tranchar la ligno</k>, <k>la pano</k> to cut wood, bread. V. exp.: <k>Tranchar</k> esas <k>trasekar</k>,
separar en du o plura peci. <k>Sekar</k> esas agar per kultelo o
simila instrumento, plu o min profunde; esas granda difero inter:
<k>me sekis</k>….<k>e me tranchis mea lingro</k>. <k>Incizar</k>
esas facar mikra e nur surfacala seko (precipio kirurgiala). <k>Skarifikar</k>
(teknikal vorto) esas incizar la pelo por l’apliko di
ventuzi; II-646. <k />

<k>tranquila</k> <ex>(physical and mental)</ex> tranquil, quiet,
still, not in motion; <k>tranquileso</k> tranquility; <k>tranquiligar</k> to
(make) still. Def.: Qua esas sen agitado. Ex.: Tranquila vicino,
strado, infanto. Restez tranquila. V. exp. vid. <k>kalma</k>.
<k />

<k>trans</k> <ex>(prep.)</ex> on the other side of, beyond, across,
over (with or without motion); (cf. <k>tra</k>); <k>transe</k>
beyond; <k>transa</k> which is on the other side; <k>transajo</k>
object beyond or on other side; the hereafter; <k>trans la
 rivero</k>, <k>la monto</k>, <k>la muro</k> on the other side of the river,
the mountain, the wall; <k>transoceana lando</k> land across
the ocean; <k>ni irez trans la rivero</k> let us go to the other
side of the river. Ant.: <k>cis</k>. <k />

<k>transaktar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to come to terms, to compound,
compromise (<k>kun ulu</k>, <k>pri ulo</k>); <k>transakto</k>compromise,
adjustment; <k>transaktema</k> inclined to compromise. Def.: Konciliar
deskonkordo per reciproka konceso. Ex.: Esas plu bona transaktar
kam procesar. On devas ne transaktar kun sua honoro. <k />

<k>transbordar*</k> <ex>(tr., nav.)</ex> to transship; <k>transbordo</k>, <k>transbordajo</k>
<ex>(act, object)</ex> transshipment. Def.: (Trans-)portar personi
od kozi de un navo (od, altra moyeni di transporto) ad altra.
<k />

<k>transferar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to transfer (<k>ulo ad ulu</k>);
(cf. <k>transportar</k>). Transfero di ula yuro ad altru. <k />

<k>transformar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to transform (<k>ulo ad ulo</k>)<k />
to change the form of; <k>transformesar</k> to be transformed; <k>transform</k>(<k>ad</k>)<k>o</k>, <k>transformeso</k> <ex>(act, state)</ex> transformation; <k>transformismo</k> <ex>(biol.)</ex>
transformism. <k />
<k>transfugar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to desert (to the enemy); <k>transanto</k>, <k>transinto</k> deserter, turncoat, transfuge.<k />

<k>transirar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to go across (to the other
side), to traverse (cf. <k>trairar</k>);<k>transar rivero</k> to
cross a river; <k>streta voyo transiras la foresto</k> a narrow
path lies across (or, crosses) the forest.<k />

<k>transitar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to be or pass in transit; <k>transito</k>transit(ion);
<k>transitala</k> transient: relating to transit (cf.<k>provizora</k>, <k>tempala</k>); <k>transitiva</k> <ex>(gram.)</ex> transitive. Ex.:
Komercaji transitas de una urbo ad altra. La transito de monarkio
a republiko. Transitala komercajo. Verbo transitiva.

<k>translacar</k> <ex>(tr., intr., mechan. and fig.)</ex> to
move, shift (<k>ulo</k>) from one place to another; <k>translaco</k>
translation: <ex>(mechan.)</ex> motion in which all points of the
moving body have at any instant the same velocity and direction
of motion. (Webster).<k />

<k>translojar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to move (from one house or
apartment to another).

<k>translucida</k> translucent: transmitting light imperfectly,
semi-transparent. Ex.: Vitro despolisita esas translucida. Ant.: <k>opaka</k>.

<k>transmigrar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to transmigrate: migrate
from one country to another; (of souls) to undergo
transmigration: the passing of a soul into another body.

<k>transmisar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to transmit. Ex.: la nervi
transmisas la impresi. Transmisar impero. Transmiso di lua vertui
a lua filii.

<k>transmutar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to transmute (<k>ulo ad ulo</k>).
Ex.: L’alkemiisti probis transmutar matali ad oro.

<k>transparar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to shine (through), glimmer,
be visible (<k>tra</k>, <k>sub ulo</k>); (cf. <k>lumar</k>); <k>transparanta</k>
transparent; (cf. <k>diafana</k>). Ex.: Brilanta objekti
transparas tra la vitro. Sun-radii transparas tra l’aquo.
Roki sub l’aquo esas transparanta per la sun-radii (pro ke
l’aquo esas diafana).

<k>transpasar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to go by or beyond (a place);
to exceed (one’s strength, etc.).

<k>transpirar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to transude, transpire, ooze
out, exhale; (cf. <k>exudar</k>, <k>sudorifar</k>); <ex>(fig. of news)</ex>
to transpire: be divulged, become known, leak out. Ex.: La humori
transpiras tra la pelo. Gasi transpiras de korpi mortinta. Pos la
recevo di ta telegramo, nula informo nova transpiris.

<k>transportar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to transport, convey; <k>transportnavo</k>
t. ship; <k>transportar su</k> to betake oneself , to proceed, repair
(to a place). Def.: Portar komercaji, e.c. de un loko ad altra.

<k>transpozar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to put (<k>ulo</k>) in another
place (further on), to displace; <ex>(mus.)</ex> to transpose.

<k>transsendar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to send (<k>ulo</k>) across,
to forward (cf. <k>transmisar</k>). Ex.: transsendar letro de
Francia ad Usa.

<k>transskribar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to rewrite (otherwise), to
transcribe (as, from shorthand to longhand); <ex>(mus.)</ex> to
write out; <k>transo</k>, <k>transuro</k> <ex>(act, result)</ex> transcription.

<k>transubstanciar*</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to transubstantiate;
change into another substance; <k>transubstancio</k> transubstantiation (as,
elements in the Eucharist).

<k>transvarsar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to decant: pour from one
vessel to another; to pour off: <ex>(surg.)</ex> to transfuse
(blood). V. exp.: vid. <k>rakar</k>.

<k>transversa</k> transverse; <k>transversal</k> athwart, running or
lying across; <k>transverse</k> crosswise; <k>transverso</k> transversal (line,
object), breadth; <k>transversa kuseno</k> bolster, long round pillow.
Ex.: Transversa lineo, arterio, strado.

<k>trapezo</k> (gymnastics) trapeze; <ex>(geom.)</ex> trapezium; <k>trapezala
 osto</k> trapezium; <k>trapezala muskulo</k> trapezius.

<k>trapikar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to pierce, run through (as with a
sword; cf. <k>traborar</k>). Ex.: La tunelo trapikas la monto. La
pluvo ne povas trapikar la nepermeebla vesto.

<k>trasar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to trace, draw: mark out, delineate,
chalk out; <k>traso</k>, <k>trasuro</k> <ex>(act, result)</ex> tracing; laying
out (of grounds, etc.); outline, sketch.

<k>tratar</k> <ex>(tr., com.)</ex> to draw (a bill of exchange)
on; <k>trato</k> draft, bill; <k>tratanto;</k> drawer; <k>tratato</k>
drawee; <k>alonjo trato</k> allonge: rider to a bill of exchange; <k>ni
 tratos vi per bilieto pos tri monati diskontenda da la
 diskontisti</k> we will draw on you a three months’ bill to
be discounted by the bill-brokers. <k />

<k>traurar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to be in mourning; <k>trauro</k>
mourning (cf. <k>chagreno</k>); <k>traurala vesto</k> m. dress; <k>portar
 granda trauro</k> to be in full or deep m.; <k>portar trauro pri
 ulu</k> to be (dressed) in m. for a person.

<k>travo</k> trave: a frame to confine an unruly horse or ox
while shoeing.

<k>traveo</k> truss (of a bridge); <ex>(arch.)</ex> bay (of
joists); (of a church) triforium. Def.: Intervalo di du trabi,
fosti, koloni, pilasti. (N.B. ne esas sempre apertita quale pordo
o fenestro); IV-644. <k />

<k>traverso</k> cross-bar, -piece, -beam, girder; <ex>(R.R.)</ex>
sleeper; <ex>(fort.)</ex> traverse; <k>traverseto</k> bracket. V. exp.:
Travers-eto esas stango horizontala, qua suportas tabuli di
armoro, di biblioteko, e.c.; IV-644.

<k>travestiar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to disguise (by assuming the
dress of a person of another sex or condition in life); (<ex>fig</ex>.
<k>burleske</k>) to travesty; <k>travestiita</k>, <k>travestiito</k> disguised
(person); (cf. <k>maskar</k>, <k>deformar</k>, <k>pariodar</k>). Travestiar
viro quale muliero, ula soldati quale rurano.

<k>travidar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to see, look through at; <k>traebla</k>
visible through (N.B. not transparent: <k>diafana</k>). Ex.: Me
travidas la stoni di fundo, en l’aquo = me vidas la stoni di
la fundo tra l’aquo.<k />

<k>travivar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to live through (a period, events);
to live to see (something happen).<k />

<k>tre</k> <ex>(adv.)</ex> very; <k>tre multa</k> very many, very
much; <k>tre granda</k> very great or large; <k>tre forta</k>
very strong. Ex.: Ca lando esas tre agreabla. To eventas tre
rare.

<k>treko</k> trail: footpath, unfinished road; (of race-course)
track; <k>trekojiro</k> winding of a trail.

<k>trelicho</k> coarse sacking, sackcloth; denim, dungaree
cloth. Def.: Speco de grosa tolo, qua uzesas nur por facar saki,
ma anke (laborala) vesti; IV-644.

<k>treliso</k>trellis-,<k />lattice-work (of wood or metal)
plaited wire-work; <k>trelisigar</k>, <k>trelisizar</k> to trellis, to lattice.

<k>trem(ad)ar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to tremble, shake, shiver,
quake (<k>de</k>, <k>pro</k>); <ex>(of wings)</ex> to flutter; (cf. <k>fremisar</k>, <k>trepidar</k>); <k>tremetar</k> to quiver, shiver; <ex>(of music)</ex>
to quaver; <ex>(of light)</ex> to flicker; <k>trem</k>(<k>ad</k>)<k>o</k>
trembling, trepidation, tremor; <k>tremigar</k> to cause (<k>ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>) to tremble; <k>ter tremo</k> earth tremor (cf. <k>terocilo</k>, <k>sismo</k>). Ex.: La tero trem(ad)is dufoye. Me trem(et)adis pro
koldeso. Tremado di la manui, di la nervi.

<k>trempar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to soak, steep, drench, wet
(thoroughly) (<k>ulo en ulo</k>). Ex.: Trempar la pano en la
vino. Trempar la linjaro. Trempado di la sulo per la pluvo.

<k>trepano</k> <ex>(surg., instr.)</ex> trepan; <ex>(gen.)</ex> any
boring instrument; <k>–agar</k> to trepan; to bore; <k>ligno
 trepano</k> auger; <k>sul trepano</k> soil-borer. Def.: Omna instrumenti
por borar o perforar (partkulare kirurgiala); III-165.

<k>trepidar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to shake, quiver, tremble; (cf. <k>tremar</k>).
Ex.: La trepidado di korpo-membri, di la nervi. Vapornavo
trepidadas pro la movado di sua mashinaro e la ondi.

<k>treso</k> tress, braid, twist; <k>tresigar</k> to braid, plait
(cf. <k>plektar</k>); <k>hartreso</k> tress of hair.

<k>tresayar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to give a start, be startled,
(feel a) thrill (<k>de</k>, <k>pro</k>); <k>tresayo</k> thrill, tremor,
start; <k>tresayar pro joyo</k> to feel a thrill of joy. Ex.: La
tondro-stroko donis tresayo a me.

<k>tresto</k> trestle, wooden horse: a horizontal piece with
four legs serving as a support; easel; <k>ponto tresto</k>
trestlework bridge.

<k>trezoro</k> treasure; <k>trezoreyo</k> treasury: place where t.
is found; <ex>(R.C. rel.)</ex> place for relics and ornaments: (cf.
<k>kaserio</k>); <k>trezorifar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex>, <k>trezorigar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex>
to treasure up, hoard up. Ex.: La trezori di la tero. Ca infanto
esas trezoro.

<k>tri</k> three (for derivatives cf. <k>du</k>); <k>trio</k> any
three things or persons united; trio, triade, triplet, trey; <k>triadek</k>
thirty; <k>triedro</k> (<k>triedraangulo</k>)<k /> <ex>(geom.)</ex>
trihedral; <k>triyara</k> triennial; <k>triesma lasta</k>
antepenultimate; <k>triuno</k>, <k>uneso</k> trinity; <k>triopla krono</k>
triple crown; <k>triseko</k> trisection; <k>triangulo</k> <ex>(geom.,
mus.)</ex> triangle; <k>triangulizo</k>, <k>triuro</k> triangulation.

<k>tribono</k> tribune: a Roman magistrate. Ex.: La tribono
acensis sur la tribuno.

<k>tribular</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to cause tribulation to, to
distress, afflict. Ta tempo tribulas nia psiki. La tribuli di
autoro.

<k>tribuno</k> (rostrum); grandstand (at races, etc.); <k>orgeno
 tribuno</k> organ loft.

<k>tribunalo</k> tribunal, court (of justice), bench, judgement
seat; <k>tribunalo kriminala</k> criminal court, assize court.

<k>tributar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to pay tribute (<k>ad ulu</k>); <k>tributo</k>
t.; <k>tributanta</k>(<k>ad</k>), <k>tributanto</k>, <k>tributero</k> tributary. Ex.:
Tributar a Caesar. Ta lando esas tributanta ad Anglia.

<k>«triduum»</k> <ex>(R.C. rel.)</ex> prayers continuing for
three days.

<k>triftongo</k> <ex>(gram.)</ex> triphthong. Def.: Grupo di tri
vokali formacanta un silabo; V-486.

<k>trigramo</k> trigram, trigraph. Def.: Grupo di tri literi
reprezentanta un sono; V-487.

<k>trikorna</k> three-horned; three-cornered; <k>tria chapelo</k>
(od, <k>trikorno</k>); three-cornered hat, shovel-hat.

<k>trikotar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to knit (a fabric) (cf. <k>krochar</k>);
<k>trikotilo</k> knitting needle or machine.

<k>trista</k> <ex>(of persons or things)</ex> sad, sorrowful,
mournful, cheerless, dispirited, doleful, gloomy; <k>tristega</k>
lugubrious; <k>tristeso</k> sadness, dreariness; <k>tristigar</k> to
sadden, throw gloom over. Ex.: Trista informo, vizajo, adio. La
morto di mia amiko tristigas me. Ant.: <k>Gaya</k>, <k>joyoza</k>, <k>kontenta</k>.

<k>triumfar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to triumph, be triumphant (<k>pri</k>);
<k>triumfe</k> in t.; <k>triumfala procesiono</k> triumphant procession; <k>persono
 triumfanta</k> triumphant person; <k>triumfarko</k> arch of t.; <k>triumfar
 pri sua enemiki</k> to t. over one’s enemies.

<k>triviala</k> trivial, trite, commonplace, stale; <k>trivialeso</k>
triteness; <k>trivialajo</k> triviality, banality; <k>triviala verajo</k>
truism; <k>trivialigar</k> to make banal. Ex.: Trivial expresuro,
stilo.

<k>tro(e)</k> <ex>(adv.)</ex> too, too much (Note: <k>Tro</k> may
be used by itself before verbs, adjectives and adverbs, but with
substantives, <k>multa</k> etc. is added: <k>el tro amas il; tro
 multa homi</k>); <k>tro(e)multa</k>, <k>granda</k>, <k>plena</k>, <k>frua</k> too many,
great, full, early; <k>il drinkas troe</k> he drinks too much; <k>lu
 tro</k>(<k>multa</k>) <k>mentias</k> he lies too much; <k>tro(e)a</k>
too, over-great, excessive; <k>troa bruiso</k>, <k /> od, <k>tro granda
 bruiso</k> too much noise; <k>un glaso troa</k> (od, <k>tro
 multe</k>)<k /> one glass too much.

<k>trogo</k> trough (as for animals); hod, tray (as for carrying
mortar); (cf. <k>vazo</k>), <k>trogoroto</k> bucket (of a
water-wheel); <k>trogedo</k> hodful, troughful.

<k>trompar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to deceive, impose upon, delude
(denotes intention; cf. <k>erorigar</k>, <k>deceptar</k>, <k>dupigar</k>); <k>tromp</k>(<k>ad</k>)<k>o</k>
deception, imposition, cheating; <k>trompuro</k> imposture; <k>trompanta</k>, <k>trompiva</k>, <k>ema</k> deceitful; <k>trompiva</k> fallacious. Ex.: Trompar
la fido di ulu per ulo.

<k>trono</k> throne; <k>tronsidar</k> to sit enthroned; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
to lord it over; <k>diskurso de la trono</k> speech from the t.; <k>entronigar</k>
to enthrone.

<k>trotar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to trot (along); <k>trotetar</k> to go
at a jog-trot; (of children) to toddle; <k>troteskar</k> to fall
into a trot; <k>trotigar</k> to cause to trot, to trot (a horse).
<k />

<k>trotuaro</k> sidewalk, pavement: footway of stone, asphalt,
etc. <k />
<k>trouzar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to use to excess, abuse.<k />

<k>trovar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to find, discover, come across; <k>trovajo</k>
thing found; (treasure-) trove; <ex>(fig.)</ex> godsend, windfall.
Ex.: Trovar trezoro, kulpo, voyo, amiko. <k />

<k>truo</k> hole, gap (cf. <k>aperturo</k>, <k>kavo</k>, <k>brecho</k>); <k>truifar</k>
to produce holes; <k>truoza</k>full of holes; <k>truizar</k> to
cover (<k>ulo</k>) with holes; <k>truizita</k> bored with holes; <k>mus
 truo</k> mousehole; <k>hom truo</k> manhole; <k>truifilo</k>, <k>truizilo</k>
punch, hole-punching press; <k>trusegilo</k> (key-)hole saw.
<k />

<k>trubaduro</k> troubadour. V. exp.: <k>Trubaduri</k> apartenas a
Suda Francia, e <k>truvero</k> a Norda Francia (e vicina landi);
IV-645. <k />

<k>trublar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to trouble, disturb, muddle: throw
into disorder; <ex>(of liquids)</ex> to make turbid or muddy; (cf. <k>konfuzigar</k>, <k>perturbar</k>); <k>trublar l’aquo</k> to disturb or muddy the
water; <k>trublar la vino</k> to make the wine turbid; <k>trublar la
 digestado</k> to disorder or disturb the digestion; <k>trublar la
 raciono</k> (<k>di ulu</k>)<k /> to disorder or disturb the
reason; <k>mento trublita</k> disordered, disturbed mind. <k />

<k>truflo</k> <ex>(bot.)</ex> truffle (genus: Tuber); <k>truflizar</k>
to stuff, or cover with t.s. <k />

<k>truismo</k> truism. Def.: Verajo evidenta, triviala, di aqua
l’enunco esas neutila, do ridinda; V-487. <k />

<k>truko</k> <ex>(R.R.)</ex> flat-car (cf. <k>varvagono</k>). Def.:
Fervoyala, platformatra var-vagono neklozita. <k />

<k>trumpo</k> trump (at cards); <k>ludar trumpo</k> to play, or lead
with a t. <k />

<k>trumpeto</k> trumpet: large, keyless bugle (cf. <k>klariono</k>);
<k>trumpetagar</k>, <k>plear</k> to play the t.; <ex>(fig.)</ex> to t. forth,
spread abroad; <k>sonigar la trumpeto</k> to sound the t. <k />

<k>trunko</k> <ex>(also geom.)</ex> trunk of a tree; <k>trunkigar</k> <ex>(geom.)</ex>
to truncate; <k>trunka kono</k> truncate a cone. <k />

<k>trupo</k> troop, band: company of persons having same
occupation; <ex>(theat.)</ex> company, troop; <ex>(of animals)</ex>
band, herd, flock; <k>trupacho</k>gang; <k>trupala</k>, <k>trupatra</k>, <k>trupema</k>
gregarious; <k>navo trupo</k> ship’s crew; <k>truponavo</k>
t. ship; <k>kavalrio trupo</k> cavalry t.; <k>muton trupo</k> flock
of sheep; <k>trupe marchar</k> to walk in a group. <k />

<k>trusar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to tuck up, put a tuck in; turn up, pin
up, tie up. V. exp.: <k>Trusar</k> esas nek <k>levar</k>, nek <k>faldar</k>
on trusas robo, mantelo, maniki, pantalono, bordi di chapelo,
mustacho; mem figurale nazo esas trusita; III-471. <k />

<k>tu</k> <ex>(acc.:</ex> <k>tun;</k><ex>pl.: </ex><k>tui</k><ex> )</ex>
thou: familiar form of 2nd person singular: you; used
in speaking to a child or an intimate friend; <k>tua</k> your;
thy, thine; <k>tuajo e meajo</k> thine and mine; <k>tudicar</k>
to say thee and thou (<k>ad ulu</k>). Ex.: Tu ne sat respektas
tua olda patrulo. <k />

<k>tualetar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to make one’s toilet: wash and
dress; careful adjustment of dress, etc.; <k>tualeto</k> toilet; <k>tualeteyo</k>
dressing room; <k>tualettablo</k> dressing table; <k>tualettuko</k>
towel. <k />

<k>tubo</k> tube, pipe (of lead, iron, etc.); <k>tubizar</k>, <k>tubagar</k>to
tube, pipe: put tubes in (<k>ulo</k>); <k>tubala</k>, <k>tubatra</k>, <k>tuboza</k>
tubular; <k>vitra –o</k>glass t.; <k>kamen tubo</k>
chimney-flue, shaft. <k />

<k>tubero</k> <ex>(anat., bot.)</ex> tuberosity; node; <ex>(of wood)</ex>
knot; <k>tuberoza</k> tuberous, nodose; knotty, gnarled; (cf. <k>tuberkulo</k>).

<k>tuberkloso</k> <ex>(med.)</ex> tuberculosis, consumption; <k>tuberklosala</k>, <k>tuberklosoza</k> tubercular, tuberculous: relating to the disease; <k>tuberklosika</k>, <k>tuberklosik(ul)o</k> tubercular person).

<k>tuberkulo</k> <ex>(bot.)</ex> tubercle; <ex>(physiol.)</ex> a
small tumor (tumour), or tumorlike elevation; (cf. <k>tubero</k>).

<k>tufo</k> tuft, bunch, cluster, clump, wisp (of straw:
assemblage of things of the same nature: threads, feathers, hair,
etc. (cf. <k>penacho</k>); <k>har tufo</k> tuft of hair; <k>arbor
 tufo</k>clump of trees; <k>herbo tufo</k> bunch of herbs; <k>tufnodo</k>
knot (of ribbons), favor (favour); <k>pudro tufo</k> powder-puff;
<k>tufizar</k>, <k>tufifar</k> to form into t.s.

<k>tuko</k> (a piece of) cloth; (cf. <k>drapo</k>, <k>stofo</k>); <k>naz
 tuko</k> handkerchief: <k>vish tuko</k> (dish-) wiper, duster (of
cloth).

<k>tulipo</k> <ex>(plant, flower)</ex> tulip; <k>tuliparboro</k>t.
tree, whitewood, white poplar: liriodendron (Liriodendron
Tulipifera).

<k>tumefaktar</k> <ex>(tr., med.)</ex> to tumefy, cause to swell;
<k>tumefakto</k>, <k>tumefakturo</k> tumefaction.

<k>tumultar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to raise a tumult, disturbance,
uproar, hubbub, to (cause a) row, a riot; <k>tumulto</k> tumult,
riot; <k>tumulteto</k> row, squabble, brawl; bustle; <k>tumulte</k>
disorderly and noisy, tumultuously; <k>tumultala</k>, <k>tumultoza</k>, <k>tumultema</k>, <k>tumultatra</k>
tumultuous, turbulent, riotous.

<k>tuniko</k> <ex>(coat of soldiers, pupils)</ex> tunic, an
antique undergarment; <ex>(anat.)</ex> coat, film, tunic (of the
eye); wall (of the stomach); <ex>(bot.)</ex> coat, integument; <k>tunikiero</k>
<ex>(zool.)</ex> tunicate.

<k>tupio</k> (spinning-, peg-) top; <k>ludar per tupii</k> to
spin tops.

<k>turo</k> tour; <k>turisto</k> tourist; <k>mondo turo</k>
world tour; <k>inspekto turo</k> tour, round of inspection. Ex.:
Facar turo di la mondo, di urbo, di lando, di domeno.

<k>turbo</k> <ex>(of persons)</ex> crowd, throng, multitude; <k>turbacho</k>
mob; <k>turbe</k> in crowds.

<k>turbino</k> <ex>(mechan.)</ex> turbine; <k>turbinnavo</k> t. ship;
<k>vapor turbino</k> steam t.

<k>turmo</k> tower; <ex>(at chess)</ex> castle; <ex>(nav.)</ex>
turret; <k>Babel turmo</k> tower of Babel; <k>turmonavo</k>
turret-ship.

<k>turnar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to turn (from right to left),
turn around, to (cause to) move circularly), twist, whirl, wheel
around; (cf. <k>jirar</k>, <k>rotacar</k>, <k>renversar</k>, <k>volvar</k>, <k>tornar</k>); <k>turno</k>
turn; <k>turnar la kapo</k>, <k>la klefo</k> to turn the head, the key; <k>roto
 turno</k> a turn of a wheel; <k>klefklozar duturne</k>(od, <k>per
 di turni</k>) <k>la pordo</k> to double lock the door; <k>miturno</k>
half turn; <k>riturno</k> turn about, face about, change of
side; <k>turnanta dervisho</k> whirling dervish; <k>turnoplako</k>, <k>turntablo</k> turntable; <k>turnorgeno</k> hand-organ; <k>turnohoko</k>
swivel; <k>turnokesto</k> revolving box (as for foundlings in a
convent); <k>turnopordo</k>, <k>turnbarilo</k> turnstile; <k>turnokruco</k>, <k>turnbarilo</k> tourniquet; <k>turnomorbo</k> <ex>(vet.)</ex>
staggers; <k>skrubturnilo</k> turn-screw; screwdriver; <k>turnokontilo</k>revolution counter (on an engine). V. exp.: vid. <k>jirar</k>.

<k>turnirar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to hold a tournament, to joust,
to take part in a tourney.

<k>tusar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to cough; <k>tusetar</k> to cough:
clear one’s throat, to hem; <k>tusaceso</k> fit of coughing.

<k>tushar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to touch, be in contact
with.. (N.B. not concern); to put one’s hand, foot, etc.
(on); (cf. <k>palpar</k>, <k>kontaktar</k>, <k>kontigua</k>); <k>tushosenso</k>
sense of touch; <k>tushala</k>, <k>iva</k> tactile; <k>tushebla</k> tangible
(cf. <k>palpebla</k>). Ex.: Tushar ulo per la fingri. Lua pedi
tushis la sulo. Regardez ol, ma ne tushez.

<k>tutelar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to be guardian of <k>(ulu) tutelesar da
 ulu</k> to be under the guardianship of someone; <k>tuteligar</k>, <k>ulu</k>
to place someone under the guardianship (of another person); <k>tutel(ad)o</k>, <k>tuteleso</k> <ex>(act, state)</ex> guardianship, tutelage; <k>tutelanto</k>, <k>tutelero</k> guradian; <k>tutelanta</k> tutelary, protecting, guardian;
<k>tutelato</k> ward.

<k>tuvar</k> <ex>(tr., nav.)</ex> to warp: move a ship or boat by
a rope or cable attached to some fixed object; <k>tuvokablo</k>
stream-line, warping-hawser. V. exp.: <k>Tuvar</k> ne esas
sinonima di <k>remorkar</k>. Navo tuvas (su ed altri) per kateno
fixa en rivero o kanalo; IV-645.

<k>ube</k> (<ex>adv</ex>.) where; <k>adube</k> whither?; where to? (with motion), to what place?; 
<k>deube</k>, <k>ekube</k> from where? whence?; <k>altrube</k> elsewhere, somewhere else; 
<k>irgube</k> anywhere, wherever; <k>nulube</k> nowhere; <k>omnube</k> everywhere; <k>traube</k> 
through what place, which way?; <k>ulube</k> somewhere; <k>me ne savas ube il esas</k> 
I do not know where he is; <k>adube vu</k>, <k>vu volas irar?</k> where do you wish to go?; 
<k>dicez a me de ube vu venas</k> tell me where you are from; <k>traube vu iros?</k> 
which way will you go?; <k>ube vu habitas?</k> where do you live?
<k>ubiqua</k> ubiquitous; <k>ubiqueso</k> ubiquity. Def.: Qua esas omnaloke; IV-270.

<k>ucelo</k>, <k>ucelulo</k>, <k>ucelino</k> bird; <k>uceleyo</k> place for birds; aiviary; <k>ucelnesto</k> bird’s-nest; 
<k>ucelkaptar</k> (<ex>intr</ex>.) to catch b.s; <k>ucelvendisto</k> b.dealer; <k>ucelo migranta</k> 
migratory b., b. of passage; <k>ucelo raptanta</k> b. of prey; <k>paradiz ucelo</k> b. of paradise; 
<k>ucelvido</k> bird’s-eye view; <k>ucelire</k>: as the b. flies; in a straight line.

<k>ula</k> some, any: indicates a certain, but only partly defined person or object; 
(<ex>semi-indefinite article</ex>) a, an (used only where it is desired to emphasize indefiniteness); 
<k>ulo</k> something; <k>ulu</k> someone, somebody, anyone; <k>uli</k> some, any (persons or things); 
<k>uldie</k> some day; <k>ulloke</k>, <k>ulube</k> somewhere; <k>ulmaniere</k> (od, <k>ule</k>)<k /> 
in some manner or way; <k>ulu altra</k> someone else; <k>ula altra</k> some other; <k>ulfoye</k> 
once, one time; <k>ultempe</k>ever, sometime(s). V. exp.: <k>Ula</k> ne indikas kompleta nedetermineso 
(quan <k>irga</k> expresus plu juste), ma mi-determineso. <k>Ula</k> povas anke ludar la rolo 
di la nedfinita artiklo, se (o kande) on trovas ica necesa. Ex.: Me stacas avan la biblioteko 
di amiko (me ne dicas: di ula amiko, nam me pensas (pri) nula amiko partikulare o predere); 
me dicas a lu: «Me deziras libro». To signifikas: «Me deziras lektar, donez a me 
(irga) libro». Ma se me dicas: «Me deziras <k>ula</k> libro», to signifikas:  
«Me deziras lektar partikulara libro (konocata da me, o ja lektita),» quan me ne povas indikar 
plu exacte, pro ke me obliviis l’autoro, o la titulo: ma me tamen havas l’ideo plu o min 
konfuza di ta libro, e ne di altra: adminime, di libro apartenanta ad «ula» speco o 
relatanta «ula» temo, quan me povas definar; III-28. Note: <k>Ula</k>, <k>irga: Ula</k> 
is used in a semi-indefinite sense, <k>irga</k> emphasizes complete indefiniteness. Ex.: 
<k>ula maniero</k> some manner or way; <k>irga maniero</k> any manner or way whatever; 
<k>ula dio en la lasta monato</k> one day (= a certain day, but date not specified; <k>irga dio</k> 
would signify any day whatever); <k>ula viro decensis de Ierusalem a Ierico</k> a certain man 
(name not specified) went down from J. to J.; <k>irga viro</k> would signify any man whatever.

<k>ulcero</k> ulcer; -ala, <k>ulceratra</k> ulcerous; <k>ulcerifar</k> (in<ex />tr.), <k>ulcerizar</k> 
(t<ex />r.): to ulcerate; <k>ulcerifo</k>, <k>ulcerizo</k> ulceration; <k>ulcerigar</k> to cause (<k>ulo</k>) 
to ulcerate.

<k>ultra</k> ultra: beyond due limit; further, additional; <k>ultra zelo</k> extreme, exaggerated zeal; 
<k>ultra</k>, <k>ultre royalisto</k> ultra-royalist, royalist in an excessive degree; 
<k>ultre</k> (<ex>prep., adv.</ex>) besides, further, moreover, in addition (to this); <k>ultre ke</k> 
(<ex>conj.</ex>) besides (that) (followed by verb). 
Ex.: Ultre, me volas dicar  Ultre la prezenta infinitivo, Ido havas pasinta e futura infinitivo. 
Ultre ke, el esas richa, el esas bela e saja. Ultre mea patrala linguo, me savas plura altri. 
V. exp.: <k>Ultre</k>, <k>pluse: Ultre</k> esas prepoziciono, qua qua signifikas: adjunte ad  
Exemple: «Ultre mea repasto me prenis kafeo.» Do <k>ultre</k> grande diferas de <k>plus</k>, 
qua indikas la kozo adjuntata. Advere de la matematikal vidpunto la difero ne esas grava, pro ke A + B = B + A. 
Ma en la komuna vivo l’ordino ne esas indiferanta, sive pro la tempo, sive pro l’importo relativa e tre 
neegala di l’adicionendi. Exemple, l’antea frazo equivalas: « Me prenis mea repasto <k>plus</k> 
kafeo». Esus ridinda dicar: «Me prenis kafeo <k>plus</k> mea repasto», kontre ke on povas 
dicar tre bone: «Me prenis kafe <k>ultre</k> mea repasto.» De to konsequas, ke on nultempe 
bezonas adverbigar <k>ultre</k> la adverbo uzenda esas sempre <k>pluse</k>, <k /> qua anuncas l’adjunto 
di <k>altra</k> kozo a l’unesma o predicita; VII-481.

<k>ulular</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to ululate: (<ex>of owls</ex>) to hoot; (<ex>of dogs, wolves, etc.</ex>) 
to howl.

<k>un</k> (<ex>cardinal</ex>) one (for derivative forms, cf. <k>du</k>); <k>una</k> one (adj. showing unity); 
<k>uno</k> (<ex>arith.</ex>) unit; <k>unajo</k> (<ex>objective</ex>) unit; <k>unu</k> one (person); <k>uneso</k> 
unity, oneness; <k>unesala</k> unitary; <k>unesma</k> first (<ex>abbr.</ex>: 1a); <k>unigar</k> 
to unify: to form into one (cf. <k>uniformigar</k>); <k>unigo</k> unification; <k>unfoye</k> once, one time; 
<k>unesme</k> first, at first, first of all; <k>unesme on devas studiar e pose on darfas ludar</k> 
first you should study and afterwards you play; <k>l’una e l’altra</k> the two together; 
<k>l’una o l’altra</k> one of the two; <k>li amis l’una l’altra</k> they liked one another 
(or, each other); <k>el amis nek l’una nek l’atra</k> she loved neither; <k>nek l’una 
 nek l’altra venos</k> neither will come; <k>unkolora</k> one-colored. Ex.: La kombatinti vundis 
l’una l’altra. Li vovis fideleso l’una a l’altra (od, la una a l’altra). 
La Una Santa Eklezio. Unu dicis ico, la altru dicis ito. Un ed un facas du.

<k>uncionar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to anoint (<k>ulu</k>, <k>per ulo</k>); <k>extrema unciono</k> (<ex>R.C. rel.</ex>) 
extreme unction; (cf. <k>unguento</k>).

<k>unglo</k> (<ex>anat.</ex>) nail, claw, talon; <k>ungloza</k> unguiculated; <k>emundar</k> (od, <k>taliar</k>) 
<k>sua ungli</k> to trim, cut one’s nails; <k>la kato unglotenas su ye l’arboro</k> 
the cat clings to the tree.

<k>uniforma</k> uniform; (of movement) regular; <k>uniformo</k> (<ex>regimentals</ex>) uniform; <k>uniformeso</k> 
uniformity (cf. <k>monotoneso</k>); <k>uniformigar</k> to make (<k>ulo</k>) u.; <k>soldat uniformo</k> soldier’s u.; 
<k>granda uniformo</k> full dress u. Def.: Qua havas la sama formo; simila. Ex.: Uniforma domi, stilo, vesto. 
Uniformeso di opiniono.

<k>unika</k> unique; without another of the same kind; only, single, sole; (<ex>fig.</ex>) unequalled, 
unrivalled, unparalleled, unprecedented (cf. <k>nura</k>); <k>unikeso</k> uniqueness; <k>unikajo</k> a u. object; 
<k>unika filio</k> only child; <k>unika talento</k> u. talent.

<k>unionar</k> (<ex>tr., immaterial sense</ex>) to unite (cf. <k>juntar</k>, <k>ligar</k>); <k>uniono</k>, <k>unionuro</k> union, 
conjuction (cf. <k>konkordo</k>); <k>uniono postala</k> postal u. Ex.: Unionar la plezuri a l’aferi. 
Unionar la gefianciti. Uniono laboristala. La spirito di unioneso.

<k>universo</k> universe; <k>universala</k> universal; <k>universaleso</k> universality; 
<k>universigar</k> to make (<k>ulo</k>) universal; <k>universalisti</k> (<ex>rel.</ex>) universalists.
<k>unlatera</k> unilateral; (<ex>jur.</ex>) binding on one party only.

<k>urbo</k> city, large town; (cf. <k>civito</k>); <k>urbego</k> a large c.: (cf. 
<k>metropolo</k>); <k>urbala</k> urban; <k>urbodomo</k> city-hall; <k>urbestro</k> mayor.

<k>urino</k> urine; <k>urinala</k> urinary; <k>urinifar</k> to urinate, make water (cf. 
<k>miktar</k>); <k>urinvazo</k> urinal, pot; <k>urinifeyo</k> (public) urinal.

<k>urjar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to be urgent, pressing; <k>urjigar</k> to urge (<k>ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>); 
<k>urjanta</k> urgent; <k>urjanteso</k> urgency; <k>la kazo urjas</k> it is an u. case; <k>en urjanta kazo</k> 
in case of urgency.
<k>urogalo</k> capercailzie: the largest European grouse (Tetrao urogallus).

<k>urso</k>, <k>ursulo</k>, <k>ursino</k> (<ex>zool.</ex>) bear (genus: Ursus); <k>ursyuno</k> young b.; 
<k>granda</k>, <k>mikra urso</k> (<ex>astron.</ex>) Great, Little Bear; <k>ursala</k> ursine.

<k>urtiko</k> (stinging-)nettle (genus: Urtica); <k>urtikago</k> (<ex>med.</ex>) urtication: whipping or 
stinging with nettles.

<k>ushero</k> usher (judicial courts, etc.). Def.: Ta qua komisesas oficale por konocigar ed 
exekutigar la judiciala decidi.

<k>utensilo</k> utensil, tool, instrument, implement; <k>utensili koqu(ey)ala</k> kitchen u.; 
<k>utensili kultivala</k> farming tools.

<k>utila</k> useful, of use; <k>utileso</k> (<ex>quality</ex>) utility, usefulness; 
<k>utilajo</k> utility, useful object; <k>utilesar</k> to be useful (<k>ad</k>); to be used (<k>por</k>); 
<k>utileskar</k> to become u.; <k>utiligar su utila</k> to make oneself u.; <k>utiligar</k> to utilize, 
turn to good use, turn to account, avail oneself of; <k>utiligo</k> utilization; <k>utilismo</k> 
(<ex>philos.</ex>) utilitarianism; <k>utilisto</k> utilitarian; <k>utilista</k>, <k>utilismala</k> utilitarian.

<k>uzar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to use, employ: make use of (<k>ulo</k>); to wear out (clothing, etc.); 
<k>uzo</k>, <k>uzado</k> use, usage (cf. <k>kusumo</k>, <k>utileso</k>); <k>uzoyuro</k> right of use; 
<k>uzi e kustumi</k> ways and customs; <k>vestaro ja uzita</k> worn clothing; <k>uzar la vestaro</k> 
to wear out clothing. Ex.: Uzar violento, remediilo. Vorto rare uzata.
<k>uzufruktar</k> (<ex>tr., jur.</ex>) to have the usufruct of (<k>ulo</k>).
<k>uzukaptar</k> (<ex>tr., jur.</ex>) to have the usucaption of (<k>ulo</k>).

<k>uzurpar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to usurp (<k>ulo de ulu</k>); to encroach upon, trench upon, infringe; 
<k>uzurpo</k> usurpation, encroachment. Ex.: Uzurpar la trono, ula yuro, povo, domeno.

<k>macedonio</k> macedoine: a dish consisting of a medley of
fruit and vegetables; <ex>(fig.)</ex> medley, hodgepodge.

<k>macerar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to macerate: soften by
steeping.

<k>«macfarlane»</k> macfarlane: a kind of overcoat without
sleeves and with a mantle.
<k>madono</k> madonna: a picture or statue of the Virgin Mary.

<k>madrigalo</k> madrigal: a part song or glee; a little
amorous poem.

<k>maestro</k>, <k>maestrulo</k>, <k>maestrino</k> maestro: a teacher of eminence, or
one eminently skilled in some art or science; <k>maestrverko</k>
master-piece.
<k>magnato</k> magnate: a nobleman of Poland or Hungary.

<k>magneto</k> magnet; <k>magnetopetro</k> loadstone; <k>magnetigar</k>
to magnetize; <k>magneta agulo</k> magnetic needle; <k>magneteso</k> <ex>(property)</ex>
magnetism.

<k>magnetizar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to mesmerize (<k>ulu</k>); <k>magnetiz(ad)o</k>
mesmerizing; animal magnetism; <k>magnetizala</k> mesmeric; (cf. <k>hipnotar</k>).

<k>magra</k> lean, meager, lank, spare; <ex>(of things)</ex>
poor, sorry, scant, meager; <k>magr(ul)o</k> a lean person; <k>(la)
 magrajo</k> the lean (of meat); <k>magrigar</k>, <k>magreskar</k> to make,
become lean; <k>magrega</k>, <k>magracha</k> emaciated. Ex.: Magra Homo,
vizajo, bovo, karno. <ex>(fig.)</ex> Magra burso, repasto, sulo,
amuzo. Ant.: <k>grasa.</k>

<k>mahagono</k> <ex>(wood)</ex> mahogany; <k>mahagoniero</k> m. tree;
(Swietenia mahagoni); <k>mahagona litoframo</k> m. bedstead.

<k>majesto</k> majesty, supreme grandeur, august dignity,
stateliness; (cf. <k>Sinioro</k>, <k>la rejo</k>, <k />e.c.); <k>majestoza</k>
majestic; <k>majestolezo</k> lesé majeste.

<k>majora</k> of full age; <ex>(mus.)</ex> major; <k>majoro</k>, <k>majorulo</k>, <k>majorino</k> one who has attained his majority; <ex>(mus. and logic)</ex>
major; <k>majoreso</k> majority: legal age. Ant.:<k>minora.</k>

<k>majorato</k> majorat; <ex>(in France)</ex> landed property
attached to a title and descending with it; entailed estate.

<k>majoritato</k>majority: more than half of a given number or
group; (cf. <k>plumulto</k>).

<k>makadamo</k> macadam; <k>makadamizar</k> to macadamize: cover a
road with small broken stones.

<k>makako</k> <ex>(zool.)</ex> macaque: a genus (Macaca) of
short-tailed monkeys.

<k>makaroniko</k> macaronic. Def.: Dicesas pri verki kompozita
en Latino barbara e burleska; IV-394.

<k>makulo</k> <ex>(also fig.)</ex> macula: spot, blotch, stain; <k>makulizar</k>
to blot, stain, daub, smear; <k>makuloza</k>, <k>makulizita</k> spotted,
speckled; <k>makuletizar</k> to spot, speckle, fleck; <k>sen makula</k>
spotless; <k>makulole</k>, <k>fangomakulo</k> oil-, mud-stain; <k>kavalo
 kun ronda makuli</k> dappled horse; <k>makulo sur lua honoro</k>, <k>sur la
 bona reputo</k> stain, blot upon his hono(u)r, reputation.

<k>mala</k> bad, evil, ill (quality, acts, writing, condition,
weather, news, sense, etc.); <k>male</k> badly, wrongly, amiss,
poorly; <k>malajo</k> <ex>(gen. sense)</ex> bad object, act, event;
hardship, misfortune; mischief; <k>plu mala</k> worse; <k>plumaligar</k>
to make worse; <k>la maxima malajo</k>, <k>lo maxim mala</k> the worst
(thing); <k>malagar</k>, <k>malfacar</k> to act, do wrong, evil,
mischief; <k>malfacema</k> malevolent, mischievous; <k>malauguroza</k>
inauspicious, sinister, unlucky; <k>mala chanco</k> ill-luck,
mischance; <k>malchancoza</k> unlucky, unfortunate; <k>malefikanta</k>
malevolent, malignant; <k>male traktar</k> to maltreat, ill-use,
abuse, bully; <k>malfamoza</k> ill-famed; <k>maledukita</k>
badly brought up, ill-bred, unmannerly; <k>malformacita</k>
malformed, gawky, ill-shaped; <k>maldigesto</k> indigestion; <k>malhumoroza</k>
bad homo(u)red, ill-tempered; <k>malintencanta</k>, <k>maloza</k>
evil-minded, badly-disposed; <k>malodoro</k> bad smell, stink; <k>mala
 morto</k> tragic death, bad end;<k>malpektita</k> unkempt; <k>mala
 pesto!</k> egad! plague on it! <k>malvolanta</k> malevolent,
ill-disposed, spiteful; <k>malvoleganta</k> malignant. Ant.: <k>bona.</k>

<k>malada</k> sick, ill (person); <k>maladeta</k>, <k>maladema</k> poorly,
sickly, somewhat unwell, ailing, indisposed; <k>malad(ul)o</k> a
sick person; <k>maladeso</k> (condition) illness, sickness (cf. <k>morbo</k>);
<k>maladeteso</k> indisposition; <k>igar maladeta</k> to
indispose. V. exp.: vid. <k>morbo</k>. Ant.: <k>sana.</k>

<k>maldicensar</k> <ex>(intr., tr.)</ex> to speak ill (<k>pri ulo</k>),
to disparage, decry (<k>ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>); (cf. <k>denigrar</k>, <k>difamar</k>, <k>kalumniar</k>). Def.: Dicar malajo pri ulu, ulo, pro mala
intenco. V. exp.: La civila lego punisas la <k>difamo</k>, na la <k>maldicenso</k>;
ica resortisas nur a la etikal lego.

<k>malear</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to cold-forge. Def.: Form-izar per
martelo (en kolda stando). V. exp.: <k>Forjar</k> esas la sama
ago, en varma stando. <k>Martelagar</k> esas nejusta o
nesuficanta, nam on povas martel-agar irga kozo, sen malear ol;
la kozo povas rezistar, o ruptesar, o deformesar altramaniere;
V-493.

<k>maledikar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to curse, imprecate, damn (<k>ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>); (cf. <k>blasfemar</k>, <k>imprekar</k>); <k>malediko</k>
malediction, curse.

<k>malgre</k> <ex>(prep.)</ex> in spite of, despite,
notwithstanding, against the will of; <k>malgreke</k><ex> (conj.)</ex>
notwithstanding that (followed by verb; cf. <k>tamen</k>); <k>malgre
 sua volo</k> against one’s will; <k>malgreto</k> in spite of
that, nevertheless; <k>ni iris malgre la pluvo</k> we went
notwithstanding the rain; <k>ni iris malgre ke il interdiktis lo</k>
we went notwithstanding he forbade it; <k>el mariajis su kun il
 malgre sua matro</k> she married him contrary to her
mother’s wish.

<k>malio</k> a mallet or mall used in play; <k>malioludo</k>
mall (a game); <k>malioplaco</k> a place for playing mall.

<k>malico</k> malice, spite; mischievousness; smartness; <k>malicoza</k>, <k>malicema</k> malicious, spiteful, mischievous; <k>malicajo</k>
malicious or mischievous act. N.B. The sense of this word is by
no means always «malice». It is something between evil
intention and keen wit with a tinge of each in it, sometimes
having more of the one, sometimes more of the other.

<k>maligno</k> malicious, pernicious, evil, ill-disposed,
malign, baleful. (N.B. <k>Maligna</k> is used in a somewhat less
strong sense than the E. «malignant»; and properly means:
disposed to take pleasure in the misfortune or suffering of
others; <k>malignega</k>, <k>malvoleganta</k>); <k>maligna muliero</k> a
malicious woman; <k>maligna spirito</k> an evil spirit; <k>maligna tomoro</k>
a malignant tumo(u)r.

<k>mamo</k> breast (of woman); udder (of animal); <k>mamoza</k>
full-breasted; <k>mamala</k> mammary; <k>mamatra</k> mammilary; <k>mampinto</k>
nipple, teat, dug (of animals).

<k>mancho</k> (long) handle, hilt, haft; neck (of musical
instr.); <k>mancho di balayilo</k> broom-stick; <k>guvernilo</k>
rudder, helm.

<k>mandelo</k> almond; <k>mandeliero</k> a. tree (Prunus
Amygdalus); <k>mandellakto</k> milk of a.; <k>mandelatra okuli</k> a.
eyed; <k>mandelsiropo</k> a. syrup, orgeat (cf. <k>orjato</k>).

<k>mandibulo</k> mandible; <ex>(zool.)</ex> either the upper or
lower, part of the beak of a bird; <ex>(anat.)</ex> lower jaw; (cf.
<k>maxilo</k>); <k>mandibulala</k> mandibular.
<k>mandoro</k> <ex>(mus.)</ex> mandore: a kind of stringed lute.

<k>mandrelo</k> <ex>(tech.)</ex> mandril, mandrel. Def.: Utensilo
por kurvigar plaki, dilatar tubi, e.c.; IV-336.

<k>manekino</k> manikin, lay figure, dummy. Def.: Figuro
imitanta la formo di homo o di animalo; ofte artikizita; III-327.

<k>manio</k> mania, monomania: derangement of the mind
especially upon a single subject; <k>manieto</k> hobby, fancy; <k>maniika</k>, <k>manioza; maniiko</k>, <k>maniozo</k> maniac(al); (cf. <k>monomaniiko</k>). Ex.:
Il havas mani(et)o skribar, kompozar. Mani(et)o pri kultivado di
tulipi.

<k>maniero</k> manner, way of doing anything; or acting;
method; mannerism; <ex>(pl.)</ex> behavio(u)r, deportment, (cf. <k>kustumo</k>, <k>modo</k>); <k>omna laboristo laboras segun sua maniero</k> every
workman has his own way of doing a thing; <k>parol</k> (od, <k>maniermodo</k>)
mode, manner of speech; <k>il havas tre agreabla manieri</k> he
has very pleasing manners.

<k>manifestar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to manifest, make to appear,
make known; <k>manifesta</k> manifest, no longer concealed (cf. <k>evidenta</k>, <k>videbla</k>, <k>notora</k>, <k>publika</k>). Ex.: Deo manifestas su per sua
laboruri. Manifesta eroro.

<k>maniko</k> sleeve (of a garment, or any sleeve-like object);
<k>maniko bufanta</k> puffed or bulging s.; <k>sur maniko</k>
over-s., s. guard.

<k>manipular</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to manipulate; to treat, work or
operate with the hand.

<k>manipulatoro</k> sounding-key; apparatus used to send
messages (telegraphic, etc.) by breaks in the current.

<k>manivelo</k> crooked handle, crank; <k>manivele plear ario</k> to
grind out a tune (as on a hand organ); <k>manivelarboro</k>
crank-shaft; <k>maniveldrilo</k> breast-drill.

<k>manjar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to eat: chew and swallow; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
to eat away; consume; <k>manjaretar</k>to nibble, to eat little; <k>manjaro</k>, <k>manjarado</k> a meal, eating; <k>manjarajo</k> something eaten or to be
eaten; food, victuals (cf. <k>nutriva</k>, <k>disho</k>); <k>manjarilaro</k>
eating utensils; <k>manjaregero</k> glutton; <k>manjarotrogo</k>
manger, crib, eating tough; <k>manjareyo</k>, <k>manjarochambro</k> eating
place, dining chamber, refectory; <k>manjarosako</k> nosebag (for
horses).

<k>mankar</k> to be lacking, wanting, missing; (cf. <k>indijar</k>);
<k>manko</k> want, lack, absence, deficiency, shortcoming, need; <k>to
 mankas a me</k> I miss it <ex>(lit.)</ex> that is missing to me; <k>manko
 di respekto</k>, <k>di pekunio</k> lack of respect, of money; <k>mankas
 multa libri (</k>od, <k>multa libri mankas)</k> many books are
missing.

<k>manometro</k> manometer: a pressure or vacuum gauge; steam
gauge.

<k>manovrar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to maneuver (manœuvre)
(troops, ships); <ex>(fig.)</ex> to manage, or bring about, with
skill (an affair, etc.).

<k>mansardo</k> garret; story or room under a sloping roof (cf.
<k>atiko</k>).

<k>mansheto</k> cuff (detachable or not, of shirts, gowns);
(cf. <k>ponyeto</k>, <k>paramento</k>). Def.: Parto (ordinare starchita)
qua finis maniko di kamizo e cirkondas la karpo; VI-245.

<k>mantelo</k> <ex>(garment)</ex> mantle, cloak; <ex>(arch.)</ex>
mantel (as over a fire-place); <k>manteleto</k> short cloak; <ex>(R.C.
ch.)</ex> mantelletta; <k>mantelsako</k> portmanteau; clothes-bag;
(cf. <k>valizo</k>).

<k>mantenar</k> to keep fast, hold fast, sustain (in a state of
stability); <k>mantenar karpenturo per fero</k> to uphold timberwork
with iron; to maintain, preserve: keep in the same state; <k>mantenar
 ordino</k>, <k>familio</k> to maintain order, a family; <k>la manteno di la
 legi</k> the maintaining of the laws. Def.: Tenar en la sama
pozeso o stando; VI-51.
<k>mantiso*</k> the decimal part of a logarithm.

<k>manuo</k>hand; <k>manuala</k> manual; <k>manulaboro</k> hand
(or, manual) labo(u)r; <k>manulibro</k> hand-book, manual:<k>manuskribita</k> hand-written (cf. <k>manuskripto</k>); <k>manuagar</k>
<ex>(tr.)</ex> to handle, wield; <ex>(fig.)</ex> to manage; <k>manuagebla</k>
which can be handled, workable; <ex>(fig.)</ex> manageable; <k>manufabrikar</k>
<ex>(tr.)</ex> to make (<k>ulo</k>) by hand; (cf. <k>fabrikar</k>);
<k>manuedo</k> handful; <k>manuedope</k> by handfuls; <k>manufrapo</k>
blow, cuff, thump; <k>manudorso</k> back of hand; <k>manupreso</k>
hand-pressure; handshake; <k>manuveturo</k> hand-truck, barrow; <k>manuvishilo</k>
hand-towel; <k>manuapogilo</k> hand-rest; <k>manusako</k> hand-bag,
reticule.

<k>manufakturo</k> <ex>(establ.)</ex> manufactory, factory (cf. <k>fabrikerio</k>);
<k>manufakturala</k> relating to factories; <k>manufakturisto</k>, <k>manufakturestro</k>
manufacturer; <k>oza</k> full of factories.

<k>maro</k> sea (cf. <k>oceano</k>); <k>mara</k>, <k>marala</k> of or
relating to the sea, marine, maritime (cf. <k>navala</k>); <k>maristo</k>
seaman, sailor; <k>maro meza (</k>od,<k>plena)</k> main sea, high
sea; <k>marportuo</k> sea-port; <k>marala nauzeo</k> sea-sickness; <k>markolo</k>, <k>stretajo</k> arm of the sea, strait; <k>marfisharo</k>
sea-fish; <k>maroaglo</k> <ex>(orni.)</ex> white-tailed sea-eagle
(Haliaetus albicilla); <k>marhundo</k> <ex>(mam.)</ex> seal (Phoca);
<k>marospumo</k> sea-foam; <ex>(fig.)</ex> meerschaum; <k>marospuma
 pipo</k> meerschaum pipe.

<k>marabuto*</k> Marabout. Def.: Mohamedista kleriko od ermito;
VII-280.

<k>marchar</k> <ex>(intr.) </ex>to walk, step, tread; <ex>(of
soldiers)</ex> to march; <k>march(ad)o</k> walk(ing), march(ing); <k>marchar
 grandapaze</k> to stride; <k>marcho acelerata</k> forced-,
quick-, hurried-march or walk; <k>marchomodo</k>, <k>marchmaniero</k> way of
walking, gait (cf. <k>pazo</k>); <k>marchanto</k>, <k>marchero</k> pedestrian,
walker, marcher; <k>marchario</k> march-music, -tune; <k>marchetar</k>
to trip along (of children). Def.: Facar pazi, pozar alterne la
pedi sur la sulo, irge qua esas la direciono o la skopo di ta ago
(ne rezervata a la militala marcho, o la militala komandi);
IV-464.

<k>marchandar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to bargain for, beat down the
price of, haggle about; <k>marchand(ad)o</k> bargaining; <k>il
 longatempe marchandis ta domo</k> he was a long time bargaining
for that house.
<k>marcipano</k> marzipan, marchpane: a kind of sweetmeat.

<k>mareo</k> tide, ebb and flow (cf. <k>fluxo</k>, <k>refluxo</k>); <k>mareego</k>
bore, eagre: rush of water up an estuary; wave caused by meeting
of two tides.

<k>margrito</k> <ex>(bot.)</ex> marguerite, oxe-eye daisy
(Chrysanthemum leucanthemum); <k>margriteto</k> English daisy (Bellis
perennis).

<k>mariajar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to marry; legally unite in wedlock
(by an official, priest, minister); (cf. <k>spozigar</k>, <k>aliancar</k>);
<k>la komonestro mariajis li</k> the mayor married them; <k>mariajar
 su</k> to get married (<k>kun ulu</k>); <k>mariajo</k>, <k>mariajeso</k>
marriage, matrimony, wedlock; <k>mariajo legala</k> civil marriage; <k>mariajanto</k>, <k>mariajero</k> person officiating at a marriage, match-maker; <k>mariajebla</k>
marriageable; <k>mariajatulo</k> married man, (<k>nova</k>)
bridegroom; <k>mariajfesto</k> wedding, nuptials; <k>mariajfestanti</k>, <k>mariajgasti</k> wedding-party, -guests; <k>mariajanunco</k> banns. V.
exp.: L’ago <k>mariajar</k> implikas 3  personi; la
homulo e la homino mariajata, e la legal (o religial) oficisto,
qua <k>mariajas</k> (unionas) li. Do, segun rigoro, la verbo <k>mariajar</k>
povas havar quale subjekto nur l’oficisto. Per extenso, on
povas dicar ke la homulo e la homino <k>mariajas</k> su, pro ke
lia volo esas ya la kauzo di la mariajo; II-726. La sacerdoto <k>mariajas</k>
Maria e me. La patrulo di Maria grantis Maria e me kom <k>spozino</k>.
Maria <k>spozuligis</k> me. Me <k>spozinigis</k> Maria, od, me <k>mariajis</k>
me kun Maria.

<k>marinar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to marinate: to salt or pickle, as
fish, and then preserve in oil or vinegar; <k>marinajo</k> marinade;
(cf. <k>salizar</k>).

<k>marioneto</k> <ex>(also fig.)</ex> marionette, puppet; <k>filo
 marioneto</k> dancing jack.

<k>marjino</k> margin (of book, of paper); <ex>(fig.)</ex>
border, edge (of anything); <k>notizar en marjino</k> to note or
write in the margin.

<k>«mark»</k> <ex>(money)</ex> mark; <ex>(weight)</ex> mark; an
old weight: 8 oz. (ounces).

<k>marko</k> mark: token by which anything is known; stamp; <k>markizar</k>
to mark; <k>markifar</k> to produce a mark, leave a trace; <k>markosigno</k>
distinctive mark or sign; (cf. <k>indiko</k>, <k>signo</k>, <k>atesto</k>); <k>marko
 sur mutono</k>, <k>sur bokotuko</k> mark on a sheep, on a napkin; <k>doganala
 marko</k> stamp of the Customs.

<k>markotar</k> <ex>(tr., hort.)</ex> to layer: bend a shoot or
branch to the ground and cover with earth so as to take root; <k>markotajo</k>
branch or shoot thus layered.

<k>marmoro</k> marble; <k>marmora</k> of marble (statuo, e.c.); <k>marmorala</k>, <k>marmoratra</k> relating to marble; marble-like, marmoreal; <k>marmorumar</k>
to stain or vein like marble.

<k>marodar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to maraud: rove in quest of
plunder; <ex>(tr.)</ex> to plunder.

<k>marquizo</k> marquee: a large field tent; an ornamental
verander or penthouse overhanging a balcony, window or door.

<k>martelo</k> hammer; <k>martelagar</k> to hammer (cf. <k>malear</k>);
<k>martelag(ad)o</k> hammering; <k>martelagebla</k> malleable; <k>ligno
 martelo</k> mallet, pestle, beetle; (cf. <k>malio</k>); <k>vapor
 martelego</k> steam-, forge-hammer.

<k>Martinsomero</k> St. Martin’s summer: warm, damp season
in England and southern Europe from November to about Christmas.

<k>marvelo</k> wonder, marvel, prodigy. Def.: Ulo qua efikas
astoneso od admiro per aparta beleso, grandeso o stranjeso, mem
per superhomeso o supernatureso; II-19.

<k>maso</k> mass: body of matter cohering in one body, usually
of considerable size; (cf. <k>amaso</k>, <k>bloko</k>, <k>turbo</k>).

<k>masakro</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to massacre. Def.: Mortigar un (od,
plu generale) plura personi kruele o senbezone; III-698.
<k>masho</k> mesh, link (as in knitting, etc.); <k>mashkuraso</k>, <k>mashkuto</k>, <k>mashtuniko</k> coat of mail.

<k>mashino</k> machine, engine; <k>mashini</k>, <k>mashinaro</k> engines,
machinery; <k>mashinisto</k> machinist: one who runs or constructs
m.s; <k>mashinala</k> mechanical; relating to machinery (cf. <k>makanikala</k>);
<k>mashinagar</k> to use or operate a m.; <k>mashinizar</k> to furnish
m.s to; <k>mashinifar</k> to produce, make m.s; <k>exploz mashino</k>
infernal machine; <k>milit mashino</k> engine of war; <k>sut mashino</k>
sewing m.; <k>vapor mashino</k> steam-engine; <k>mashinskribar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex>
to write with a m., to typewrite (<k>ulo</k>); (cf. <k>skrib mashino</k>, <k>mashinisto</k>, <k>mashinero</k> typist).

<k>mashinacar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to machinate: plan or contrive
in secret with evil purpose.

<k>masiva</k> massive, bulky; <k>masivo</k> a large solid mass (as
of masonry); a block (of flowers, trees, etc.); bulk (of a
mountain or hill).

<k>maskar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to mask (to cover the face with a
mask, not <k>travestiar</k>); <k>maskilo</k> a mask; <k>maskita</k>, <k>maskito</k>
masked (person); <k>maskofesto</k>, <k>maskitaro</k> masquerade; <k>maskiteso</k>
<ex>(fig.)</ex> a disguise.

<k>maskarono</k> <ex>(arch.)</ex> carved or moulded face (or
figure). V exp.: To ne esas masko, ma vizajo plu o min groteska,
skultita IV-336.

<k>maskula</k>, <k>maskulala</k>, <k>maskulatra</k> male, masculine; <k>maskulo</k> a male;
<k>maskula genro</k> gender; <k>maskuleso</k> masculinity.

<k>masonar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to do mason’s work on: to
build (with stone, brick, etc.); to wall up, seal up (a door,
etc.); <k>masonisto</k> mason, bricklayer.

<k>masto</k> mast; <k>masteto</k> small m., spar, pole; <k>ye
 mimasto</k> at half-mast; <k>masti</k>, <k>mastaro</k> masts (of a ship,
etc.); <k>mastizar</k> to put m.s on, in (a ship, etc.); <k>mastizilo</k>
sheer legs.

<k>mastico</k> mastic: a resin from the mastic tree; any of the
pasty cements, esp. putty; <k>masticizar</k> to putty.

<k>mastikar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to chew, masticate; <k>mastikajo</k>
something to chew; cud; <k>mastikendo</k> <ex>(med.)</ex> masticatory; <k>mastikachar</k>
to munch.

<k>mastro</k> master:<k />person having authority; <k>mastrino</k>
mistress; <k>mastreso</k> mastery; <k>su mastreso</k> self-mastery,
self-control; <k>sub mastro</k> foreman, overseer.
<k>mato</k> mat, matting (of straw or other materials).

<k>materio</k> <ex>(also fig. as of discourse, book, etc.)</ex>
material, matter (out of which something is made); <k>materiajo</k>
material object, substance; <k>materiala</k> material: relating to
matter; <k>materioza</k> substantial, not formal; <k>materiatra</k>
material (analogous to); <k>materialisto</k>, <k>materiista</k> materialist(ic);
<k>materialismo</k> materialism; <k>materialeso</k> materiality; <k>materio
 prima</k>, <k>kruda</k> raw material; <k>materiigar</k> to materialize: to
make (a spirit) visible in or as a material form; <k>materialigar</k>
to invest with material characteristics, to substantialize.

<k>matida</k> dull, hollow (of sound); mat(t), dead, dull, not
shiny, glossy (of colo(u)rs, etc.). Ant.: <k>sonora</k>, <k>brilanta.</k>

<k>matino</k> morning, forenoon: time from dawn to midday; <k>matinala</k>
m., f.; matutinal; <k>ca matine</k> on (or in) this m., f.; <k>morga
 matino</k> tomorrow m., f.; <k>(esas) frumatine</k> (it was) early
in the m.

<k>matloto*</k> matelot: a kind of fish-stew; a kind of
sailor’s dance, hornpipe.

<k>matro</k> mother; <k>matrala</k> maternal; <k>matreto</k> little
mother; <ex>(fig.)</ex> mamma; <k>matreso</k> maternity:
motherliness; <k>matrala linguo</k> mother-tongue; <k>matraquo</k> <ex>(chem.)</ex>
mother-liquor. V. exp.: <k>Matro</k> esas la sentimental
equivalanto di patrino; VI-535.

<k>matrikulo</k> matricula: register in which names are entered
consecutively, as for a hospital, prison, society, etc.; <k>matrikuleskar</k>, <k>matrikulizar</k> to matricula.

<k>matura</k> <ex>(also fig.)</ex> ripe, mature: having become
completely developed; <k>maturigar</k> to cause to ripen or come to
maturity; <k>matura frukti</k> ripe fruits; <k>matura evo</k> mature
age; <k>matura abceso</k> ripe (suppurating) abcess; <k>matura delibero</k>
mature deliberation.

<k>matutino</k> <ex>(R.C. Ch.)</ex> matins. Def.: «Ofico» di la
matino; V-340.

<k>maxim(e)</k> <ex>(adv. of comparison)</ex> most; <k>maxim(e)a</k>
highest; <k>maxim(e)o</k> maximum; <k>maxim(e)multo</k> the generality,
majority, the most; <k>maxim(e)multe posible</k> the most possible; <k>maxim(e)granda
 posibla</k> the greatest possible; <k>maxim(e)bona</k> the best; <k>maxim(e)a
 sorgo</k> the greatest care; <k>lu laboris maxime</k> he works
most; <k>la maxim granda asno ek la tri</k> the biggest ass of
the three; <k>maxim(e)alta</k> highest; <k>maxim(e)a valoro</k> highest
value; <ex>(fig.)</ex> highest price; <k>maxim(e)ala</k> relating to the
maximum; <k>maxim(e)klara posible</k> as clear as possible, the
clearest possible. Ant.: <k>minim.</k>
<k>mayuskulo</k> capital or uncial letter, majuscule. Ant.: <k>miniskulo.</k>

<k>mazo</k> mace. Def.: Baston(ego) plu grosa ye un extremajo
kam ye l’altra; ica servas kom mancho, e l’enesma havas
nodi, o klovi o saliaji; II-709. La mazo moderna esas uzata quale
ceremoniala insigno, ex.: en parlamento.

<k>me</k> I, me; (acc. <k>me</k>, or in case of necessity <k>men</k>);
<k>mea</k>, <k>mei</k> <ex>(sing. and pl.)</ex> my, mine; <k>la meajo e la
 tuajo</k> mine and thine. Ex.: Me amas mea frati. Vua servisti
ne frequentas mei, e mei ne frequentas vui.

<k>meceno</k> Maecenas; <ex>(fig.)</ex> patron of art and
science.

<k>mecho</k> wick (of lamp, of candle); tinder; <ex>(artil.)</ex>
quick-match; <k>mechofusilo</k> match-lock.

<k>medio</k> <ex>(also nat. sciences)</ex> environment,
surroundings; <ex>(of people)</ex> circle, set; (cf. <k>cirkumaji</k>);
<k>en la intelektala</k>, <k>etikala e sociala medio</k> in the
intellectual, moral and social environment; <k>media</k> ambient,
surrounding.

<k>mediacar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to mediate: to intervene,
interpose between people or in something to harmonize or
reconcile; <k>mediaco</k> mediation, intervention; <k>mediacanto</k>, <k>mediacero</k>
mediator; intermediate; agent; middleman, go-between; <k>mediacanta</k>
intermediate; (cf. <k>mediata</k>).

<k>mediana*</k>, <k>mediano</k> <ex>(geom., and fig. in zool., anat., bot.)</ex>
median (middle), mesial. Def.: Rekto qua juntas somito di
triangulo a la mezo dil latero opozita; VII-280.

<k>mediata</k> mediate: intermediate, not direct or immediate,
indirect; <k>mediatigar</k> to mediatize: to make intermediate,
render mediate; <k>mediate</k> intermediately, indirect; <k>ne mediata</k>
immediate: without intervention of another object, cause or
agency; (cf. <k>quik</k>); <k>mediatajo</k> something intermediate,
intermediary (object; cf. <k>mediacanto</k>).

<k>medicino</k> <ex>(art, profession)</ex> medicine; (cf. <k>medikamento</k>);
<k>medicinala</k> medical; <k>medicinisto</k>, <k>medicinulo</k>, <k>medicinino</k> one who occupies
himself with medicine, even theoretically (cf. <k>mediko</k>); <k>medicindoktoro</k>
doctor of m., <k>medicinstudent(ul)o</k> student of m.

<k>mediko</k>, <k>medikulo</k>, <k>medikino</k> physician, doctor; <k>medikala</k>
medical; <k>medikacho</k> quack. V. exp.: Per <k>mediko</k> on devas
komprenar <k>medicinisto</k> <k>praktikanta</k>, kontre ke <k>medicinisto</k>
(segun l’etimologio) esas irgu qua okupas su profesione pri
medicino (mem nur teoriale). Profesoro di medicino, exemple, esas
medicinisto, ma povas ne esar mediko. <k>Kuracisto</k> signifikas
ta qua (profesione) kuracas, sive mediko, sive ne; VI-141.

<k>medikamento</k> medicine, medicament; <k>medikamenta</k>, <k>medikamentala</k>, <k>medikamentatra</k>
medicinal; <k>medikamentizar</k> to apply, give medicine to (<k>ulu</k>).

<k>meditar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to meditate, think over,
ponder (cf. <k>projetar</k>); Ex.: Meditar (pri) ula verajo, la
paroli di evangelio-libri. Il pasas sua tempo en meditado. Meno
meditema.

<k>mefito</k> mephitis: noxious or foul exhalation, especially
from earth; <ex>(mines)</ex> choke-damp.

<k>megalita</k> megalithic: consisting of large stone; <k>megalito</k>
megalith (monument).

<k>mejisar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to taw (skins). Def.: Specala
maniero preparar la peli, precipue la mikra peli: mikra bovyuno,
mutono, mutonyuno, kapro-yuno, por fabrikar ganti, delikata shui,
e.c. La mejisado esas specala karakterizata per to ke la tanago
di la peli, vice facesar per tanoza extrakturi, quale la tanago
propre dicita, esas facata per specala mixuro blankatra kompozita
de aluno, vitelo e marala salo; VI-245.

<k>mekaniko</k> (science of) mechanics; <k>mekanikala</k>
mechanical; relative to mechanics or the laws of motion (cf. <k>mashinala</k>);
<k>mekanikisto</k> mechanician: one learned in the theories of
mechanics (cf. <k>mashin(if)isto</k>). Ex.: omna movi di korpi
esas mekanikal, la libera falo di korpo, same kam la falo di
vapor-martelo.

<k>mekanismo</k> <ex>(philos., mechan, and fig.)</ex> mechanism,
machinery; structure; mechanical parts. Def.: Ensemblo di la
mekanikal relati, kun egardo a la dispozeso di la parti; VII-205.
Ex.: La mekanismo do horlojo od altra mashino. La mekanismo esas
ulo abstraktita, la strukturo, la dispozeso di la parti di la
aparato.

<k>melankolio</k> (of persons) melancholy; <ex>(med.)</ex>
melancholia; <k>melankolioza</k> melancholy, dispirited, gloomy (of
mind); (cf. <k>trista</k>). Ant.: <k>gayeso.</k>
<k>meleo*</k> melee; a general had to hand fight.

<k>melono</k> melon, muskmelon (Cucumis Melo); <k>aquo melono</k>
watermelon (Cucumis Citrulis); <k>kantalupo melono</k> cantaloup.

<k>mem</k> <ex>(adv.)</ex> even, still, (in comparson); <ex>(emphasis)</ex>
really, indeed (cf. <k>ya</k>); <k>mem se</k> even if; <k>mem
 plu bona</k> still better, better yet; <k>yes</k>, <k>me konfesas</k>, <k>ke
 mea manui esas mem tre sordida</k> yes, I admit that my hands a
really very dirty; <k>ica pano esas bona</k>, <k>ma ita esas mem plu
 bona</k> that bread is good but that is even better; <k>il
 meritas estimo</k>, <k>mem amo</k> he merits esteem, even love.

<k>membro</k> member (of society, community, party, parliament,
of an equation); limb (of body); <k>membro (di frazo)</k> clause
(cf. <k>klauzo</k>); <k>membri</k>, <k>membraro</k> members, limbs; <k>membroza</k>
limbered, membered.

<k>«memento»</k> <ex>(R.C. ch.)</ex> memento: prayers for living
and dead.

<k>memorar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to remember, recollect, have a
memory of; (cf. <k>merkar</k>); <k>memorigar</k> to cause (<k>ulu</k>)
to remember, remind, bring to mind, commemorate; <k>memor(ad)o</k> <ex>(act,
faculty)</ex> memory, remembrance; <k>memorajo</k> what is rembered,
recollection; <k>memorigilo</k> reminder, souvenir, keepsake; <k>memore</k>
by heart; <k>memorinda</k> memorable; <k>memorigo</k> commemoration,
remembrance; <k>memorigiva</k>, <k>memorala</k> commemorative; <k>memornoto</k>
note of reminder, memorandum; <k>memorlibro</k> memo. book; <k>ri
 memoro</k> reminiscence, recollection.

<k>memorando</k> memorandum; (of societies, academies); <ex>(dipl.)</ex>
memorial: a note or informal state paper used in diplomacy.

<k>memorialo</k> memoir. Def.: Historiala verko, en qua
l’autoro naracas l’eventi di sua vivo o di sua tempo;
IV-172.

<k>menajo</k> housekeeping: administration, cleaning and
general management of a house, especially apart from mere cooking
arrangements; <k>menajisto</k>, <k>menajulo</k>, <k>menajino</k>, <k>menajestro</k> housekeeper.
Def.: Domal (hemala) ekonomio o servado; IV-66.

<k>menajerio</k> menagerie. Def.: Kolekturo de animali rara o
sovaja por expozo; III-327.
<k>mencionar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to mention, make mention of; <k>honoroza</k>, <k>mencionizanta menciono</k> honorable mention. V. exp.: vid. <k>citar</k>.

<k>menso*</k> <ex>(of abbeys)</ex> revenue; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
table-money, allowance for table.

<k>menstruar</k> <ex>(intr., physiol.)</ex> to menstruate, have
the monthly flow; <k>menstruo</k> menses.

<k>mento</k>mind: seat of consciousness, thought, volition and
feeling; mentality: cast or habit of mind (cf. <k>spirito</k>, <k>psiko</k>, <k>intelekto</k>); <k>mentala</k> mental; <k>mento militistala</k> a
military mind: an intelligence which looks at all matters from a
soldier’s viewpoint; <k>mento partisala</k> a partisan mind
or spirit; <k>mento publika</k> public spirit or mind; <k>mentomediko</k>
physician of the mind, alienist. ?EFIS
<k>mentiar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to lie, tell a falsehood (<k>pri</k>, <k>per</k>); <k>mentietar</k> to fib.

<k>mentono</k> chin; <k>mentono salianta</k> prominent c.; <k>mentono
 dupada</k> double c.; <k>mentonbarbo</k> c. beard; (cf. <k>infra
 labiobarbo</k>); <k>mentonbandajo</k> c. bandage; <k>mentonkateno</k> <ex>(horses)</ex>
curb-chain; <k>mentonumo</k> c.piece, c.-band, -strap. Def.: <k>(mentonumo)</k>
Bendo ek stofo, ledro o metalo por renar kapvesto sur la kapo;
anke kuseneto od utensilo por violino fixa dum ke on pleas;
III-10.

<k>menuzar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to do fine carpenter’s or
joiner’s work; <k>menuzisto</k> cabinet-worker, joiner (cf. <k>ebenisto</k>).
V.  exp.: vid. <k>karpentar</k>.

<k>mercero</k> <ex>(Eng.)</ex> mercer’s business,
haberdasher’s trade. (<ex>U.S.</ex>) dry-goods business; <k>merceristo</k>
mercer, haberdasher: a dealer in textile fabrics, trimmings, and
small articles of dress.

<k>meringo</k> <ex>(cook.)</ex> meringue: a kind of icing and
cake made of it.

<k>meritar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to deserve, merit (<k>ulo de ulu</k>);
<k>merito</k> merit, worth, desert. Ex.: Meritar laudo, puniso,
rekompenso.

<k>merizo</k> wild cherry; <k>meriziero</k> wild cherry tree
(Prunus avium).

<k>merkar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to mark, to impress (<k>ulo</k>) on
one’s memory, to retain or remember) a thing, keep in mind,
(cf. <k>memorar</k>); <k>vorti facile merkebla</k> words easy
to keep in mind; <k>merkez mea vorti</k> mark my words; <k>me
 merkos to</k> I will bear that in mind; <k>merkovorto</k>
catch-word, cue-word, key-word. V. exp.: <k>Merkar</k> expresas
ideo simila a <k>lernar</k>, tamen min konsideranta la peno e
l’intenco; III-495.

<k>merkato</k> <ex>(aslo fig. as in polit. econ.)</ex> market:
public place for selling. Def.: Vendeyo publika; III-466. Stando
di la ofro e demando di vari en un urbo o loko; II-76.

<k>merlono*</k> <ex>(fort.)</ex> merlon. Def.: Parto (solida) di
muro inter du kreneli; VII-280.

<k>meso</k> <ex>(R.C. Ch.)</ex> mass; <k>meslibro</k> missal,
prayer-book; <k>meso senkanta</k> low mass

<k>meskina</k> mean, paltry (person, act); narrow, illiberal
(ideas, policy); stingy, niggardly (persons, policy); shabby
(room, person); <k>meskinajo</k> mean or paltry thing or act, shabby
trick. Def.: Qua indijas larjeso, alteso (precipue etikala);
III-10.

<k>mestica</k>, <k>mestico</k> <ex>(of persons, animals)</ex> half-breed,
mixed-breed; mestizo: a peson of mixed Spanish and American
Indian blood; (cf. <k>mulato</k>, <k>hibrido</k>); (cf. V-33).

<k>mestiero</k> trade, handicraft: occupation or business in
which manual or mechanical labo(u)r is necessary, as that of a
carpenter or mason; <k>mestierala</k> technical, craft; <k>mestieristo</k>
artisan, mechanic; <k>il esas mestiere tornisto</k> he is
a turner (or lathe-worker) by trade.

<k>metar</k> to put on , don (clothing, ornaments); (cf. <k>vestizar</k>);
<k>metar frako</k> to put on a dress-coat; <k>meto</k> donning,
dressing; <k>metebla</k> wearable: which can be put on.

<k>metafrazo</k> metaphrase: literal translation. Def.: Expliko
qua konsistas en tradukar loko (frazo) en plura klara, simpla e
vulgara vorti; V-485.

<k>metalo</k> metal; <k>metala</k>, <k>metalala</k>, <k>metaloza</k> metallic: of m.,
relaing to m., full of m.; <k>metalajo</k> m. object; <k>metalizar</k>
to metallize; to coat or impregnate with m.; <k>metalifo</k>
metallurgy; ore production (cf. <k>metalurgio</k>); <k>metalifisto</k>
metallurgist; <k>metalfilo</k> wire; <k>metallaboristo</k> m.worker; <k>metalvazaro</k>, <k>metalajaro</k> ironmongery, hardware.

<k>metalurgio*</k> metallurgy: science and art of preparing
metals from the ores (not the extracting of ores; cf. <k>metalifo</k>).

<k>metodo</k> method: special or definite system of procedure; <ex>(of
things)</ex> <k>–ala</k> methodical; <ex>(of persons)</ex> <k>–oza</k>
methodical; <k>metodale</k>, <k>metodoze</k> methodically. Ex.: Il facas omno
segun metodo (od, metodoze). Metodala aranjo.

<k>metodismo</k> <ex>(rel.)</ex> methodism: doctrine of
methodists; <k>metodisto</k> methodist (member of a religious sect).

<k>metonomazio</k> metonomatosis. Def.: Chanjo di propra nomo
per traduko, qua celas ol; V-485.

<k>metro</k> <ex>(metric)</ex> meter (metre): 1.093 yards; <ex>(poet.)</ex>
meter; <k>metroquadrato</k> square meter: 1.196 square yards; <k>metro
 kubo</k> cubic meter: 35 cubic feet; <k>metrala</k> <ex>(measure or
verse)</ex> metrical. Note: A list of metric abbreviations may be
found in IV-608-9.
<k>metropolo</k> metropolis: a chief or capital city.
