<k>meza</k>, <k>mezo</k> middle, midst; <k>meze di</k> in the middle of; <k>meza</k>, <k>mezala</k> middle, medial, median; <k>mezgrada</k>, <k>mezvalora</k> <ex>(of
quantities)</ex> average; <ex>(math.)</ex> mean; <ex>(gen.)</ex>
middling, mediocre, tolerable (cf. <k>pasabla</k>); <k>mezgrado</k>, <k>mezvaloro</k> average, mean, mediocrity; <k>mezvalore</k>
moderately, indifferently; <k>mezepoko</k> the Middle Ages; <k>mezepokala</k>
medieval; <k>mezeva</k> of middle age; <k>meza stando</k> (od, <k>situeso</k>)<k />
moderate circumstances; <k>meza fosto (di fenestro)</k> mullion; <k>mezosoprano</k>
mezzo-soprano; <k>meza proporcionalo</k> <ex>(geom.)</ex> mean
proportional.

<k>mezurar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to measure (with an instrument), to
survey (land); <k>mezur(ad)o</k> measure, measurement, measuring; <ex>(mus.)</ex>
time, measure; bar; <k>mezurilo</k> an instrument for measuring; <k>mezurebla</k>
measurable; <k>sen mezura</k> immeasurable, immoderate; excessive,
exorbitant; <k>super mezuro</k> over-measure; <k>agro mezuristo</k>
land (or, field) surveyor. V. exp.: vid. <k>evaluar.</k>
<k>mi</k> mi, third note of diatonic scale.

<k>miaular*</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to mew: to cry as a cat, to
caterwaul, miaou.

<k>mielo</k> honey; <ex>(fig.)</ex> sweetness; <k>mielala</k>, <k>mieloza</k>, <k>mielatra</k> honeyed, melliferous; <k>mielifar</k> to produce honey; <k>mielaquo</k>
hydromel, mead; <k>mielkuko</k> gingerbread; <k>mielmixuro</k>
oxymel: a mixture of vinegar and honey; <k>mieltempo</k> honeymoon.

<k>mieno</k> (of the face) look(s), mien, countenance, <k>mienacho</k>
affected, lackadaisical, simpering look; <k>mieno superba</k>
haughty look; <k>facar mieni</k>, <k>mienachi</k> to put on airs, mince,
simper, smirk; <k>ne judikez homo segun lua mieno</k> do not
judge a person by his looks.

<k>mifarmajo</k> metairie: land (or implements) leased for
half-share of produce; <k>miado</k> metayage; <k>miisto</k>, <k>miero</k>
metayer.

<k>migrar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to migrate; <k>migranta</k>, <k>migrema</k>
migrating; <ex>(fig.)</ex> itinerant; <k>migranta uceli</k> migrating
birds.

<k>migreno</k> megrim: a kind of sick or nervous pain affecting
one side of the head, hemicrania. ?DeFIR

<k>migrenino*</k> <ex>(med.)</ex> a kind of remedy for megrim or
hemicrania.

<k>mikra</k> little, small; (cf. <k>poka</k>); <k>mikreta</k>, <k>mikracha</k>
tiny, wee; <k>mikrope</k> little by little, bit by bit; <k>mikrigar</k>
to make small, belittle; (cf. <k>mingrandigar</k>, <k>diminutar</k>), <k>mikrokosmo</k>
microcosm. Ex.: Mikra spaco, chambro, homo, sumo, nombro, merito.
Ant.: <k>granda.</k>

<k>mil</k> thousand; <k>milo</k> a (one) thousand; <k>milesma</k>
(ordinal) 1000th ; <k>milimo</k> (fraction) 1/1000
(part); <k>milyara</k> millenary; (cf. <k>cent</k>, <k>du</k> for
derivatives).

<k>militar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to (make) war; <ex>(fig.)</ex> to
militate; (<k>por</k>, <k>kontre</k>); <k>militigar</k> to cause to make
war; <k>militanto</k>, <k>militisto</k> fighter, combatant, warrior; <k>militala</k>
military: relating to war; <k>militistala</k> military: relating to
warriors; <k>militema</k> combative, pugnacious, bellicose; <k>militarto</k>
art of war; <k>militruzo</k> stratagem (of war); <k>militistaro</k>
armed force of a country (cf. <k>armeo</k>); <k>militjudicio</k>
court-martial; <k>militala kaptito</k> prisoner of war; <k>militnavo</k>
warship; <k>militnava</k> naval.

<k>militarismo</k> militarism; <k>militaristo</k> militarist: a
believer in militarism; <k>militarigar</k> to militarize: to bring
into a condition of (or imbue with) militarism. Ex.: On dicas, ke
la maxim bona metodo kuracar militaristo esas igar lu militisto.

<k>mimar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to mimic: express by dumb show, as
for ridicule; <k>mimanto</k>, <k>mimisto</k> mimic, mime.

<k>mimetika*</k> <ex>(zool.)</ex> a mimicking (animal); <k>mimetikeso</k>
mimicry; imitative resemblance of one animal to another or to
some inanimate object.

<k>min(e)</k> <ex>(adv.)</ex> less (Note: The short form: <k>min</k>
is used when followed by adjective or verb; as, <k>min granda</k>
smaller; the longer form: <k>mine</k> is used when not followed
by word which it modifies, as at the end of a sentence; <k>il
 laboris mine</k> he worked less; <k>min bela</k> less
beautiful; <k>parolez min multe</k> speak less; <k>min multo</k>
the lesser; <k>min kam ultempe</k> less than ever; <k>min multa
 pekunio</k> less money; <k>sempre min</k> less and less. V.
exp.: <k>Min</k> esas diminutala; <k>minus</k> esas
sustracionala. Ex.: Esante min durstanta kam me, il drinkis un
glaso minuse; II-738. Ant.: <k>plu.</k> Note: In distinction from
E. usage where «less» is used adjectivally, <k>min</k> is
always an adverb, therefore : <k>min multa homi</k>, <k />not<k>min
 homi.</k>

<k>minar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to undermine, to mine: extract ores,
etc.; (cf. <k>subdestruktar</k>) <ex>(milit.)</ex> to sap; <k>mineyo</k>
a mine; <k>mineyala</k> pertaining to mines: <k>la rivero minis
 la rivo</k> the river undermined the bank.

<k>minacar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to menace, to threaten (<k>ulu</k>, <k>per
 ulo</k>). Ex.: Il minacis mortigar me. La muro minacis krular (E.
the wall totters). Kolero esas minaco.

<k>mineralo</k> mineral; <k>mineraligar</k> to mineralize: transform
into a mineral; <k>mineralizar</k> to mineralize: to cover or
impregnate with mineral.
<k>minestrelo</k> minstrel: poet, singer of the Middle Ages.

<k>miniaturo</k> miniature; a small and delicate painting, as a
portrait; a representation on a much reduced scale.

<k>minim(e)</k>, <k>minim(e)a</k> (superlative of <k>min</k>) least, lowest,
minimum; <k>minim(e)o</k> minimum; <k>minim(e)a nombro (necesa por valideso di
 voti)</k> quorum; <k>min bona</k>, <k>min kurajoza</k> least good,
least courageous; <k>min multa bruiso posibla</k> least possible
noise: <k>minim chera</k> least dear, the cheapest; <k>la minim
 alta monto</k> the lowest mountain; <k>skribar pri kozi quin on
 komprenas minime</k> to write things about which one understands
least; (cf. note on form in <k>min(e).</k>

<k>miniona</k> small and dainty, daintily pretty; <k>minionino</k>
a daintily pretty girl or woman; <ex>(fig.)</ex> darling, pet; <k>miniona
 boko</k> a pretty (and small) mouth; <k>miniona pedo</k> a dainty
foot.

<k>ministerio</k> administrative or executive department of a
government of which a <k>ministro</k> is the head (cf. V-158); <k>la
 ministraro demisionis</k>, <k>ma la ministerii ankore funcionis</k> the
ministers have resigned but the «ministries» (administrative
departments) still carried on their work.

<k>ministro</k> <ex>(state functionary)</ex> minister; <k>ministraro</k>
cabinet, ministry (collective); <k>ministrala</k> ministerial; <k>ministreyo</k>
government office; <k>dum la ministreso di Sro. X</k> during
the ministry of Mr. X; <k>chef ministro</k> premier, prime minister.
<k>miniumo</k> minium: red oxide of lead; (paint) red-lead.

<k>minora</k> <ex>(jur.)</ex> minor: under age; <ex>(logic, music,
eccl.)</ex> minor; <k>minoreso</k> <ex>(of age)</ex> minority; <k>minora
 modo</k> minor key. Ant.: <k>majora.</k>

<k>minto</k> <ex>(bot.)</ex> mint (genus: Mentha); <k>minto krispa</k>
curly mint (Mentha crispa); <k>piprominto</k> peppermint
(Mentha piperita).

<k>minucio</k> minutia, trifle, minor detail: <k>minucii</k>
minutiae; <k>minuciema</k> (person) particular; attentive to detail,
fastidious, hairsplitter; <k>minuciemacho</k> fuss-budget, busybody.

<k>minus</k> <ex>(arith., alg.)</ex> minus; <k>di plus tri minus
 un facas (od</k>, <k>esas) quar</k> two plus three minus one makes
four; <k>il pagis a me un dollar minuse</k> he paid me one
dollar less (i.e. he took one dollar from the price); <k>un glaso
 minuse</k> one glass less. V. exp.: vid. <k>min.</k>

<k>minuto</k> <ex>(of time: astron., geom. of degree)</ex>
minute.

<k>minvalorigar</k> to depreciate: to lessen the value of; to
undervalue, underrate; disparage; <k>la abundo de pekunio
 minvalorigas la valoro</k> the abundance of money depreciates
its value; <k>komercaji minvaloreskas</k> goods are beginning to
depreciate; <k>minvalorigar persono</k> to depreciate a person.

<k>miraklo</k> miracle; <k>mirakla</k> miraculous: truly
supernatural; <k>miraklala</k> miraculous: relating to miracles; <k>miraklatra</k>
miraculous: mervelous,wonderful; <k>miraklifanta</k> wonder-working,
working miracles.

<k>miriado</k> myriad: an immense number; <ex>(antiq.)</ex> ten
thousand.

<k>mirtelo</k> <ex>(fruit)</ex> bilberry; <k>mirteliero</k> bilberry
plant: European whortleberry plant (Vacinium Myrtillus).

<k>misaliancar (su)</k> to contract a misalliance; to marry
beneath one; <k>o</k> misalliance, a bad match.

<k>miseventar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to come to any harm, to
happen unluckily, to turn out ill; <k>miso</k> mischance, mishap,
misadventure.

<k>misirar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to go astray, lose one’s
way.

<k>miskonocar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to misunderstand (something
perceptible to the senses), to mistake; (cf. <k>konocar</k>).
<k>misnomar</k>, <k>misizar</k> to misname, give a wrong name to (cf. <k>nomar</k>).

<k>mispazo</k> <ex>(lit. and fig.)</ex> false step, mis-step;
blunder, slip; <ex>faux pas; </ex><k>mispazar</k> to make, take a
false step, stumble (cf. <k>pedbutar</k>).

<k>mispozar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to put in the wrong place. V.
exp.: vid. <k>egarar.</k>

<k>misprezentar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to present wrongly,
misrepresent. Ex.: Il misprezentis (od, mis-deskriptis) la stando
di la afero, la fakti di la kazo.

<k>missendar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to missend (ulo); to misdirect
(a letter, etc.).

<k>misterio</k> <ex>(also antiq., eccl.)</ex> mystery; <k>misteriala</k>
relating to mysteries; <k>misterioza</k>, <k>misteriatra</k> mysterious.

<k>mistifikar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to hoax, mystify: mischievously
deceive someone in sport; <k>mistifiko</k> hoax, mystify (for sport);
(cf. <k>perplexigar</k>, <k>konfuzigar</k>).
<k>misuzar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to misuse, make bad use of, waste.

<k>mitamburo</k> tambourine. V. exp.: Pro ke tamburo (ed anke
tamburino) havas du feli, esas naturala indikar per «mitamburo»
la instrumento, qua havas un felo; IV-511.

<k>miteno</k> mitten; <k>mi miteno</k> a mitten which leaves the
fingers bare. Def.: Ganto en qua nur la grosa fingro esas
separita e la qua ceteri unionita; III-327
<k>mitralio</k> grape-shot, canister, shrapnel; <k>mitraliagar</k>, <k>mitraliopafar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to fire grapeshot, shrapnel at or on.

<k>mixar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to mix, mingle, blend (<k>ulo kun ulo</k>);
<k>inter mixar</k> to intermix (<k>uli</k>); <k>mixar su</k> to
intervene in, meddle; <k>mixar karti</k> shuffle cards; <k>mixo</k>, <k>mixuro</k> mixture, blend, medly; <k>mixajo</k> miscellanea,
miscellany; <k>mixolinea</k> <ex>(geom.)</ex> mixtilineal; <k>mixacheso</k>
promiscuousness. Ex.: Mixar l’aquo kun la vino. Mixar (E.
blend) kolori. Mixar diversa flori en buketo.Mixar su en
l’aferi di altru. Me mixas klor-acido kun nitrat-acido (e me
intermixas la du acido).

<k>mizerar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to be in misery (because of
poverty, destitution, or unhappiness or pain); <k>mizero</k> misery,
wretchedness, want, sore need, distress.

<k>mizerikordio</k> mercy, mercifulness; <k>mizerikordioza</k>, <k>mizerikordiema</k>
merciful, compassionate, clement; <k>sen mizerikordia</k> unmerciful.
Def.: Kompato (di Deo) qua pardonas a pekanto; III-327. Ex. Deala
mizerikordio. Klamar mizerikordio ad ulu. Ta homo esas
senmizerikordia.

<k>mnemoniko</k> mnemonics: art or system for developing the
memory.

<k>moblo</k> a piece of furniture: any movable object
serviceable or use or decoration of an apartment; <k>moblaro</k> <ex>(set,
collection)</ex> furniture; <k>moblizar</k> to furnish (a house,
room, etc. with furniture); <k>moblizitadomo</k>, <k>chambro</k>, <k>lojeyo</k>
furnished house, room, lodging; <k>moblifar</k> to make furniture.

<k>modo</k>mode: a passing usage which depends upon taste,
caprice; fashion, style; <ex>(gram.)</ex> mood (indicative,
imperative, etc.); <ex>(philos., mus.)</ex> mode; <ex>(jur.)</ex>
modus; <k>modala</k> <ex>(log.)</ex> modal; <k>modaleso</k> <ex>(log.)
</ex>modality; <k>segun la modo</k>, <k>segun moda</k> according to the
mode, in the fashion, fashionable; <k>vestizar ulu segun la modo;</k>to dress someone in the fashion: <k>modo anciena</k> old
fashion.

<k>modelo</k> model (of a machine, etc.): copy or standard to
be followed; <k>modelatra</k> standard, exemplary; <k>Solomon
 konstruktis la templo segun la modelo di la tabernaklo</k>
Solomon built the temple according to the model of the
tabernacle; <k>el posturas kom modelo por skultisto</k> she acts
as a model for a sculptor; <k>modelo skribita</k> a written copy; <k>ilua
 vivo esas modelo di vertuo</k> his life is a pattern of virtue;
(cf. <k>shablono</k>, <k>imitajo</k>, <k>moduro</k>, <k>modelajo</k>).

<k>moderar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to moderate: keep within bonds
(passions, zeal, ardour, etc.); to abate (a price), reduce
(one’s expenses); mitigate (a sentence); <k>moderema</k>
temperate; <k>moderilo</k> governor, regulator (of speed); <k>modere</k>
moderately; <k>senmodereso</k> immoderation. Ant.: <k>acelerar</k>, <k>augmentar.</k>

<k>modesta</k> modest: not bold or presumptuous; not boastful
or obtrusive; (N.B. «modest» in the sense of observing sex
proprieties is translated by <k>pudoroza</k>, <k>chasta</k>, <k>decanta</k>).
V. exp.: vid. <k>diskreta.</k> Ant.: <k>Superba</k>, <k>pretendema</k>, <k>arogema</k>, <k>vanitatoza</k>, <k>fatua.</k>

<k>modifikar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to modify: make partial changes
in (cf. <k>chanjar</k>); <k>modifikivo</k> <ex>(gram.)</ex> a modifying
or qualifying word. Ex.: Modifikar lego, frazo, puniso.

<k>modlar</k> <ex>(tr., sculpt.)</ex> to make a model (in clay,
wax) of something from which a statue or other work is to be
executed or enlarged.

<k>modulacar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to modulate: pass from one key to
another without break in melody; to inflect, vary ( the voice in
speaking).

<k>mokar</k> to laugh at: ridicule, deride, mock, rally, gibe,
scoff; <k>moketar</k> to banter, chaff; <k>mok(ad)o</k> mockery,
derision, jeer; <k>mokoklamo</k> hue and cry.

<k>mola</k> soft: easily yielding to pressure, not hard; (cf. <k>dolca</k>);
(of muscles) flabby (cf. <k>laxa</k>); <ex>(of meat)</ex> tender; <ex>(of
fruits)</ex> mellow; <k>molacha</k> flimsy, flabby; <k>moligar</k>
to soften; <ex>(fig.)</ex> to mollify; <k>moligiva</k> emollient; <k>ovi
 mole koquita</k> soft-cooked eggs. Ant.: <k>harda.</k>

<k>molestar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to molest, pester, annoy, bother.
V. exp.: <k>Molestar</k> signifikas volata tedado per tormenteti
o persekuteti. La vorto bone tradukas la F. <ex>brimer</ex> (E. to
play jokes on), qua esas molestado impozita kom probo a la novici
en armeo, lerneyo. Anke on povas dicar: «la dogano esas
konstanta molestado por la voyajanti»; III-35.

<k>molio</k> mole, jetty (used as a harbor (harbour)
breakwater).

<k>moloso</k> a species of watch-dog (Canis familiaris
molossus); <ex>(pros.)</ex> Molosian metre.

<k>monak(ul)o</k> monk, friar; <k>monakala</k>, <k>monakatra</k> monastic,
monachal, monkish; <k>monakino</k> nun; <k>monakeso</k> (condition,
state) monasticism, monkhood; <k>monakismo</k> (system, doctrine)
monasticism; <k>monakeyo</k> monastery, convent.

<k>monato</k> month; <k>monatsalario</k> month;s pay; <k>omnamonate</k>, <k>monata</k> every month, monthly; <k>camonate</k> (during, in) this
month; <k>po monato</k>, <k>singla monate</k> by the month, so much a
month; <k>mi monata</k> half-monthly, twice a month.

<k>mondo</k> (general sense) the world (cf. <k>tero</k>); <k>mondumo</k>
the world: society, people; <k>mondumo eleganta</k>, <k>alta</k> world of
fashion, smart set, high-life; <k>mondala</k>mundane; <k>mondumema</k>
worldly-minded; <k>mondumala</k> relating to society; relating to
good manners; <k>mondumajo</k> a worldly thing, vanity; <k>mondumanulo</k>
man of the world; <k>umaneso</k> worldliness.

<k>moneto</k> <ex>(of gold, silver, copper)</ex> coin, cash,
change, specie; <ex>(fig.)</ex> currency; (cf. <k>pekunio</k>); <k>monetopeco</k>
a coin; <k>monetpapero</k> paper money: which takes the place of
coin (cf. <k>bankobilieto</k>); <k>monetala</k> monetary; <k>monetigar</k>
to monetize: put into circulation, give a standard value to in
currency; <k>monetifar</k> to coin, mint into money; to raise money;
<k>monetifisto</k> coiner; <k>monetifeyo</k>, <k>moneterio</k> mint; <k>monetuyo</k>
a purse.

<k>monoftongo*</k> <ex>(gram.)</ex> monophthong: a single vowel
sound; a combination of two vowels pronounced as one.

<k>monoklo</k> monocle, single eye-glass. Def.: Unika aparta
okulvitro; V-1.

<k>monokroma</k> monochrome; <k>monokromajo</k> <ex>(paint)</ex>
monochrome picture; camaieu. Def.: (monokrom-ajo) Pikturo per un
sola koloro, plu o min klara; VI-480.

<k>monomanio</k> <ex>(med.)</ex> monomania: insanity upon
one particular subject (cf. <k>manio</k>); <k>monomaniika</k>, <k>monomaniiko</k>
monomaniac(al).

<k>monstro</k> <ex>(pr. and fig.)</ex> monster; <k>monstra</k>, <k>monstrala</k>, <k>monstratra</k> monstrous, enormous; <k>monstrajo</k> <ex>(object or act)</ex>
monstrosity.

<k>monto</k> mount, mountain; <k>monteto</k> hill, hillock,
knoll; <k>montaro</k>, <k>montokateno</k> mountain range; <k>montoza</k>
mountainous; <k>montetoza</k> hilly; <k>monto Etna</k> Mt. Etna; <k>Venusmonto</k>
<ex>(anat.)</ex> mons veneris; <k>montopinto</k> mountain peak (the
point); (cf. <k>admonte</k>).

<k>montanto</k> upright: piece of any framework, wood or iron;
stanchion, beam, post, side-piece (of a ladder).

<k>montrar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to show, exhibit: make to see or
know; <k>montrinda</k> worthy of showing, presentable; <k>montristo</k>
showman; <k>montrar rara libro</k> to show a rare book; <k>montrez a me
 ta homulo</k> show me that man; <k>montrar kurajo</k> to show
courage; (cf. <k>manifestar</k>, <k>expozar</k>, <k>indikar</k>, <k>prizentar</k>, <k>aparar</k>).

<k>moqueto</k> moquette: a kind of velvet carpeting; Wilton
carpeting.

<k>mori</k> manners, habits, conduct considered from the moral
point of view; (cf. <k>etiko</k>); <k>bona mori</k> good morals,
habits or customs; <k>morala</k> habitual, customary: relating to <k>mori</k>
(N.B. not conforming to the rules of right conduct,
righteousness. A moral man = <k>etikala homulo;</k> cf. IV-233); <k>moralisto</k>:
one who studies the <k>«mori».</k> Def.: Kustumi (di persono o
lando), natural od aquirita, relate lia boneso o maledeso por la
konduto di vivo.

<k>morbo</k> disease, malady, distemper: the illness itself;
(for state, condition, ill person, cf. <k>malada</k>, <k>morbeso</k>); <k>morboza</k>
diseased; <k>morbala</k> morbid: relating to the disease; <k>morbifanta</k>, <k>morbiva</k> morbific, pathogenic. Ex.: Kancero esas un de la maxim
danjeroza morbi; Morbala simtomi. V .exp.: Me audas, ke Sro. X.
esas <k>malada</k> (E. sick, ill). Yes, il havas la <k>morbo</k>
(E. disease) di Bright. Nuntempe esas multe <k>maladeso</k> (E.
sickness) en nia urbo.

<k>mordar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to bite (cf. <k>rodar</k>); <k>mordetar</k>
to nibble; <k>mordanta</k>, <k>mordema</k> biting; <ex>(fig.)</ex> mordant,
caustic, sarcastic, poignant.

<k>morge</k> tomorrow, <k>(la) morga dio</k>, <k>morgo</k> the next
day, day after; <k>morge matine</k>tomorrow morning; <k>posmorge</k>
(day) after tomorrow; <k>til morge</k> until tomorrow; <k>sep
 dii pos morge</k> a week from tomorrow. Ex.: li lektos la libro
morge. Se me ne venos morge, takaze me venos posmorge.

<k>morso</k> bit (of a bridle); <ex>(fig.)</ex> curb, check,
restraint.

<k>mortar</k> <ex>(intr., lit. and fig.)</ex> to die, cease to
live, depart this life; <ex>(of fire)</ex> to go out; <ex>(of
movement)</ex> to come to an end; <k>mortigar</k> to deprive of
life; cause to die, kill, execute, put to death (by natural or
artificial means); (cf. <k>ocidar</k>, <k>asasinar</k>, <k>senkapigar</k>, <k>masakrar</k>); <k>morteskar</k> to be dying, be on the point of
death; <k>morto</k> death, decease; <k>mortado</k> mortality; <k>mortanto</k>, <k>mortonto</k> dying person, moribund person; <k>mortinta</k> dead,
defunct; <k>mortopunto</k> point of death; <k>mortopuniso</k> death
penalty; <k>mortala</k> death; <k>mortiva</k> mortal: subject to
death; <k>mortiveso</k> liability to death; <k>mortigive malada</k>
mortally sick; <k>mortigo</k> killing, execution; <k>mortigisto</k>
executioner; <k>mortiganta</k>, <k>mortiva</k> mortal, deadly: which causes
death; (as a disease, wound); <k>stone mortinta</k> stone dead; <k>naske
 mortinta</k> born dead stillborn; <k>mortar naturale</k> to die a
natural death; <k>mortale vundita</k> mortally wounded; <k>mortigive
 mortala paleso</k> deathly pallor; <k>esar (balde) mortonta</k>
to be at the point of death, at death’s door; <k>mortar ye la
 mondumo;</k> to be dead to the world; <k>mortintala domo</k>
mortuary; <k>depoz</k>, <k>expozeyo di mortinti</k> morgue.

<k>mortezo</k> <ex>(carp.)</ex> mortise; <k>mortezizar</k> to cut a
mortise in.

<k>mortifikar</k> <ex>(tr., rel. and fig.)</ex> to subdue the
passions and appetites by severe discipline; (N.B. for sense of
«to humiliate», cf. <k>shamigar</k>, <k>vexar</k>).

<k>moruo</k> <ex>(ich.)</ex> cod (-fish) (Gadus morrhua); <k>sika
 moruo</k> stockfish; dried (unsalted) cod; <k>sika salmoruo</k>
dried salted cod; <k>oleo ek moruhepato</k> cod-liver oil.

<k>mosko</k> <ex>(scent) </ex>musk; -<k>izita</k> m. scented; <k>moskanado</k>
m. duck; (Anas moschata); <k>moskocervo</k> m. deer (Moschus
moschiferus); <k>moskobovo</k> m. ox (Ovibus moschatus); <k>moskomusareno</k>
m. shrew, sondeli (Myogale moschata); <k>moskorato</k> m. rat
(Fiber zibethicus); <k>moskoskarabeo</k> m. beetle (Ceromby
moschatus).

<k>motivo</k> motive: that which excites to action, determines
choice; <ex>(mus.)</ex> motif; <k>motivizar</k> to state the motive or
grounds of (an opinion, act); <ex>(fig.)</ex> to justify; <k>plendo
 motivo</k> reason for complaint, grievance; <k>sen motiva</k>
gratuitous: without proof or motive (cf. <k>gratuita</k>); <k>sen
 motiva supozajo</k> gratuitous supposition; <k>il motivizis sua
 refuzo</k> he stated the grounds for his refusal.

<k>motoro</k> <ex>(mechanical)</ex> motor: moving power, that
which imparts motion; <k>motorveturo</k> motor vehicle; <k>gazolin
 motoro</k> gasoline motor.

<k>movar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to move, set in motion, stir,
propel; <k>mov(ad)o</k> movement, motion; <k>movanta</k> moving; <k>moviva</k>
motive, propelling, driving; <k>movebla</k> movable; <k>movebleso</k>
mobility; <k>movopovo</k> moving power, propelling force; <k>movo</k>
<k>alternanta</k> alternating movement; <k>ne movebla</k>
immovable.

<k>moyeno</k> means, medium (through which a thing is done);
instrumentality; <k>moyeni</k> (material) means, resources; <ex>(math.)</ex>
means; <k>moyenacho</k> (poor) expedient; <k>moyeni legitima</k>
legitimate means; <k>per la moyeno</k> by means (of); <k>kontributar
 segun sua moyeni</k> contribute according to one’s means; <k>vivo
 moyeni</k> means of subsistence or existence; <k>trovar la moyeno facar
 ulo</k> to find the means to do something.

<k>muar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to moult, mew; shed or cast off hair
(if dogs), feathers (of birds), horns (of deer), outer layer of
skin (of serpents), and the like which are replaced by new
growth; to break, change (voice at puberty); <k>vocomuo</k>
change of voice. Def.: Chanjar pelo, pili, plumi, ye determinita
tempi o periodi; III-606.
<k>muaro</k> moire: a watered fabric, as watered silk.

<k>mucilajo</k> <ex>(bot.)</ex> (plant-) mucilage; (N.B. for the
adhesive substance, cf. <k>gluo</k>). Def.: Humoro vikoza qua
trovesas en ula planti; IV-586.

<k>muelar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to grind, crush (in a mill); (cf. <k>grindar</k>);
<k>mueleyo</k>, <k>muelerio</k> mill; <k>mueldisko</k>, <k>muelpetro</k> millstone; <k>muelisto</k>
miller.

<k>muflo</k> <ex>(chem.)</ex> muffle. Def.: Speco di vazo (ek
argilo) en qua on pozas objekti submisenda nedirete a
l’efiko di la fairo; III-530.

<k>muflono</k> <ex>(zool.)</ex> mouflon; species of wild sheep
(Ovis Musimon).

<k>mujar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to bellow, roar (winds, waves,
thunder, cannon); (cf. <k>bramar</k>).

<k>muko</k> mucus; <k>mukozo</k> mucus membrane (cf. <k>pituito</k>, <k>mucilajo</k>). Def.: Humoro normale sekretaca da la membrani
dicata mukozi; IV-585.

<k>mulato</k>, <k>mulatulo</k>, <k>mulatino</k> mulatto; (cf.<k>mestico</k>, <k>hibrido</k>).
Def.: Genetito da blankulo e negrino (o negro e blankino); V-33.

<k>muldar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to form a mold (mould) of, as in
sand, in which to make a casting; <ex>(fig.)</ex> -<k>ar su</k> to
mold, model oneself. V. exp.: En giserio, on unesme <k>muldas</k>:
to esas ago donar justa formo ad la sablo o l’argilo en qua
on varsos la fuzita metalo. Po la <k>muldo</k> on uzas la <k>muldilo</k>
ek ligno, fero, e.c. Duesme on <k>gisas</k> la fuzita metalo en
la <k>mulduro</k>; III-82.

<k>multa</k> <ex>(of number)</ex> many, numerous; <ex>(of
quantity)</ex> much; <k>multo</k> a lot, a large quantity; <k>multi</k>
many (in number); <k>multa homuli</k> many men; <k>multa vino</k>
much wine; <k>multeso</k>, <k>multopleso</k> multiplicity; <k>multopla</k>, <k>multo</k>
manifold, multiple; <k>(plu) multigar</k> to multiply: make more
numerous (for math. sense, cf. <k>multiplikar</k>); <k>multigo</k>
multiplication; <k>multeskar</k> to become more numerous; <k>multatempe</k>
many a time; <k>multaforma</k> multiform; <k>multaflora</k>
multiflorous: many-flowered; <k>multe plu bone</k> much better, a
great deal better; <k>multasorta</k>, <k>speca</k> many kinds of, many
species of; <k>multakolora</k> multi-colo(u)red, many colored; <k>plu
 o min multe</k> more or less. Ant. <k>Poka.</k>

<k>mungar (su)</k> to blow one’s nose, to wipe one’s
nose.

<k>muntar</k> <ex>(tr., tech.)</ex> to put together, assemble,
set up, mount (a machine, a gem). V. exp.: On <k>asemblas</k>
planki o peci, on ne <k>muntas</k> li. On <k>muntas</k> mashino o
karpenturo, asemblante lua peci; IV-598.

<k>muro</k> wall; <k>murego</k> thick or large wall (as of a
city, a fort); <k>murala</k> mural; <k>murizar</k>, <k>murklozar</k> to wall
up, immure; <k>murarmoro</k> cupboard (in a wall);<k>murpapero</k>
wallpaper.

<k>murmurar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to murmur: make a low, continued
noise; <ex>(of water) </ex>to purl; <ex>(of wind)</ex> to breathe,
whisper, rustle; <ex>(of bees)</ex> to hum; <k>murmur(ach)ar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex>
to mumble, mutter: utter indistinctly; (N.B. for sense of «to
whisper» cf. <k>susurar</k>).

<k>muso</k> mouse; <k>musea</k>, <k>musgriza</k> m. colo(u)red, m. gray
(grey) (colored); <k>mustruo</k> m. hole; <k>museyo</k> m. nest; <k>muskaptilo</k>
m. trap.

<k>musho</k> <ex>(ent.)</ex> fly; <k>musheto</k> small fly, midge; <k>mushkaptilo</k>
f. catcher; <k>para musho</k> f. screen; <k>mushsnapero*</k> <ex>(orni.)</ex>
flycatcher (Muscicapa).

<k>muskulo</k> <ex>(anat.)</ex> muscle; <k>muskulala</k> muscular
(system, etc.); <k>muskuloza</k> muscular: brawny; <k>muskularo</k>
musculature; <k>muskuleso</k> muscularity.

<k>musono</k> monsoon. Def.: Vento qua suflas de esto a westo
dum duimo di l’yaro, ed inverse dum l’altra duimo;
II-643. DeFIRS

<k>mustar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex><k />must, to have to, to be
under the nesessity of, be obliged; (past tense) had to; <k>me
 mustas ridar</k>, <k>vidante ta spektaklo</k> I had to laugh, seeing
that spectacle (i.e., I could not do otherwise). V. exp.: <k>Mustar</k>
expresas neceseso absoluta (sen-kondiciona) e nerezistebla;
VI-487; kp. <k>darfar</k>, <k>oportar.</k> Ex.: Sur ta glitiganta
planko-sulo, me mustis falar. Quante richa il mustas esar. Me
mustas facar equivalas: esas necesa ke me facez. Quon on mustas
facar por enirar en la cielo? Il ne povas venar kun me, il mustas
laborar.

<k>muta</k>, <k>mut(ul)o</k> dumb, mute: destitute of the power of
speech (cf. <k>tacanta</k>); <k>mutega</k>, <k>stonemuta</k> stone
dumb.

<k>mutilar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to mutilate, maim. Ex.: Mutilar
membro di la korpo. <ex>(fig.)</ex> Mutilar la verseso, la poemo.

<k>mutono</k> a sheep; <k>mutoni</k> sheep; <ex>(fig.)</ex> small,
compact masses of white fleecy clouds (which move across the sky
like a flock of sheep); <k>mutonino</k> ewe; <k>mutonulo</k> ram; <k>mutonkarno</k>
mutton; <k>mutonatra</k> sheep-like; woolly, fleecy; <k>mutoneyo</k>, <k>mutonstablo</k> sheep-fold; <k>mutonfelo</k> sheepskin; <k>mutonshultro</k>
shoulder of mutton; <k>pastoro di mutoni</k> shepherd.

<k>mutuala</k> mutual. Ex.: Societo di mutual sokurso (E.
benefit society). Mutuala asekurerio. V. exp.: <k>Mutuala</k>, <k /> <k>reciproka</k>:
<k>Mutuala</k> aplikesas nur a la sociala institucuri di
«reciproka» helpo, sokurso, e.c.; IV-162.

<k>muzelo</k> <ex>(anat.)</ex> snout, muzzle (of animals); <ex>(fig.)</ex>
pout, pouting; <k>facar muzelo</k> to pout, stick out the lips; <k>muzelligar</k>
to muzzle; <k>muzelligilo</k> a muzzle; <k>muzelfloro</k> <ex>(bot.)</ex>
snapdragon (Antirrhinum). Def.: La nazo e la boko di bestii, en
qui ta du parti esas salienta (hundo, porko, e.c.); III-10.

<k>muzikar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to play music; <k>muzikigar</k> to
set to m.; <k>muzikajo</k> written music, score; <k>muzikala</k>
musical, relating to m.; <k>muzikema</k> musical: fond of playing
m.; <k>muzikamanta</k> m. loving; <k>muzikisto</k>, <k>muzikero</k> musician.
Note: A list of musical terms and abbreviations may be found
IV-328-330.

<k>pacar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to be at (or,
in) peace; <k>pacigar</k> to pacify, appease; <k>paceskar</k> to
make peace (<k>kun</k>); <k>pacifar</k> to make for peace; <k>paco</k>
peace; <k>pacala</k> relating to peace; <k>pacema</k> pacific: who
likes peace; <k>pacoza</k> peaceful: which is at peace; <k>pacifanta</k>, <k>paciganta</k> pacifying; <k>pacigo</k> pacification, peace-making,
appeasement; <k>pacifismo</k> pacifism; <k>pacifista</k>, <k>paco</k>
pacifist.

<k>pacienta</k> patient; <k>pacienteso</k> patience, calm endurance
or waiting, forbearance; <k>pacientesar</k> to be patient, have
patience, bide one’s time; <k>ludo di pacienteso</k> <ex>(game)</ex>
patience. Ex.: Il esas pacienta en doloro. Vartar paciente. La
patrulo pacientesis pri sua filio.

<k>pado</k> pad, padding; listing (put around doors and windows
to keep out cold); <k>padizar</k> to pad, stuff (window, etc.); <k>padochapelo</k>
porter’s pad (for burdens); padded cap (worn by children); <k>stulo
 pado</k> chair-pad. Def.: Kusen(et)o (generale ronde e kun truo en
mezo); polsteraji quin on pozas cirkum la pordi e fenestri por
kalfatar l’aperturi.

<k>padelo</k> frying-pan, skillet: metal vessel with long
handle used for frying.

<k>padloko</k> padlock; <k>padlokizar</k> to padlock, fasten with a
padlock.

<k>pafar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to shoot (with firearms); <k>pafo</k>
a shot (fired); <k>pafado</k> firing, volley; <k>pafilo</k> a
fire-arm; <k>pafajo</k> a charge, shot (for firing); <k>paflineo</k>
line of fire; <k>pafaperturo</k> loop-hole; <k>skoppafado</k>
target-firing.

<k>pagar</k> <ex>(tr., lit. and fig.)</ex> to pay (<k>ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>),
to pay for (<k>ulo</k>); <k>pag(ad)o</k> (act) pay, payment; <k>pagenda</k>
payable: which must be paid; <k>paganto</k>, <k>pagero</k> one who pays; <k>pagisto</k>
paymaster; <k>pagajo</k> payment: sum paid; <k>pagodio</k> pay
day; <k>pagopor dio</k> a day’s pay; <k>pagodato</k>, <k>paglimito</k>
maturity (of a debt). Ex.: Pagar la domaji, la kusti, la perdo.
Pagar la laboristi. <ex>(fig.)</ex> Pagar sua krimino per la vivo.

<k>pagayo</k> paddle (as for canoe); <k>pagayagar</k> <ex>(tr.,
intr.)</ex> to paddle.

<k>pagino</k> page (of a book); <k>paginigar</k> <ex>(tr., print.)</ex>
to make up into pages, to folio; <k>numerizar la pagini</k> to
number the pages (<k>di</k>); <k>paginonumero</k> number of page.

<k>pako</k> bundle, package, parcel; <k>paketo</k> packet: small
bundle; <k>pakego</k> large bundle, bale; <k>pakigar</k> to bundle
up, make (<k>ulo</k>) into a parcel; <k>pakigo</k>, <k>pakuro</k> packing;
<k>pakiganto</k>, <k>pakisto</k> packer; <k>paketoposto</k> parcel post.

<k>pakotilio</k> <ex>(com., nav.)</ex> (seaman’s) venture.
Def.: Diversa vari (mikra) quin la maristi daras embarkar sen
pagar freto; III-141.

<k>paktar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to covenant, enter into a compact
(<k>kun</k>): (cf. <k>kontratar</k>); <k>li paktis kun Satano
 kontre me</k> they entered into a compact with Satan against me;
<k>esas pakto inter li</k> there is an agreement between them.

<k>pala</k> pallid, pale; <k>palega</k> ghastly, wan, sallow; <k>paleso</k>
paleness, pallor, wanness; <k>paligar</k> to cause to turn pale; <k>paleskar</k>
to turn, grow, become pale, to blanch.

<k>palato</k> <ex>(anat.)</ex> palate; <k>palatala</k> <ex>(also
gram.)</ex> palatal; <k>palatalo</k> <ex>(also gram.)</ex> palatal
(-bone); <k>palatvelo</k> velum: soft-palate.

<k>paleografio</k> paleography; <k>paleografiisto</k> paleographer.
Def.: Arto dechifrar la anciena skriburi.

<k>paleto*</k> paddle-board (of a paddle-wheel); blade (of an
oar).

<k>palio</k> straw <ex>(fig.)</ex> chaff; <k>paliea</k>
straw-colo(u)red; <k>paliofasko</k> truss of straw; <k>palitapiso</k>
straw matting; <k>paliomatraco</k> straw mattress; <k>paliamaso</k>
heap of straw; <k>paliizar</k> to cover with straw.

<k>paliatar</k> <ex>(tr. med. and gen.)</ex> to palliate;
mitigate, alleviate, (a disease); to cloak, extenuate (a fault); <k>paliativa</k>, <k>paliativo</k> palliative. Def.: Alejar maladeso o malajo, sen
remediar ol komplete; III-331; Kalmigar provizore. Ex.: Laudano
paliatas kelka dolori. Paliatar eroro.

<k>palinodio</k> palinode. Def.: Anciena verso en qua la poeto
retraktis sua olima opinioni.

<k>paliso</k> stake, pale, picket (as of a fence); <k>palisego</k>
pile, large post; <k>palisrango</k> row of stakes, paling (cf. <k>palisado</k>);
<k>palisizar</k> to cover with stakes; to stake out, make with
stakes. Def.: Longa peco ek ligno (ofte) akutigita ye un
extremajo.

<k>palisado</k> palisade, stockade (paling); (cf. <k>palisaro</k>);
<k>palisadeto</k> picket (as of a fence) (cf. <k>paliso</k>); <k>palisadcelulo</k>
<ex>(biol.)</ex> p. cell. Def.: Obstaklo (precipue en militarto) ek
serio di pintigita palisi o fosti. Anke uzata por la senco
biologiala; II-294.

<k>palmo</k> <ex>(bot.) </ex>palm(-branch); <ex>(anat.)</ex> palm
(of hand); <k>palmiero</k> palm tree; <k>palmeto</k> <ex>(arch.)</ex>
palmette: carved palm-leaf ornament; <k>palmosundio</k> Palm
Sunday.

<k>palmipeda</k>, <k>palmipedo</k> palmiped. Def.: Speci di uceli quale
anadi, cigni, pinguini, qui havas pedi palmata.

<k>palpar</k> <ex>(tr.) </ex> to feel (about); <k>palp(ad)o</k>
feeling (by touch); <ex>(med.)</ex> palpation ( a method of
exploration by touch and pressure); <k>palpebla</k> palpable,
tangible; <ex>(fig.)</ex> plain, obvious; <k>palpilo</k> palp(us),
feeler, tentacle; <k>palpar su</k> to feel oneself. Def.: Tushar
per la fingri o per altro por explorar. Ex.: Palpar la pulsado
(di l’arterii) di ulu.

<k>palpitar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to palpitate, throb; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
to tremble, flutter. Ex.: Kande la kordio palpitas, on ne esas
mortinta. Palpitar pro pavoro.

<k>paltoto</k> paletot: a loose coat or jacket worn by both
sexes, an overcoat (cf. <k>surtuto</k>).

<k>pamfleto</k> pamphlet (N.B. this refers only to a pamphlet
on a satirical or strongly controversial subject; cf. <k>broshuro</k>).

<k>pano</k> bread (leavened; cf. <k>azimo</k>); loaf (of b.; <k>du
 pani</k> two loaves of bread); <k>pano nefresha</k> stale b.; <k>panopeco</k>
piece of b.; <k>panigar</k>, <k>panifar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to make, to
bake b.; <k>paniferio</k> bakery; <k>panopeceto</k> small piece
of bread, b.crumb (cf. <k>krumo</k>); <k>paneyo</k> pantry (bread
place); <k>panloncho</k> slice of b.

<k>pancho</k> paunch (of animals); <ex>(fig.)</ex> belly, paunch
(of persons). Def.: La unesma e maxim granda stomako di rumineri.

<k>panduro</k> pandour; <ex>(fig.)</ex> marauder, brutal man.
Def.: Speco di Hungariana soldati; IV-269.

<k>panear</k> <ex>(intr., nav.)</ex> to lie to, be hove to; <ex>(fig.
esp. automobiling)</ex> to be in a state of breakdown or halt
(occasioned by accident, misfunction, trouble). V. exp.: Panear:
esas en paneo. Paneo ne esas simpla halto, nek avario; ol esas
halto koaktata pro avario o pertubo, misfunciono; ol esas verto
teknikala di navigado, qua divenis vulgara ed internaciona per
l’automobilismo; IV-578.

<k>panelo</k> <ex>(arch.)</ex> panel, wainscot; <ex>(gen.)</ex> a
flat section of considerable size of a garment, wall or other
surface; <k>panelaro</k> waniscotting, panelling <ex>(collect.)</ex>; <k>panelizar</k>
to panel, wainscot; <k>panelspegulo</k> pier glass.
<k>panika</k>, <k>paniko</k> panic, sudden fright. Ex.: Panika teroro.

<k>pankreatito*</k> <ex>(med.)</ex> pancreatitis. Def.: Inflamuro
di la pankreati.

<k>palmipeda</k>, <k>palmipedo</k> palmiped. Def.: Speci di uceli quale
anadi, cigni, pinguini, qui havas pedi palmata.

<k>palpar</k> <ex>(tr.) </ex> to feel (about); <k>palp(ad)o</k>
feeling (by touch); <ex>(med.)</ex> palpation ( a method of
exploration by touch and pressure); <k>palpebla</k> palpable,
tangible; <ex>(fig.)</ex> plain, obvious; <k>palpilo</k> palp(us),
feeler, tentacle; <k>palpar su</k> to feel oneself. Def.: Tushar
per la fingri o per altro por explorar. Ex.: Palpar la pulsado
(di l’arterii) di ulu.

<k>palpitar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to palpitate, throb; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
to tremble, flutter. Ex.: Kande la kordio palpitas, on ne esas
mortinta. Palpitar pro pavoro.

<k>paltoto</k> paletot: a loose coat or jacket worn by both
sexes, an overcoat (cf. <k>surtuto</k>).

<k>pamfleto</k> pamphlet (N.B. this refers only to a pamphlet
on a satirical or strongly controversial subject; cf. <k>broshuro</k>).

<k>pano</k> bread (leavened; cf. <k>azimo</k>); loaf (of b.; <k>du
 pani</k> two loaves of bread); <k>pano nefresha</k> stale b.; <k>panopeco</k>
piece of b.; <k>panigar</k>, <k>panifar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to make, to
bake b.; <k>paniferio</k> bakery; <k>panopeceto</k> small piece
of bread, b.crumb (cf. <k>krumo</k>); <k>paneyo</k> pantry (bread
place); <k>panloncho</k> slice of b.

<k>pancho</k> paunch (of animals); <ex>(fig.)</ex> belly, paunch
(of persons). Def.: La unesma e maxim granda stomako di rumineri.

<k>panduro</k> pandour; <ex>(fig.)</ex> marauder, brutal man.
Def.: Speco di Hungariana soldati; IV-269.

<k>panear</k> <ex>(intr., nav.)</ex> to lie to, be hove to; <ex>(fig.
esp. automobiling)</ex> to be in a state of breakdown or halt
(occasioned by accident, misfunction, trouble). V. exp.: Panear:
esas en paneo. Paneo ne esas simpla halto, nek avario; ol esas
halto koaktata pro avario o pertubo, misfunciono; ol esas verto
teknikala di navigado, qua divenis vulgara ed internaciona per
l’automobilismo; IV-578.

<k>panelo</k> <ex>(arch.)</ex> panel, wainscot; <ex>(gen.)</ex> a
flat section of considerable size of a garment, wall or other
surface; <k>panelaro</k> waniscotting, panelling <ex>(collect.)</ex>; <k>panelizar</k>
to panel, wainscot; <k>panelspegulo</k> pier glass.
<k>panika</k>, <k>paniko</k> panic, sudden fright. Ex.: Panika teroro.

<k>pankreatito*</k> <ex>(med.)</ex> pancreatitis. Def.: Inflamuro
di la pankreati.

<k>pantalono</k> (long) trousers, a pair of pantaloons (cf. <k>bracho</k>);
<k>pantalonfenduro</k> t. flap.

<k>pantomimo</k> pantomime, dumb-show. Def.: La pleado di
aktoro qua ne parolas e konseque expresas «omno» (<k>panto</k>)
per gesti parte konvencionala; VII-156.

<k>papo</k> pope; <k>papala</k> papal; <k>papeso</k> <ex>(dignity,
office)</ex> papacy; <k>papismo</k> papism, popery; <k>papisto</k>, <k>papista</k> papist; <k>papigebla</k> eligible to be pope.

<k>papavero</k> <ex>(bot.)</ex> poppy (genus: Papaver); <k>papavereto</k>
red (or, corn-) poppy (Papaver Rhoeas.).

<k>papero</k> paper; <ex>(fig.)</ex> paper document, writing); <k>papera</k>
made of p.; <k>paperachi</k> old paper(s), waste p.; <k>absorbiva
 papero</k> blotting-p.; <k>paperi aferala</k> business papers; <k>paperfabrikeyo</k>
p. mill; <k>paperfolio</k> sheet of p.; <k>paperobloko</k> block of
p.; <k>papervendisto</k> stationer; <k>paperifisto</k> p.
manufacturer; <k>paperklovo</k> thumb-tack (for fastening papers),
paper-fastener; <k>paperkorbo</k> basket for p.; <k>paperkorno</k> p.
cone; <k>paperkultelo</k> p.-knife;<k />-<k>presilo</k>
p.-weight; <k>paperpasto</k> papier-mache; <k>papero striizita</k>, <k>paperlineizita</k> ruled p.;<k>papero statala</k> a state paper; <k>paperuyo</k>
p. holder, portfolio; <k>senskriba papero</k> blank p.

<k>papiro</k> papyrus; <ex>(bot.)</ex> paper-rush. Def.:
Egiptiana arbusto sur la kortico di qua skribis la antiqua, e ta
kortico ipsa; III-141.

<k>paplo</k> pap (for infants); pulp (fopr making paper); <k>paplatra</k>
pulplike, pulpy.

<k>papriko</k> Cayenne pepper (Capsicum). N.B. «paprika», the
mildly pungent condiment might be translated by <k>dolca pimento</k>, <k>dolca papriko.</k>

<k>papulo</k> papule, (solid) pimple (cf. <k>veruko</k>). V.
exp.: Papulo esas normala saliajeto di la pelo o di la mukozi
(sur la fingri, sur la lango, e.c.). <k>Pustulo</k> esas tumoreto
pusifanta (de qua venas lua nomo) en eruptiva morbi (variolo,
skarlatino, e.c.); II-646.

<k>para</k> <ex>(arith.)</ex> even, equal; of equal footing, of a
common level; <k>pareso</k> parity; <ex>(fin.)</ex> par; <k>paro</k>
a pair, a couple (of animals, or objects of like nature), brace; <k>parigar</k>
to put in two’s, pair, couple, match (by two’s); y<k>e
 pareso</k> at par, on a par, on an equality; <k>super para</k>, <k>pareso</k> above par; <k>tri para de perdriki</k> three brace of
partridges.

<k>paradar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to parade (as troops, or like
troops); Ex.: Trupi paradas tra la stradi. Parado di cirko.
Parado-placo, -agro (E. paradeground).

<k>paradizo</k> <ex>(lit. and fig.)</ex> paradise; <k>paradizucelo</k>
bird of paradise. Ex.: La paradizo Mohamedala. <ex>(fig.)</ex> Ca
loko esis terala paradizo.

<k>paradoxo</k> paradox; <k>paradoxa</k>, <k>paradoxala</k>, <k>paradoxatra</k> paradoxical
(statement, opinion, etc.); <k>paradoxem(ul)o</k> person given to
paradox. Def.: Aserto o propoziciono kontre vulgara o komuna
opiniono. Ex.: La movado dila tero esis longa-tempe paradoxo.

<k>parafo</k>scrawled initials. paraph: flourish after a
signature; <k>parafizar</k> to put one’s initials to (<k>ulo</k>)
with an added flourish; <k>parafacho</k>

<k>parafairo</k> screen or protection from fire; fire-guard,
fire-screen.

<k>parafrazar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to paraphrase: freely translate,
amplify (a text). V. exp.: <k>Perifrazo</k> esas frazo o frazeto
uzata por expresar nedirete to quon on povus expresar per un
simpla vorto. Ex.: «la flamifanta globo», vice «la suno». <k>Parafrazo</k>
esas quaza traduko di frazo o texto en la sama linguo, por
klarigar o developar olu. Ex.: La predikero citas verso ek la
Biblio, e pose parafrazas olu; VI-248.

<k>parafulmino</k> a protection against lightning; a lightning
conductor.

<k>paralela</k>, <k>paralelo</k> parallel (lines); <k>paraleleso</k> parallelism;
<k>paralela cirklo</k> <ex>(geog.)</ex> circle of latitude.

<k>paralizar</k> <ex>(tr., lit. and fig.)</ex> to paralyse,
palsy; render powerless, destroy energy; <k>paralizesar</k> to be
paralysed, have a paralytic stroke; <k>paralizaceso</k> paralytic
stroke; <k>paralizika</k>, <k>paraliziko</k> paralytic (person). Ex.: Pavoro
paralizis omna lua fakultati.

<k>paralogismo*</k> paralogism. V. exp.: <k>Paralogismo</k>
esas rezonado nekoncie falsa o kande la premisi ne justifikas la
dedukturo. <k>Sofismo</k> esas volata paralogismo o mis-rezonado.

<k>paralumo</k> a shade from light (as a shade for a lamp, a
window blind, etc.).

<k>paramento</k> cloth cuff, turned-up end of the sleeve of a
coat or gown; (cf. <k>mansheto</k>, <k>ponyeto</k>). Def.: Parto (ek
drapo o simila stofo) di la maniko di vesto, qua esas trusita;
VI-245.

<k>parapluvo</k> anything which protects from rain; an
umbrella.
<k>parasuno</k> any shade from the sun: a parasol.

<k>parazita</k>, <k>parazitala</k>, <k>parazitatra</k> <ex>(lit. and. fig.)</ex>
parasitic(al); <k>parazito</k> of men, animals, plants, a parasite; <k>parazitaro</k>
vermin; <k>parazitesar</k> to be a parasite; <k>paraziteso</k> parasitism.
<k>Parco</k> <ex>(myth.)</ex> Parca, one of the three Fates.

<k>parcelo</k> parcel, patch (of land): clearly defined and
divided portion of gound etc.; <k>parceligar</k> to parcel out (<k>ulo</k>);
(cf. <k>pak(et)o</k>).

<k>pardonar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to forgive, condone, overlook,
pardon (<k>ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>); (cf. <k>indulgar</k>). V. exp.: vid. <k>exkuzar.</k>

<k>parenta</k> of the same family, related, akin; <k>parento</k>, <k>parentulo</k>, <k>parentino</k> a relative; (cf. <k>patro</k>); <k>parentaro</k> kinsfolk; <k>parenteso</k>
relationship; <k>parentigar</k> to connect by marriage; <k>bone
 parentigar la pueri</k> to marry the children into good
families; <k>parenteskar kun nobelaro</k> to become connected by
marriage with the nobility.

<k>parentezo</k> <ex>(sign and phrase)</ex> parenthesis; <k>parenteze</k>
in p.; by the way of (cf. <k>incidente</k>).

<k>parfacar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to do (<k>ulo</k>) thoroughly,
complete, carry through to the end.

<k>parfinar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to finish (<k>ulo</k>)
completely, to accomplish, fulfil (cf. <k>plenigar</k>, <k>realigar</k>);
<k>paro</k> (a complete, perfect) finish, consummation.

<k>parfumo</k> <ex>(substance and odor)</ex> pefume, fragrance,
agreeable odo(u)r (cf. <k>odorizar</k>); <k>parfumizar</k> to
perfume; <k>parfumoza</k> fragrant (naturally); <k>parfumizita</k>
perfumed (artificially); <k>parfumaquo</k> scented water.

<k>pariar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to bet, lay a wager, stake (<k>ulo</k>, <k>pri ulo</k>); <k>pariar por ulu</k> to bet on someone; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
to back (the success) of someone; <k>pariar kontre ulu</k> to bet
with (against) someone; <k>pario</k> bet, wager; <k>pariajo</k> the
stake; <k>pariado mutuala</k> «pari mutual». Ex.: Me parias 100
fr. kontre 50 fr. Pariar ke kavalo vinkos.

<k>parieto</k> wall (serving as partition, as in a room); inner
surface (of a vase, tube. etc.); <ex>(anat.)</ex> coat, wall (as of
stomach); <k>parieti</k> walls, coatings; <ex>(anat., bot., zool.)</ex>
paries, parietes; <k>parietala</k> relating to a wall; parietal; <k>parietala
 osto</k>, <k>parietalo</k> parietal bone; <k>parietizar</k> to put a wall in;
chamber off (<k>ulo</k>); <k>parietizita</k> walled, chambered.

<k>parirar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to go through (to end or
destination).

<k>parkurar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to run through (to end or
determined place); <ex>(fig.)</ex> to peruse (a book) quickly, to
read cursorily; <k>paro</k> the running over, passage; <k>parajo</k>
line taken, road, course (of a river), trip (of auto, etc.); <ex>(surg.)</ex>
course, direction (of a wound).

<k>parlamento</k> parliament; <k>parlamentano</k> member of p.; <k>parlamenteyo</k>
house of p.

<k>parlementar*</k> <ex>(intr., milit.)</ex> to parley: confer
with an enemy; <k>parlementanto</k>, <k>parlementero</k> negotiator (of terms), bearer
of a flag or truce.

<k>paroko</k> parish priest, rector (cf. <k>pastoro</k>); <k>parokala</k>
priestly; <k>parokeso</k> rectorship, living; <k>parokeyo</k> rectory,
parsonage; <k>parokio</k> parish; <k>parokiala</k> parish, parochial
(church, school, etc.)<k>parokiano</k> parishioner.

<k>parolar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to speak, talk (<k>pri</k>) (cf. <k>konversar</k>, <k>diskursar</k>); <k>paroligar</k> to cause someone to talk; <k>parola</k>
verbal, oral; <k>parolo</k> speaking, word; <k>parolado</k> speech,
talk; <k>parole</k> by word of mouth, verbally; <k>paroloza</k>, <k>parolema</k>
talkative, vebose, loquacious; <k>parol(ach)adar</k> to be verbose;
<k>paroltalento</k> gift of speech; <k>parolmaniero</k> elocution (cf.
<k>diciono</k>);<k>parolyuro</k> right to speak; <k>parolajileso</k>, <k>rapideso</k> volubility, fluency; <k>paroltubo</k> speaking trumpet
(cf. <k>vocokonduktilo</k>); <k>parolar la Franca (</k>or,<k>parolar
 France)</k> to speak French; <k>parolar segun la raciono</k> to
talk sense, reason; <k>amikala paroli</k> friendly words. V. exp.:
vid. <k>dicar.</k>

<k>paronimo</k>, <k>paronima</k> <ex>(gram.)</ex> paronym(ous). Def.: Vorti di
simila formo od etimologio, ma di diferenta signifiki quale: <k>abstraktar</k>, <k>distraktar.</k>

<k>paronomazio</k> <ex>(rhet.)</ex> resemblance between words of
different languages.

<k>parotidito</k> <ex>(med.)</ex> parotitis (cf. <k>oreliono</k>).
Def.: Inflameso neinfektala di la parotido; M. XI-67.

<k>parqueto</k> parquetry: inlaid flooring; <k>parquetizar</k> to
parquet (a floor).

<k>parto</k> part, share, portion; part (in games, music,
etc.); <k>partigar</k> to divide into different shares, portions; <k>partoprenar</k>
<ex>(tr.)</ex> to take a share (in), participate (in); <k>partigebla</k>
divisible into parts or shares; <k>partoprenanto</k> sharer,
partaker, participant; <k>partala</k> partial: affecting a part
only, not total;. Def.: Un porciono de de divebla toto. Ex.:
Dividar ulo en quar parti. Partoprenar ula afero.

<k>partenero</k> partner (in a dance, in sports; N.B. not in
business; cf <k>asociito</k>). Ant.: <k>adverso.</k>

<k>patero</k> <ex>(theat.)</ex> (Eng.) pit. (U.S.) parquet
circle: part of ground floor under balcony.

<k>partio</k> party: collection of people for amusement, play,
hunting, fishing, etc.

<k>partikulo</k> <ex>(gram.)</ex> particle, a subordinate word
never inflected, a preposition, conjunction, interjection; an
affix; <ex>(phys.)</ex> particle: minute portion of matter; <ex>(R.C.
rel.)</ex> particle, fragment of consecrated bread.

<k>partikulara</k> particular, peculiar, special; <k>partikulareso</k>, <k>partikularajo</k> peculiarity, particularity; <k>partikulare</k> particularly,
especially, peculiarly; <k>partikularigar</k> to particularize, specify
(cf. <k>detalizar</k>); <k>partikularismo</k> <ex>(rel., polit.)</ex>
particularism. Ex.: Planto partikulara ad klimato. Partikulara
amiko. Partikularajo (od, singularajo) di parolado esas
idiotismo. Partikularigar la mikra detali. Il laboris partikulare
(od, specale) bone. V. exp.: <k>Partikulara</k> esas la kontreajo
di generala od <k>universala; aparta</k> signifikas quaze <k>separita</k>, <k>izolita</k>, <k>sola;</k> VII-154; kp. VII-476.

<k>partiso</k> party, a number of persons united against others
of contrary opinion; <ex>(in a law-suit)</ex> litigant, party; <k>partiseto</k>
faction; <k>partisano</k> party member; partisan; <k>partisaneso; emeso</k>
partisanship; <k>partisala</k>, <k>ema</k>, <k>partisana</k> party, partisan.
<k>partizano</k> partisan, a kind of halberd or pike.

<k>parturar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to bear (a child), bring forth,
beget, give birth to; to calve, lamb; <ex>(fig.)</ex> to produce,
create; (cf. <k>gravidigar</k>); <k>parturo</k> childbirth,
delivery, confinement, parturition (cf. <k>akusho</k>, <k>genito</k>); <k>parturala</k>
puerperal; <k>parturajo</k> (of animals) a litter; <k>parturintino</k>
woman in child-bed; <k>parturbenediko</k> churching (of a woman after
a childbirth).

<k>parvenar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to arrive (at destination), to
attain (one’s aim, fortune, success in life); <k>parveninto</k>, <k>parvenintacho</k> <ex>(fig.)</ex> successful person; parvenu, upstart.

<k>pasar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to pass (<k>tra</k>, <k>super ulo</k>);
to pass (one’s life, time, etc.); to pass away; <k>pas(ad)o</k>
passing, passage (on land: cf <k>pasajar</k>); <k>pasanta</k>, <k>pasema</k>
passing, transitory; <k>pasanto</k>, <k>pasero</k> passer-by, passenger (on
land); <k>pasinta</k> past, gone; <k>pasinto</k> one who has
passed; <ex>(fig.)</ex> dead, vanished person; <k>pasajo</k>
anything which is passed, gone; <k>paseyo</k> pass; passage
(place); <k>pasigar</k> to cause to pass; to cause or allow (a
boat, a vehicle) to pass (cf. <k>preterpasar</k>); <k>paspermiso</k>, <k>pasletro</k>pass: permit for transit; <k>pasvorto</k> password.
Ex.: Il pasis avan nia pordo. Pasar de Anglia a Francia. Tempo
pasas. Pasar de un temo ad altra. Me preter-pasis lua domo.
Pasigez la salo, me pregas!

<k>pasabla</k> passable, tolerable, middling, fair; <k>pasable</k>
tolerably, rather, fairly, passably, pretty, indifferently. Def.:
Indikanta grado o valoro meza, la minim alta, quan on povas
aceptar o tolerar; III-205. Ex.: Ico esas pasabla vino. La
teatrajo esis pasable bona. Ta muliero esas pasable bela. Esas
pasable varma en ca chambro, ma ne sat varma por mea olda patro.

<k>pasajar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to take passage (on a ship), be a
passenger (on ship); to go by sea; <k>pasajo</k> passage, crossing; <k>pasajanto</k>, <k>pasajero</k>passenger (on sea; cf. <k>pasanto</k>). Ex.: Me
pasajis de Calais ad Dover. Me havis bela veturo dum la pasajo.

<k>pasiono</k> passion: violent emotion; great love or
fondness; vehement desire; <k>pasionoza</k> passionate, impassioned; <k>pasionizar</k>, <k>pasioneskar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to impassion. Ex.: Amoro ed odio
esas la maxim forta pasioni. Il pasionoze amoris el. La muziko
pasionizis me. Me pasioneskis pri muziko (E. I became
passionately fond of music).

<k>pasiva</k> passive; <k>pasivo</k> <ex>(gram.)</ex> passive
(voice); <ex>(com.)</ex> debt (owed) liability; <k>pasiveso</k>
passiveness. Ant.:<k>aktiva.</k>

<k>pasko (festo)</k> Easter, the Passover; <k>ala</k>
paschal; <k>ala ovo</k> an Easter egg; <k>komuniar ye pasko</k>
to receive the sacrament at Easter.

<k>pasmento</k>, <k>pasmenti</k> passement(erie): trimmings of lace, gimp,
braid of gold, silver, worsted, etc. for clothes an furniture.

<k>paspelo</k> edging, welt. Def.: Streta bendo de stofo
(generale de diversa kolori), per qua on bordizas ula parti di
vesto (kolumo, manchi; specale militistala); VI-142.

<k>pasto</k> paste: any soft composition; <ex>(cook.)</ex> dough;
<ex>(tech.)</ex> pâte; <k>pastatra</k> pasty, doughy.

<k>pastelo</k> pastel; (colo(u)red) crayon; <k>pastelpiktar</k> to
paint in pastel.

<k>pasteto</k> pâte: pie, pasty (made of meat or fish); <k>karno
 pasteto</k> meat pie.

<k>pastilo</k> pastil: aromatic lozenge for breath; a
preparation to scent the air.

<k>pastoro</k> pastor, minister, clergyman (cf. <k>paroko</k>);
shepherd (of sheep); <k>pastorala</k> <ex>(all senses)</ex> pastoral; <k>pastordramato</k>, <k>pastorkanto</k> <ex>(poem, drama)</ex> a pastoral; <k>pastoretulo</k>
shepherd boy; <k>pastorbastono</k> shepherd’s crook.

<k>pasturar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to pasture (animals),
graze, browse, feed (off grass while moving); <k>pastureyo</k> <ex>(place)</ex>
pasture; <k>pasturajo</k> <ex>(the food)</ex> pasturage; <k>pasturyuro</k>
the right to pasture.
<k>patino</k> patina, green film formed on metals.

<k>patro</k> a parent (father or mother); <k>patrulo</k> father; <k>patrino</k>
mother (cf. <k>matro</k>); <k>patreto</k> little father, papa; <k>ge
 patri</k>parents (both sexes);<k>patrala</k>, <k>patrulatra</k> paternal,
fatherly; <k>patrinala; patrinatra</k> motherly, maternal; <k>patruleso</k>
paternity; <k>patrocido</k> parricide.

<k>patrioto</k> patriot; <k>patriota</k>, <k>patriotala</k> patriotic; <k>patrioteso</k>
<ex>(quality)</ex> patriotism; <k>patriotismo</k> (doctrine taught)
patriotism. V. exp.: vid. <k>civismo.</k>

<k>patristiko</k> <ex>(theol.)</ex> patristics. V. exp.: Cienco
pri la doktrino dil ekleziala patri.

<k>patroliar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to go on patrol, go the rounds;
<k>patroliigar</k> to patrol (<k>ulu</k>).

<k>patrologio</k> <ex>(theol.)</ex> patrology. V. exp.: Cienco
pri la verki e la vivo dil akleziala patri.

<k>patrono</k> <ex>(antiq.)</ex> patron; <ex>(modern)</ex> patron,
supporter, protector; employer; <ex>(eccl.)</ex> advowee; patron
saint; <k>patroneso</k> patronage: authority or position of a patron;
<k>patronesar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to be a patron (<k>ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>),
to patronize: support (<k>ulu</k>).

<k>pauzar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to pause: stop temporarily; <ex>(mus.)</ex>
to make a rest. Ex.: Pauzar dum lektado, dum kantado. Pauzar
plurfoye en voyo.

<k>pavo</k> paving stone, cobble-stone; -<k>aro</k>, <k>pavizuro</k>
pavement; <k>pavizar</k> to pave.

<k>pavano</k> pavan. Def.: Anciena danso (hispana origine);
IV-395.

<k>paviliono</k> pavilion: a large peaked tent; a building with
a tent-like roof; (cf. <k>tendo</k>).

<k>pavono</k> <ex>(orni.)</ex> peacock (genus: Pavo); <k>pavonumar</k>
<ex>(intr.)</ex> to strut (like a peacock), pose.

<k>pavorar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to be afraid, be in fear, be in a
funk; <k>pavorigar</k> to frighten (<k>ulu</k>); <k>pavoreskar</k> to
take fright, begin to be scared; <k>pavoro</k> fear, fright; (cf. <k>alarmo</k>, <k>paniko</k>); <k>pavoroza</k> fearful; <k>pavorem(ul)o</k> a timid
person; <k>sen pavora</k> intrepid, fearless. V. exp.: <k>Timo</k>
esas sentimento intelektala, preske tote intelektala, ofte («me
timas ne finor mea laboro»). <k>Pavoro</k> esas instantala
sentimento, nereflektata e nerepresebla, ofte tote senmotiva ed
absurda (pavor pri araneo, muso, e.c.) «La generalo ne <k>pavoris</k>,
ma il <k>timas</k>, ke lua soldati <k>pavoros</k>». <k>Teroro</k>
esas tre granda pavoro, qua igas tremar e qua supresas omna
reflekto. <k>Hororo</k> esas sentimento di repulseso plu kam
pavoro; etimologie ol signifikas heriso (di la hari e pili). <k>Angoro</k>
esas propre fiziologial sento di konstrikto di la fauco e di
quaza sufoko, pro desquieteso o pasionoza expekto; II-79, 648;
IV-236.

<k>pazar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to take steps, to stride, step
(out), stalk (along); <k>pazetar</k> to trip along, take short
steps; <k>pazo</k> step, pace, gait; <k>pazo granda</k> stride; <k>pazope</k>
step by step; <k>pazi silencoza</k> soft or stealthy steps; <k>pazo
 rapida</k> <ex>(milit.)</ex> quick time, quick march; <k>trans</k>, <k>superpazar</k> to stride across, step over, straddle; <k>pazo
 kontilo</k> pedometer (cf. <k>hodometro</k>).

<k>pazigrafio*</k> pasigraphy. Def.: Irga sistemo di universala
skribado, qua uzas signi, partikulare matematikala simboli, por
reprezentar idei, ne vorti.

<k>peano</k> pean, pæan. Def.: Himno o kanto por honorizar
ulu, ulo; militala kanto; vinkala kanto.

<k>peco</k> piece; lump (of sugar, of beef, etc.); (cf. <k>fragmento</k>, <k>parto</k>, <k>porciono</k>); <k>peceto</k> morsel, small bit; <k>pec(et)igar</k>
to break, cut, tear (<k>ulo</k>) into pieces; to crumble; <k>peceskar</k>
to fall to pieces; <k>peceteskar</k> to crumble; <k>pecope</k>
piece by piece, bit by bit, piecemeal; <k>peci omnaspeca</k>, <k>peci
 diversa</k> odds and ends; <k>peco prenebla</k> <ex>(in checkers,
etc.)</ex> a piece which can be taken; <k>unpece</k> in one
piece; <k>monetpeco</k> a piece of money; <k>peci de ruptita
 vazo</k>pieces of a broken vase. V. exp.: <k>Peco</k>
signifikas: «parto di kontinua toto, <k>qua</k> <k>konstitucas</k>
<k>ipse</k> <k>unajo</k> <k>o toto</k>; qua havas ula propra
uneso» (on pensez pri la peci di mashino). Do on povas bone
parolar pri <k>peco de drapo</k>, <k>pri monetpeco</k>; e
konseque pri <k>parto</k> di peco. Ne esas tre utila parolar pri <k>panpeco</k>, <k>fromajopeco</k> suficas dicar <k>pano</k>, <k>fromajo</k>; IV-352.

<k>pecho</k> pitch; <k>pechoza</k> pitchy; <k>pechatra</k> sticky; <k>pechizar</k>
to pitch, cover with pitch.

<k>pedo</k> <ex>(anat. and fig.)</ex> foot; <ex>(of animals)</ex>
paw; <ex>(of verse)</ex> foot; <k>pedala</k> pedal, relating to the
foot; <k>pedalo</k> <ex>(tech.)</ex> pedal; treadle; foot-board; <k>pedalagar</k>
<ex>(intr.)</ex> to pedal, work the pedal (of a bicycle, organ,
etc.); <k>pedobalno</k> foot-bath; <k>pedbutar</k> to stumble; <k>pedfrapar</k>
<ex>(tr.)</ex> to kick (cf. <k>kikar</k>); <k>pedfingro</k> a toe; <k>pedirar</k>
<ex>(intr.)</ex> to go on foot; <k>pedirante</k> on foot; <k>pedirala</k>, <k>iranto</k>, <k>pedero</k> pedestrian; <k>pedkolo</k> instep; <k>pedokuracado</k>
chiropody; <k>pedsoldato</k> foot-soldier, infantryman; <k>pedvestizar</k>
to put boots, shoes, stockings on (<k>ulu</k>); <k>pedotabureto</k>foot-stool;
<k>marchar pe quar pedi</k> to go on all fours; <k>sen peda</k>apodal,
footless.

<k>pekar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to sin; <ex>(fig.)</ex> to
transgress, offend; <k>peko</k> sin (original, mortal, venial)<k />;<k>peketo</k> slight offense, peccadillo; <k>pekoza</k> sinful,
wicked; <k>pekokonfeso</k> confession of sin; <k>pekanta</k>, <k>pekema</k>, <k>pekiva</k> sinning peccable; <k>pekokapr(ul)o</k> scapegoat. Ex.:
Pekar kontre la imperi di Deo. <ex>(fig.)</ex> Pekar kontre la
komuna raciono.

<k>pektar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to comb (the hair); to card (wool,
etc.); <k>pektilo</k> a comb; <k>pektisto</k> comber, carder (in a
factory); <k>pektohari</k>, <k>pektrezidui</k> combings.

<k>pektoro</k>chest, breast (cf. <k>mamo</k>, <k>pulmono</k>, <k>sino</k>); <k>pektorala</k>
pectoral; <k>pektoralo</k> <ex>(anat.)</ex> pectoral muscle; pectoral,
any breast object; <k>pektorvesto</k> <ex>(of women)</ex> bodice.

<k>pekunio</k> (ready) money, cash; <k>pekuniala</k> pecuniary; <k>pekunioquanto</k>
sum of money; (cf. <k>moneto</k>).

<k>pelo</k> skin, hide (on the body; cf. <k>felo</k>); <k>pelala</k>
relating to the skin, hide; cutaneous (cf. <k>epidermala</k>); 
<k>sen peligar</k> to skin.

<k>pelerino</k> pelerine, a kind of cape, tippet worn by
ladies.

<k>pelmelo</k> pell-mell, hurly-burly, hubbub, jumbled mass,
medley, litter; <k>pelmele</k> helter-skelter.

<k>peloto</k> ball (formed of thread, silk, etc. wound round); <k>pelotigar</k>
to make (<k>ulo</k>) into a ball; to wind. Def.: Bulo ek filo
volvita; III-205. <k />

<k>penar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to take the trouble (to do
something or to do something difficult of execution), to take
pains; (cf. <k>esforcar</k>); <k>penigar</k> to put (<k>ulu</k>)
to trouble (to do something); <k>peni</k> pains (taken); <k>pene</k>
with difficulty; <k>penege</k>, <k>per granda peno</k> with great
trouble, with much difficulty; <k>to ne valoras la peno</k> that
is nor worth the trouble; <k>me penas facar ca laboro</k> I take
pains in doing this work.

<k>penacho</k> panache, a plume or bunch of feathers, as on a
helmet.

<k>pendar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to hang (up or down),
suspend, dangle; <k>pendigar</k> to cause (<k>ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>) to be
hanged or hung; <k>pendajo</k>, <k>pendpeco</k> something hung; pendant; <k>pendanto</k>, <k>pendero</k> one who hangs; a hangman; <k>pendinda</k> worthy of
hanging. Ex.: La frukti pendas de la abori. Pendar animalo per la
pedi. La judiciisto pendigas la trahizinti (E. the judge caused
the traitors to be hung). Juvelo pendanta.

<k>penetrar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.; lit. and fig.)</ex> to
penetrate, pierce (cf. <k>perforar</k>, <k>borar</k>); <k>penetrigar</k> to
cause (<k>ulo</k>) to penetrate (<k>en ulo</k>); <k>penetranta</k>, <k>penetriva</k>, <k>penetrema</k> penetrating, piercing <ex>(fig.)</ex> sagacious, acute,
keen; <k>penetremeso</k> acuteness, shrewdness. Ex.: La kuglo
penetris la korpo. <ex>(fig.)</ex> La trupi penetris la lando. La
penso penetris lua mento. Penetranta okuli. Penetrema mento.

<k>pensar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to think; <k>penso</k>, <k>pensado</k> a
thought, thinking, cogitation; <k>pensema</k> thoughtful, pensive; <k>penseskar</k>
to have an idea; (cf. <k>meditar</k>, <k>reflektar</k>, <k>rezonar</k>, <k>intelektar</k>, <k>imaginar</k>, <k>konceptar</k>, <k>memorar</k>, <k>sonjar</k>, <k>revar</k>, <k>kredar</k>, <k>judikar</k>, <k>opinionar</k>). Def.: Formacar ideo pri ulu, ulo. Ex.: Me pensis
(pri) ulo quo povas helpar vu. La homo qua pensas povas esar la
mastro di qui ne pensas. Pensez ante ke vu facos to.

<k>pensionar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to pension (soldiers, etc.)<k />to
pay a regular stipulated sum for board and lodging; <k>pensiono</k>
regular payment, board and lodging, regular charge. Def.: Pagar
reguloze ula sumo por manteno. V. exp.: <k>Pensiono</k> esas sumo
quan ulu pagas o recevas reguloze por lua manteno. Ica senco
kontenas ta di <k>pensiono</k> (1) di oficero od oficisto en
retreto; ol kontenas anke ta di la <k>pensiono</k> (2) di skolano
«interna», qua lojas e nutresas en edukerio, e ta di la <k>pensiono</k>
(3) di gasto di hotelo, qua anke lojas e nutresas, o nur
nutresas. Takaze ta qua <k>recevas</k> pensiono (1) esus <k>pensionato</k>, <k>pensionario</k>; qua pagas pension (2) o (3) esas <k>pensionanto</k>, <k>pensionero;</k> la loko ipsa esas <k>pensioneyo</k>, <k>pensionerio;</k> V-282.

<k>pento</k> <ex>(downward)</ex> slope, incline, gradient, pitch,
declivity; <k>penta</k>, <k>pente</k> (downward) sloping, shelving. V. exp.: <k>Rampo</k>
e <k>pento</k> esas esence sama, ma <k>pento</k> esas la
inklinajo de supre ad infre, e <k>rampo</k> la sinso de infre ad
supre; <k>rampo</k> acensas, <k>pento</k> decensas.
<k>pentarko*</k> pentarchos, one of five rulers; quinquivir.

<k>per</k> <ex>(prep.)</ex> by means of, through the help of, by,
with (marks, instrument, means); <ex>(arith.)</ex> multiplied by
(the sign); (cf. <k>da</k>); <k>per ke</k> through the fact
that. Ex.: Pruvar per exempli. Trapikar per poniardo. Sendar
letro per posto. La substantivi finas per «o» en la singularo.
Lu sucesis vinkar, per ke lu uzis ruzo. Quar per du facas ok.

<k>pero</k> peer (nobleman); <k>perino</k> peeress; <k>pereso</k>
peerage (rank or dignity); <k>peraro</k> peerage <ex>(collect.)</ex>;
<k>perochambro</k> Chamber of peers; (Eng.) House of Lords.

<k>perceptar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to perceive: to receive
impressions of external objects; to feel; discern; <k>percept(ad)o</k>
perception; <k>perceptiva</k> perceptive (faculty, etc.); <k>perceptebla</k>
perceptible; <k>ne ebla</k> imperceptible. Def.: Komprenar per
la sensi. Ex.: Perceptar ula bruiso. Materiaji esas sole
perceptebla.

<k>perchar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to perch; to roost (<k>sur</k>); <k>perchilo</k>
a roost; <k>percheyo</k> perching place; <ex>(fig.)</ex> upper gallery
in a theater (theatre). V.: exp.: Perchar aplikesas, ne nur a
hani, ma ad omnaspeca uceli, e mem metafore ad animali e homi;
III-327.

<k>perdar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to lose (cf. <k>egarar</k>); <k>perdesar</k>to be lost, be a loser; <k>perdo</k> loss; <k>perdajo</k> what is
lost; <k>perde vendar</k> to sell at a loss. Def.: Cesar havar to
quon on posedis o proprietis. Ex.: Perdar sua burso, fundo, voyo,
raciono, parento. Ant.: <k>ganar.</k>
<k>perena</k> perennial. Def.: Qua duras plura yari; V-89.

<k>perfekta</k> perfect (cf. <k>bonega</k>, <k>ecelanta</k>); <k>perfekteso</k>
perfection; <k>perfekte</k> perfectly (cf. <k>komplete</k>, <k>tote</k>); <k>perfektigar</k>
to perfect, bring to perfection; <k>perfektigebla</k> perfectible.
Def.: Qua havas omna sua qualesi sen inter-mixuro di defekti.
Ex.: Perfekta baleso, vino, homo, boneso.

<k>perfida</k>, <k>perfid(ulo)</k> perfidious, felonious, false-hearted,
treacherous (person); <k>perfidajo</k> act of perfidy. Ant.: <k>loyala.</k>

<k>perforar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to perforate, pierce through; (cf.
<k>borar</k>, <k>penetrar</k>). Def.: Truifar sen rotaco; III-165. Ex.:
Kuglo perforas korpo, muro.

<k>perifrazar</k> <ex>(tr.) </ex>to periphrase; express in a
roundabout way, by circumlocution. V. exp.: vid.: parafrazo.
Exp.: «La rejo dil uceli» esas perifrazo por l’aglo.

<k>periodo</k> <ex>(astron., chron.)</ex> period: term, portion
of time (cf. <k>ciklo</k>, <k>punto</k>); <k>periodala</k>, <k>periodoza</k> periodical;
<k>periodaleso</k>, <k>periodozeso</k> periodicity.

<k>peripecio</k> peripetia, sudden turn of fortune,
vicissitude; <ex>(theat.)</ex> denouement.

<k>periplo</k> <ex>(ancient geog.)</ex> periplus (a sailing
round). Def.: Historiala nomo di ula specala cirkumnavigi, e
naraco di li; V-89.

<k>perisar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to perish: die; be destroyed,
ruined; <k>perisiva</k>, <k>perisema</k> perishable. Ex.: Mili di soldati
perisis en ta batalio. <ex>(fig.)</ex> Lua nomo ne povos perisar.
Flori perisas.

<k>perjurar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to perjure: violate one’s
oath, <ex>(fig.)</ex> to break one’s word. Def.: Violacar
promiso facita per juro; V-430.

<k>perkutar</k> <ex>(tr., also med.)</ex> to percuss; <k>perkuto</k>
percussion: shock of one body against another; <k>perkutilo</k>, <k>instrumento</k> instrument of percussion; (of guns) hammer, bolt
(which sets off the cartridge). Def.: Frapar forte. Ex.: La
perkutilo perkutas la amorcilo. La cimbalisto perkutas la
cimbali. La mediko exploras per perkutado.

<k>perlo</k> pearl; <k>artificala</k>, <k>falsa perlo</k> imitation
pearl; <k>vera perlo</k> a real pearl; <k>prizentar perli a porki</k>
<ex>(fig.)</ex> to cast pearls before swine; <k>perlifanta</k>
pearl-bearing.
<k>permanar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to be permanent; <k>permano</k>, <k>permananteso</k> permanence; <k>permananta armeo</k> standing army.

<k>permear</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to permeate, pervade; <k>permeebligar</k>
to render (<k>ulo</k>) permeable. Ex.: L’aquo permeas sulo.
L’odoro permeas l’aero.

<k>permisar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to permit, allow, give leave to,
authorize, give license to; (N.B. This verb is transitive in
relation to the thing, but intransitive relative to the person).
-<k>o</k> permission, consent; <k>permisoatesto</k> written
authorization, a permit (cf. <k>konjedo</k>, <k>licenco</k>); <k>permiso
 parola</k> verbal permission; <k>permisario</k> one granted a
permit; <k>permisez a me</k> allow me! may I be permitted! Def.:
Donar libereso o yuro facar, dicar (ulo ad ulu). Ex.: Ka vu
permisas ke me apertas la fenestro? Esas permisata a vu promenar
en ca gardeno.

<k>permutar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to transpose, interchange,
permute; <k>permutite</k> vice versa. V. exp.: <k>Permutar</k> esas
chanjar l’ordino di plura kozi, qui duras formacar
kolekturo. Me <k>chanjas</k> mea vesti kande me desmetas uli e
metas altri. Ma me <k>permutas</k> li, kande (sen metar li) me
chanjas lia ordino en mea vesteyo. Kande on mixas ludkarti qui
restas sempre sama, on facas nur <k>permuti</k>; on <k>chanjas</k>
li kande on prenas altra paketo de karti vice l’unesma;
VII-204.

<k>perono</k> perron, an out-of-door flight of steps; outside
stair-case; front-door steps.

<k>peroneo*</k> <ex>(anat.)</ex> perone, fibula, small bone of
the leg. ? eFS

<k>peroraciono</k> <ex>(rhet.)</ex> peroration. Ant.:
exordio. Def.: Lasta parto, konkluzo di diskurso.

<k>perpetua</k> perpetual, forever; <ex>(fig.)</ex> for life; <k>perpetue</k>
everlastingly; <k>perpetueso</k> perpetuity; <k>perpetuigar</k> to
perpetuate. Def.: Kontinua, qua ne cesas. Ex.: Perpetua fairo
brulis sur la altaro di Vesta. Perpetua movado. Perpetua exilo.

<k>perplexa</k> perplexed, puzzled; <k>perplexeso</k> perplexity:
embarrassment of mind; irresolution. Ex.: Perplexa pro
desfacilaji neprevidita. Situeso perplexigiva. V. exp.: <k>Perplexa</k>
expresas nociono komplexa, quaze meza inter embarasata e nequieta
(kun nuanco di hezito); V-89.

<k>perquizita</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to make (legal) search, inquiry
(<k>pri ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>); <k>perquizito</k> perquisition; search; <k>perquizito
 mandato</k> search-warrant. Def.: (<k>Perquizito</k>) Legala,
judiciista serchado; figurale, tre severa ed exakta serchado,
generale malvolanta o suspektema; III-392. Ex.: Perquizitar
apartamento di persono suspektinda.

<k>persekutar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to persecute: harass unjustly; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
to importune, annoy. V. exp.: <k>Persequar</k> esas: proxime
sequar persiste, por atingar ulu od obtenar ulo. Ex.: Persequar
furtisto. Persequar cervo en chaso. Persequar la glorio, la
plezuro, la suceso. Persequar ulu avan tribunalo. <k>Persekutar</k>
esas: kruele traktar ulu persiste. Ex.: La mali persekutas la
boni, pro ke li odias lo bona. La Kristani persekutesis dum la
unesma yarcenti di l’eklezio; V-430.

<k>persequar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to pursue (with a view to
overtake); <ex>(jur.)</ex> to prosecute; <k>persequesar (da)</k> to be
pursued, prosecuted (by); <k>persequeskar</k> to start pursuit; to
indict, sue. V. exp.: vid. <k>persekutar.</k>

<k>perseverar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to persevere, pursue
steadfastly: continue on a given course, esp. in the face of
discouragement, obstacles; (cf. <k>persistar</k>). Ex.:
Perseverar en ula entraprezo. Il esas persever-anta, -ema homo.

<k>persieno</k> persienne, (outside) Venetian shutter; the
ordinary outside window-blinds with movable slats; (cf. III-290; <k>jelozio</k>).

<k>persiko</k> <ex>(fruit)</ex> a peach; <k>persikiero</k> peach tree
(Amygdalus persica); <k>persikkerno</k> peach-stone; <k>persikliquoro</k>
a persicot (a cordial).

<k>persistar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to persist: hold firm, continue
steadfast (<k>en</k>, <k>pri</k>) (cf. <k>perseverar</k>). Ex.: La testo
persistas negar. Il persistas en sua opiniono. Persistanta morbo.
Persistema homo. V. exp.: vid. <k>insistar.</k>

<k>persono</k> person (man, woman, child); <ex>(theol., gram.)</ex>
person; (cf. <k>individuo</k>); <k>personala</k> personal; <k>personaro</k>
personnel; <k>personeso</k> personality, individuality: quality of
being a person; <k>personaleso</k> quality of being personal (to
someone); <k>personalajo</k> personal peculiarity; personal remark; <k>persone</k>, <k>personale</k> in person, personally, in a personal manner; <k>personego</k>
personage: a great person or person of distinction; <k>personigar</k>
to personify (<k>ulo</k>); <k>personospegulo</k> cheval-glass: a
full-length dressing-glass.

<k>perspektiva</k>, <k>perspektivo</k> perspective; <k>perspektive</k> in perspective,
in the distance. Ex.: Lineala perpektivo. Desegnuro perspektiva.

<k>persuadar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to persuade (<k>ulu pri ulo</k>, <k>su</k>);
<k>persuado</k>, <k>persuadeso</k> persuading, persuasion, conviction; <k>persuadiva</k>, <k>persuadema</k> persuasive. Ex.: Il persuadis me venar. Me esas
persuadita ke ...

<k>perturbar</k> <ex>(tr., astron., social)</ex> to perturb,
trouble, unsettle, throw into disorder; <k>perturbanta</k>, <k>perturbiva</k>
perturbing, disturbing. Ex.: Perturbo di la mento. Perturbi
sociala, financala.

<k>peruko</k> wig, periwig, peruke; <k>perukisto</k> wig-maker.
Def.: Kuafuro de falsa hararo.

<k>perversa</k> perverse, obstinate in the wrong, wayward,
depraved; <k>perversigar</k> to pervert. Def.: Qua havas nenormala o
kontreetika tendenci (o gusto); III-205.

<k>peskar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to fish, angle (<k>por</k>, <k>per</k>, <k>ek</k>);
<ex>(tr.)</ex> to draw (<k>ulo</k>) out of the water, to catch
(also refers to coral fishing, pearl fishing, etc.); <k>peskala</k>
piscatorial; <k>peskanto</k>, <k>peskero</k>, <k>peskisto</k> fisher; <k>peskobatelo</k>
fishing-boat; <k>peskajo</k> the catch (cf. <k>fisho</k>); <k>peskeyo</k>
fishing-place, -ground; <k>peskilo</k> a fishing instrument (rod,
line, etc.); <k>peskbastono</k> fishing-rod; <k>peskyuro</k> licence,
right to fish. Ex.: Peskar karpo.

<k>pesto</k> pestilence, pest, plague (cf. <k>kontagio</k>); <ex>(fig.)</ex>
bane, scourge; <k>pestala</k>, <k>pestoza</k> pestiferous, pestilential; <k>pestiko</k>, <k>pestika</k> (person) infected; <k>pestizar</k> to infect; <k>pestizanta</k>
pestilential, infectious, contageous; <k>bubon pesto</k> bubonic
plague; <k>la pesto kaptez lu</k> may the plague take him.

<k>peticionar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to petition: present a
petition (<k>ad ulu</k>); <k>peticiono</k>, <k>peticionado</k> petition: written
request; petitioning.

<k>petro</k> stone (as a material substance; cf. <k>roko</k>, <k>stono</k>);
<k>petra</k> stony: (made) of stone; <k>petroza</k> stony: full of
stone; <k>petrepoko</k> stone age; <k>petrotaliisto</k>
stone-cutter; <k>petrigar</k> to petrify; <k>petrizar</k> to cover
with stone; <k>petroministo</k> quarryman; <k>petro kruda</k> rough
stone, quarry stone; <k>petroruptilo</k> stone breaker; <k>petrokonio</k>
keystone; <k>petroplako</k> flagstone.

<k>petrelo</k> <ex>(orni.)</ex> stormy petrel; Mother
Carey’s chicken (Procellaria pelagica).

<k>petrisar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to knead: work into a uniform mass
(dough, etc.).

<k>petular</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to be frisky, impetuous,
boisterous, turbulent, unruly.

<k>pezar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to weigh (<k>dek grami</k>, <k>e.c.</k>)
(cf. <k>gravesar</k>, <k>ponderar</k>); <k>pezo</k> weight; <k>pezajo</k>
a heavy object; weight for weighing; <k>pezanta</k>, <k>pezoza</k> heavy,
weighty, ponderous; <k>pezo kuntara</k> gross weight; <k>pezo neta</k>
net weight; <k>super pezo</k>, <k>pezeceso</k> excess weight; <k>pezo
 vivanta</k> live weight; <k>pezo ampla</k> good weight; <k>pezajo
 falsa</k> a light weight (for weighing); <k>po lua pezo ek oro</k>
at its weight in gold; <ex>(fig.)</ex> extremely dear.

<k>pia</k> pious, devout, godly; <k>pieso</k> piety, devoutness
(cf. <k>devoco</k>); <k>piacho</k> a bigot. Def.: Qua reverencas
Deo.

<k>piafar</k> <ex>(intr., of horses)</ex> to make a piaffer, to
paw the ground.

<k>piano</k> piano, pianoforte; <k>pianpliar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex>
to play the piano; <k>piano vertikala</k> upright piano; <k>piano
 horizontala</k> grand-piano.

<k>piedestalo</k> pedestal (of a column, statue, vase, etc.); <k>piedestaleto</k>
piedouche: small pedestal supporting a bust, etc.

<k>pigo</k> <ex>(orni.)</ex> magpie (genus: Pica); <k>pigea</k>
black and white colo(u)red.

<k>pigmeo</k> pigmy, dwarf; <ex>(fig.)</ex> a person without
talent, or merit, or power.

<k>pigmento</k> <ex>(natural, physiol.)</ex> pigment (cf. <k>farbo</k>).
Def.: Materio naturale koloroza, qua donas koloro ad altra kozi;
V-660. Ex.: Okulala, harala, pelala pigmento.

<k>pikar</k> <ex>(tr., lit. and fig.)</ex> to prick; prod, goad,
puncture; sting; <k>piketar</k> to peck at; strike with the beak; <k>pik(ad)o</k>
prick, prodding; <k>pikuro</k> a prick, puncture; sting (of
insects); <k>pikanta</k>, <k>pikema</k> prickly, stinging, piquant,
pungent; biting, piercing, sharp, nipping (of cold, liquids,
words, etc.); <k>pikilo</k> a pricking instrument; <k>pikbastono</k>
a goad (as for oxen). Ex.: Pikar sua fingro. Pikar bovulo,
kavalo, papero. Vorti pikanta. Pikanta mustardo.

<k>piklo</k> something preserved in spice (cf. <k>spico</k>); <k>piklaji</k>
pickles: vegetables, fruit or other food preserved in spice or
vinegar pickle and used as a condiment; <k>piklosauco</k>
ravigote: a sharp sauce.

<k>pikono</k>roko o harda materii (ex. makadamo). La
(one-pointed) pick, pickaxe (cf. <k>piocho</k>). Def.:
Instrumento por exkavar fera parto esas karakterizita per un
pinto perpendikla a la mancho; VI-533.

<k>piktar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to paint (pictures in oil or water
colo(u)rs); (cf. <k>indutar</k>, <k>farbizar</k>); <k>pikt(ad)o</k>, <k>pikturo</k>
painting, picture; <k>piktinda</k>, <k>pikturatra</k> pictureque.

<k>pilo</k> <ex>(of animals, also bot.)</ex> hair, bristle; <ex>(of
persons)</ex> hair of all parts of body except top of head; (cf. <k>haro</k>);
<ex>(of sheep, camels, etc.)</ex> wool; <ex>(of cloth, of hats)</ex>
nap; <k>pilaro</k> <ex>(of one object)</ex> coat; <k>pilala</k>
relating to h.; <k>piloza</k> hairy, shaggy, pilose; <k>pilobulbo</k>
h. bulb, h. root; <k>senpiligar</k> to depilate; <k>senpiligivo</k>
depilatory (substance); <k>longpila hundo</k> long-haired dog; <k>rezapila</k>
short-haired.

<k>pilio</k> <ex>(elec.)</ex> pile, primary cell. Ex.: La pilio
di volta.

<k>pilorio</k> pillory; <k>piloriagar</k> to pillory, put (<k>ulu</k>)
in a pillory.

<k>pinco</k> nippers (without hinges); claw (of crabs, etc.); <k>pinceto</k>
<ex>(surg.)</ex> forceps; tweezers; <k>pincego</k> (fire-) tongs;
clamp; <k>sukro pinco</k> sugar-tongs. V. exp.: <k>Tenalio</k>
esas utensilo kompozita de du peci ligita per charniro. <k>Pinco</k>
esas utensilo sen charniro (la du peci o parti esas unionita per
