sand; <k>graviatra</k> gritty.

<k>gravida</k> pregnant, with child; <k>gravideso</k> pregnancy,
gestation (state); <k>gravidigar</k> to make pregnant, get with
child; <k>gravideskar</k> to become pregnant, conceive a child; <k>gravideso</k>
(<ex>physiol.</ex>) conception.

<k>gravitar</k> (<ex>intr., phys. and fig.</ex>) to gravitate, be
attracted, tend to a center; <k>la lego di gravitado</k> the law of
gravitation.

<k>greftar</k> (<ex>tr., hort.</ex>) to graft (plants, trees); <k>greftajo</k>, <k>grefturo</k>, <k>greftosproso</k> graft, portion of a plant to be grafted on
another.

<k>Greka</k> Greek, Grecian; <k>la Greka</k> the Greek
language; <k>GrekoLatina</k> Greco-Latin.

<k>grelar</k> (<ex>intr., impersonal</ex>) to hail; <k>greletar</k>
to sleet; <k>grelas</k> it hails; <k>greleto</k> sleet; <k>grelo</k>
hail(-storm); <k>greluno</k> a hail-stone; <k>grelfrapar</k>, <k>grelagar</k>
to devastate, ravage (ulo) by hail; <k>stono grelo</k> a hail of
stones; <k>flecho grelo</k> a shower of arrows.

<k>gremio</k> lap (of a sitting person); (<ex>fig.</ex>) <k>gremio di
 l'eklezio</k> bosom, pale of the church; <k>gremialo</k> gremial,
lap cloth worn by a bishop. Ex.: El tenis sua infanto sur sua
gremio.

<k>grenado</k> (<ex>fruit</ex>) pomegranate; (<ex>milit.</ex>)
(hand-) grenade; <k>grenadiero</k> p. tree (punica granatum); <k>grenadisto</k>
a soldier who throws g.s; (<ex>fig.</ex>) grenadier: a foot soldier
of a special corps.

<k>greto</k> grating, a partition of iron or wood bars; grate
(of a stove), (metal or wood) railing or fence (used to partition
off); <k>gretizar</k> to inclose or cover with railing, to rail in

<k>grifono</k> (<ex>myth.</ex>) griffon; griffon, a kind of
European water-dog.

<k>grilar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to grill, broil (ulo) on gridiron; <k>grililo</k>
grill, gridiron; <k>grilita kotleto</k> broiled chop.

<k>grimar</k> (<ex>tr., theat.</ex>) to make up (su), by painting
wrinkles, etc., the appearance of an old person; to make up (ulu)
as an old person.

<k>grimasar</k>, <k>grimasadar</k> to grimace, contort the face, make a wry
face.

<k>grincar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to gnash, grind <k>(per la denti)</k>;
to grate (as a door, etc.).

<k>grindar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to grind, rough down as on a
grindstone, or as with emery, etc.; <k>grindopetro</k> whetstone; <k>grindopetrego</k>
grindstone. V. exp.: On ne nur akutigas o polisas kozi, ma on
anke tornas (grindas) li per la grind opetr-(eg)o. Materii por la
grindo esas <k>karborundo*</k>, smerilo, diamant-polvo, e.c.;
III-82.

<k>griza</k> gray, grey (colored); <k>grizo</k> gray (the color);
<k>grizeso</k> grayness (quality); <k>griz(ul)o</k>, <k>grizhara</k>, <k>grizbarba</k>, <k>grizkapa homulo</k> a gray-haired man; <k>grizeskar</k>
to become, turn g.; <k>grizatra</k>, <k>grizeskanta</k> grizzled.

<k>grondar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to roar, rumble (of thunder,
storm, wind, waves); to growl, snarl (of animals). Def.: Audigar
bruiso duranta e nelauta, quale la tondro fora, od ula animali
iraceskanta; IV-12.

<k>gropo</k> croup, rump (of a horse and some other animals); (<ex>arch.</ex>)
hip-roof; <k>groprimeno</k> crupper (of harness).

<k>grosa</k> thick and long; (<ex>fig.</ex>) large, great, gross,
thick, bulky; (cf. <k>granda</k>), <k>grosa arboro</k> a large
tree; <k>skribar grosa literi</k> to write in large, heavy
letters; <k>grosa e kurta</k> squat, dumpy, stubby. Def.: Relatas
du dimensioni, specale en korpo di qua la longeso esas granda o
nedefinita; III-544. Ex.: Grosa homo, filo, kordo, kolono. V.
exp.: <k>vid. dika.</k> Ant.: <k>tenua</k>.

<k>grosiera</k> (<ex>of persons, acts or objects</ex>) without
delicacy, coarse, rude, blunt, boorish, low; <k>grosiereso</k>
grossness: coarseness; <k>grosierajo</k> coarse language or word;
vulgarity, rude act; <k>grosier(ul)o</k> a rude man, a boor; <k>grosiereg(ul)o</k>
blackguard. V. exp.: To ne esas simple ne- (o des-) polita, ma
ne-edukita, preske ne-civilizita; IV-12.

<k>grucho</k> crutch; <k>gruchiero</k> one who carries c.s; (<ex>fig.</ex>)
a cripple; <k>gruchirar</k> to go on c.s.
<k>grumo</k> groom, a manservant, esp. one in charge of horses.

<k>grumelo</k> grume, a clot (in the blood, in milk, etc.); <k>grumeloizita</k>, <k>grumelooza</k> clotted; <k>grumeloigar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>), <k>grumeloifar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>):
to clot; (cf. <k>koagular</k>).

<k>grunar</k>, <k>grunachar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to grunt (as a pig); (<ex>of
persons</ex>) to grumble, growl.

<k>grupo</k> group (of persons or objects), clump (of trees),
flock (of sheep); <k>grupigar</k>, <k>grupe dispozar</k> to group; <k>grupifar</k>
(<ex>intr.</ex>) to group, form into g.s; <k>grupano</k> member of a
g.

<k>gruzo*</k> (<ex>orni.</ex>) grouse, ptarmigan, white, black,
red (Lagopus scoticus) M. XI. 348.

<k>guachpiktado</k>, <k>guachuro</k> gouache-painting; a style of
water-color painting. DeFI

<k>guardo</k> (<ex>milit.</ex>) guard, body of troops; <k>guardano</k>
soldier or member of g.

<k>guatar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to watch, be on w. for; to lie in
wait for; <k>guatigar</k> to place (ulu) on w.; <k>guatanto</k>, <k>guatero</k>, <k>guatisto</k> watcher, look-out-man; <k>guatoturmeto</k> w. tower.
Ex.: Guatar l'enemiko, l'okaziono. La kato guatas la muso.

<k>gubernio</k> government (district; e.g., as in Russia); <k>guberniestro</k>
governor (of a certain district, province).

<k>guidar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to guide, to lead, to conduct in a
way; <k>guidanto</k>, <k>guidero</k>, <k>guidisto</k> (person) guide; <k>guidilo</k> (<ex>mechan.</ex>)
guide; <k>guidoflago</k> (<ex>milit.</ex>) guidon; <k>guidlibro</k> g.
book. V. exp.: <k>Guidar</k> esas esence montrar la justa voyo ad
ulu, qua ne konocas ol, qua povas hezitar od erorar. <k>Duktar</k>
e <k>guidar</k> esas <k>direktar</k> ulu od ulo akompanante lu:
ex. Kapitano <k>duktas</k> sua kompanio, ma generalo nur <k>direktas</k>
armeo, restante en sua quartero. On <k>duktas</k> o <k>direktas</k>
navo, aer-navo, kande on esas «ye bordo» (en oli); ma per
Hertzala radii on povas <k>direktar</k> torpedo sen duktar ol;
IV-162.

<k>guindo</k> heart cherry. Def.: Frukto simila a cerizo;
IV-136

<k>gumo</k> gum, vegetable substance which exudes from certain
trees; (cf. <k>kauchuko</k>); <k>gumoza</k>, <k>gumatra</k> gummy; <k>gumizar</k>
to smear, cover with g.; <k>gumarboro</k> g. tree; <k>gumrezino</k>
g. resin; <k>gumtafto</k> court plaster.

<k>gurmo</k> milk-scall, -crust, scabs on an infant’s head
(crusta lactea).

<k>gurmando</k> gourmand, one fond of good living; <k>gurmandacho</k>
glutton. Def.: Homo qua prizas la bona (bon-saporoza) dishi e
manjas multo de li; VII-155. V. exp.: Manj-eg-ero (<k>gurmandacho</k>)
esas homo qua manjas multo, sen dicerno, kun apetito brutal; <k>gurmando</k>
preferas ne manjar kam manjar ulo qua ne plezas lu; <k>gastronomo</k>
prizas la bona dishi, la bona vivi, e.c., tamen lu ne manjas o
drinkas tro multo, lu esas nur «experto» pri la tablo; VII-155.

<k>gurto</k> broad strap, band; girth (of saddle); <k>gurtizar</k>, <k>gurtligar</k>, <k>gurtagar</k> (<ex>tr</ex>.) to strap, band, girth (a horse); <k>gurtfrapar</k>, <k>gurtflogar</k> to strike, flog with a strap. Def.: Bendo larja e
plata (de ledro, tolo, e.c.) por ligar o kun-ligar. (To ne esas
bendo, rimeno, nek zono); III-469.

<k>gustar</k> (<ex>tr</ex>.) to taste; (cf. <k>saporar</k>). <k>–ala</k>
gustatory; <k>gustexperto</k> expert taster (as of tea),
connoisseur (of wines, etc.); <k>bona –o</k> a nice t.
(used also in psychological sense); <k>gustagreabla</k>, <k>gust ecitanta</k>
relishing, tempting, savory; <k>malgusta joko</k> a bad joke, a
vulgar joke; <k>gustar la vino</k> to t. the wine, <k>il esas
 autoro sen bona –o</k> (<ex>fig</ex>.) he is an author
deficient in t.; <k>kontentigar omna gusti</k> (<ex>physiol. and
psychol</ex>.) to satisfy (please) all tastes.

<k>guto</k> drop (of liquid); <k>gutifar</k> to drop, drip,
trickle, run down; <k>gutope</k> d. by d.

<k>guturo</k> (internal) throat, gullet; (cf. <k>fauco</k>); <k>guturala</k>
relating to the gullet; gutteral; <k>guturalo</k> (<ex>gram</ex>.) a
gutteral. Def.: L’interna kavajo supre en la kolo (ciencale:
la faringo, la laringo e la supra ezofago): ex. on parolas pri
soni guturala (ciencale, li esas velala od uvulala); III-165

<k>guvernar</k> (<ex>tr. general sense</ex>) to rule with
authority, to have physical power over, to direct: <k>guvernar navo</k>
to steer a ship; to rule over a ship; <k>guvernilo</k> (<ex>tech</ex>.)
governor; a rudder, helm; <k>guvernar aferi</k> to manage a business;
<k>guvernar sua pasioni</k> to control one’s passions; <k>ca
 muliero –as sua spozo</k> this woman rules her husband; <k>guvernar
 infanti</k> to manage children; <k>la rejo di Anglia regnas ma
 ne –as; la parlamento –as</k> the king of England
reigns but does not govern; the parliament governs; <k>la verbo
 aktiva –as l’akuzativo;</k> the active verb governs the
accusative; <k>la navo guvernesas bone</k> the ship answers her
helm; <k>guvernala sistemo</k> governmental system; <k>la –isto
 di provinco</k>, <k>di banco</k> the governor of a province, of a bank;
<k>guvernanto</k>, <k>guvernisto di navo</k> helmsman of a ship; <k>guvernantino</k>, <k>guvernistino di puero</k> governess of a child; <k>la guvernado</k>
<k>vabo</k> honey-comb. Def.: Konstrukturo ek vaxo, quan la abeli facas en la abeluyo IV-398.

<k>vacilar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to vacillate: be unsteady, waver, reel, stagger; to fluctuate, 
waver in mind or opinion; (<ex>of light</ex>) to flicker; (<ex>in speaking</ex>) to falter; <k>vacil(ad)o</k> 
vacillation; <k>vacilar sur la gambi</k> to shake in or be unsteady on the legs. Ex.: La tablo vacilas. 
Ta homo havis vacilanta marcho (-maniero). Lumo qua vacilas.

<k>vacino</k> (<ex>disease</ex>) cow-pox; <k>vacinserumo</k> vaccine (matter); <k>vacinizar</k> to 
vaccinate (<k>ulu</k>); <k>vaciniz(ad)o</k> vaccination; <k>vacinifar</k> to produce cow-pox.

<k>(tra) vadar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to ford, wade across (a river, etc.); <k>eyo</k> ford; <k>ebla</k> 
fordable.

<k>vagar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to wander, rove about, stroll, stray, straggle; <k>vagado</k> roaming, 
vagrancy; <k>vagema; vagemacho</k> vagrant, vagabond; <k>vaganta mendikero</k> strolling beggar; <k>vaganta mento</k> 
(<ex>fig.</ex>) wandering mind.

<k>vagono</k> railway-carriage, car; <k>vagono unesmaklasa</k> first class c.; <k>lit</k>, <k>dormo vagono</k> 
sleeper; <k>restor vagono</k> dining-car.

<k>vajisar</k> (<ex>intr., of infants</ex>) to wail, cry. V. exp.: La specala krio di nove naskinta o 
yuna infanto; IV-578.

<k>vakar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to be vacant; <k>vako</k> vacancy; <k>vakanta</k> vacant. Ex.: La trono, la 
ofico vakas. Vakigar la trono, lo ofico. Vakanta aprtamento, episkopeso.

<k>vakancar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to have a (or, be on a) vacation, holiday; <k>vakancdio</k> a day's holiday. 
Ex.: Pasar la vakanco en la ruro. Ni vakancas dufoye dum la yaro: la paskala e la somerala vakanco.

<k>vakua</k> empty, void, blank, vacuous (<k>de</k>); <k>vakuo</k> vacuum, blank; <k>vakueso</k> vacuity, 
emptiness; <k>vakuajo</k> gap, chasm, hole; <k>vakuigar</k> to empty, vacate; to draw (poultry), to gut (fish); 
to drain (a ditch, etc.); <k>vakueskar</k> to become empty; <k>vakuifar</k> to make a void, produce a vacuum 
(as by air-pump); <k>vakua chambro</k>, <k>stomako</k>, <k>spaco</k> empty room, stomach, space; <k>vakua muro</k> 
blank wall; <k>vakua tempo</k> unoccupied time; <k>aer vakuo</k> air-vacuum, -hole; <k>latrin vakuigo</k> 
emptying of cess-pools or water-closets; <k>vakuigar botelo</k> to empty a bottle; <k>la botelo vakueskas 
 lente</k> the bottle becomes slowly empty. Ant.: <k>plena</k>.

<k>valo</k> vale, valley, dale; (cf. <k>advale</k>); <k>valeto</k> small valley, dell; <k>tra monti e 
 vali</k> up hill and down dale; <k>valo lakrimoza</k> (<ex>fig.</ex>) vale of tears.

<k>valida</k> (<ex>jur.</ex>) valid: having legal force, good; <k>valideso</k> validity; healthfulness; <k>validigar</k> 
to validate; <k>valida mariajo</k> a legal marriage; <k>ne validigar</k> to invalidate.

<k>valorar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to be worth, be equal to in value, be as good as; be fit, be useful or good 
(for something); (<ex>of laws</ex>) to be in force; <k>valorigar</k> to make (<k>ulo</k>) of worth, of value, make 
useful for; <k>valoro</k> value, worth; <k>valoranta</k> worth; <k>valoroza</k> valuable; <k>valorajo</k> valuable object; 
<k>valorpaperi</k> (<ex>com.</ex>) valuable papers: stocks, securities, etc.; <k>valorigar lego</k> to put a law in 
force; <k>sen valorigar</k> to deprive (<k>ulo</k>) of value, to demonetize (money); <k>sen valora</k> valueless; 
<k>min valorigar</k>, <k>valoreskar</k> to depreciate; <k>pen valorar</k> to be worth the trouble, be worth while; 
<k>plu valoro</k> superior, increased value; <k>min valoro</k> less, inferior value; <k>ica stofo valoras kin 
 franki po metro</k> this fabric is worth five francs a meter; <k>to valoras nulo</k> that is good for, 
worth nothing; <k>valorar sua pezo de oro</k> to be worth its weight in gold; <k>quante co valoras</k> how much is 
this worth; <k>ica medikamento valoras kontre febro</k> this medicine is good for fever; <k>ica plumo 
 neplus valoras por skribar</k> this pen is no longer fit to write with; <k>to valoras la peno</k> 
(od, <k>penvaloras</k>) <k>askoltar</k> that worth listening to; <k>valorigar sua talento</k> to turn one's 
talent to account.

<k>vana</k> vain: fruitless, ieffectual; (cf. <k>vanitatoza</k>, <k>frivola</k>); <k>vane</k> in vain, to no purpose; 
no use! <k>vaneso</k> vanity (N.B. not of person), emptiness, vainness (of a project, etc.); <k>vanigar</k> to 
thwart, baffle, foil; <k>vanajo</k> a v. act, wish. Def.: Sen-efikiva; sen-rezulta; sen reala fundmaneto. Ex.: 
Vana esforci, esperi. Vaneso di homala grandaji. Vaneso di la vanaji, omno esas vanajo.

<k>vango</k> (<ex>anat. and fig.</ex>) cheek; <k>vangoza</k> chubby: full cheeked; <k>vangegi</k>, <k>vangosako</k> jowls; 
cheek-pouch (of certain monkeys); <k>vangobarbo</k> whisker(s); <k>vangofrapar</k>, <k>vangbatar</k> to slap, cuff, 
strike (<k>ulu</k>) on the face.

<k>vanitato</k> vanity, self-conceit; <k>vanitatoza</k>, <k>vanitatoz(ul)o</k> self-admiring, vain (person). Ex.: Lua 
vanitato esas netolerabla. V. exp.: vid. <k>superba</k>. Ant.: <k>modesteso</k>.

<k>vaporo</k> steam (from boiling water); vapor (from liquids or fluid floating in the atmosphere); 
(<ex>of wine</ex>) fume (affecting the head); <k>vaporoza</k>, <k>vaporatra</k> vapor-ous, ish; <k>vaporigar</k> to vaporize, 
volatalize; <k>vaporeskar</k> to evaporate; turn into vapor; <k>vaporigilo</k> evaporating machine; <k>vaporagar</k> 
(<ex>tr.</ex>) to steam (<k>ulo</k>), give a steam bath to; <k>vaporbalno</k> vapor-, steam-bath; <k>vapormashino</k> 
steam engine; <k>vapornavo</k> steam boat; <k>incens vaporo</k> cloud of incense; <k>arseno vapori</k> fumes 
of arsenic.

<k>varo</k>, <k>vari</k> ware(s), commodit-y, -ies; merchandize (cf. <k>komercajo</k>). Def.: Kozo vendebla, 
granda o mikra; II-76.

<k>vari(ad)ar</k> (<ex>tr., intr.</ex>) to vary, change; (cf. <k>chanjar</k>, <k>diversigar</k>); <k>variigar</k> 
to cause (<k>ulo</k>) to vary; <k>varianta</k>, <k>variiva</k>, <k>variebla</k>, <k>variema</k> variable, versatile, unsteady, fickle, 
flighty; <k>varianto</k> a variant (reading, interpretation, spelling. etc.); <k>variebleso; variemeso</k> 
variableness; variability; versatility; <k>variar la frazo</k> to say the same things in other words. 
Ex.: Mori varias segun la nacioni. La vetero varias perpetue. V. exp.: Chanjar ne esas exakta sinonimo 
di variar: variar esas chanjar segun quanteso od inteseso; III-103.

<k>variolo</k> (<ex>med.</ex>) variola: smallpox; <k>variolala</k> variolous: relating to v.; <k>varioliko</k>, <k>variolika</k> 
(person) suffering from v.; <k>variolmarkizita</k> pock-marked.

<k>varma</k> (<ex>also fig.</ex>) warm; <k>varmega</k> hot; <k>varmeta</k> tepid, lukewarm; <k>varmeskar</k> 
to get warm; <k>varmigar</k> to heat, warm; <k>varmig(ad)o</k> heating; <k>varmigilo</k> heating apparatus; 
<k>ped</k>, <k>lit</k>, <k>pladvarmigilo</k> foot-, bed-, plate-warmer. Ant.: <k>kolda.</k>

<k>varsar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to pour (out) (as liquids); to spill (accidentally); shed (blood); to empty 
(solid things); <k>varsero</k> (<ex>astron.</ex>) Aquarius. V. exp.: vid. <k>rakar</k>.

<k>vartar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to await, wait for (<k>ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>); <k>vartigar</k> to keep (<k>ulu</k>) 
waiting; <k>vartanta</k> waiting, expectant; <k>vartante</k> while waiting, in the interim (cf. <k>dume</k>); 
<k>varteyo</k> waiting-place, -room. Def.: Restar en la ula loko o stando, til ke ulo eventas; III-423. 
Ex.: Me vartas nepaciente la decido. V. exp.: vid. <k>expektar</k>.

<k>vaskulo</k> (<ex>anat., biol.</ex>) blood vessel, tube, canal; <k>vaskulala</k>, <k>vaskuloza</k> vascular; <k>vaskularo</k> 
vascular system.

<k>vasta</k> vast, extensive (in all directions); <k>vasteso</k> vastness, vast extent, spaciousness; 
<k>pluvastigar</k> to spread (<k>ulo</k>), to make more extensive. Def.: Granda segun omna sua 
dimensioni; III-42. Ex.: Vasta agro esas agro same longa e larja; vasta salono esas salono same 
proporcione longa, larja ed alta. Figurale, on pluvastigas ula ideo od opiniono (donar ad ol plu 
granda areo). Vasta eruditeso.

<k>vato</k> wadding, padding: soft stuff of loose texture; prepared sheets of carded cotton (as used 
to thicken dresses, quilts, etc.); <k>vatizar</k> to wad, pad, stuff (with wadding).

<k>vaxo</k> wax (of any kind, nat. or artific.); <k>vaxizar</k> to (smear, rub with) wax; <k>vaxotelo</k> 
oil-cloth; <k>siglo vaxo</k> sealing w.; <k>modlo vaxo</k> modeling w.; <k>parquet vaxo</k> 
floor w.

<k>vazo</k> vessel (for holding liquids); vase (as for flowers, etc.); <k>vazaro arjenta</k> silver 
service; <k>stana vazo</k> tin-pot, -vessel.

<k>vehar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to go about in any sort of vehicle: ride, drive, sail; <k>vehigar</k> to 
convey, carry, cart, transport (in a vehicle); <k>veh(ad)o</k> riding, driving, sailing; <k>vehilo</k> 
vehicle: any means of transport by land, air or water; (<ex>fig.</ex>) any means of transmitting; 
(<ex>med.</ex>) excipient; menstruum; <k>aero esas vehilo di sono</k> air is v. of sound; <k>imprimarto 
 esas vehilo por instrukto</k> the art of printing is a v. of instruction.

<k>veino</k> (<ex>anat., also of marble, wood</ex>) vein; (<ex>geol., min.</ex>) vein, seam; <k>veinala</k> 
venous: relating to v.s; <k>veinizita</k> marked with v.s; <k>veinaro</k> venous system; <k>veinizar</k> 
to v.: mark wit v.s; <k>veinoseko</k> phlebotomy.

<k>vejet(ad)ar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to vegetate: grow as or like a plant; (<ex>fig.</ex>) to lead a dull 
life; <k>vejet(ad)o</k> vegetating; <k>vejetala</k> vegetable; <k>vejetanta</k> (<ex>of persons</ex>) vegetating; 
<k>vejetiva</k> vegetative; <k>vejetantaro</k> vegetation; <k>vejetanto</k>, <k>vejetivo</k> vegetable, plant (cf. 
<k>legumo</k>).

<k>vejetarar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to be a vegetarian; <k>vejetaro</k>, <k>vejetarismo</k> vegetarianism; <k>vejetaranto</k>, <k>vejetarano</k> 
vegetarian.

<k>vekar</k> (<ex>intr., also fig.</ex>) to awaken, wake up; <k>vekigar</k> to wake, rouse (<k>ulu</k>); 
<k>veko</k>, <k>vekigo</k> awakening; <k>vekigilo</k> alarm.
<k>vekto</k> beam (of scales); <k>tiro vekto</k> swingle-tree, -bar (of a carriage).

<k>velo</k> veil; a piece of stuff used to conceal something; (<ex>fig.</ex>) cover, screen, shade; 
<k>veleto</k> small v.; lady's v.; <k>velego</k> awning; <k>velizar</k> to veil; cover, hide; <k>velo 
 gaza</k> gauze v.; <k>nubo velo</k> v. of clouds; <k>palat velo</k> (<ex>anat.</ex>) velum. Ex.: Eskartar, 
levar la vel(et)o de la vizajo. La velo di la templo. La veli (E. <ex>shades</ex>) di la nokto. La nubi 
velizas la suno.

<k>velkar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to fade away, wither, lose freshness; (of flowers) to droop; <k>velkigar</k> 
to cause (<k>ulo</k>) to wither. Ex.: La suno velkigis la folii di la planti.
<k>veluro</k> velvet; <k>velura</k> made of v.; <k>veluratrajo</k> imitation v.; velous.

<k>venar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to come (<k>ad</k>, <k>de</k>); <k>parvear</k> to arrive; <k>parveninto</k> 
an arrival.

<k>vendar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to sell; <k>vendo</k>, <k>vendado</k> sale, selling; <k>vendeyo</k>, <k>venderio</k> shop, store; 
<k>vendanto</k>, <k>vendinto</k>, <k>vendisto</k> dealer, vendor; <k>vendebla</k> vendible, salable, marketable; <k>vendotable</k> 
shop counter; <k>vendkontrato</k> bargain (written). Ant.: <k>komprar</k>.

<k>veneno</k> (<ex>also fig.</ex>) venom, poison; <k>venena</k>, <k>venenoza</k> venomous, poisonous; (<ex>fig.</ex>) 
malignant; <k>venenagar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to poison (<k>ulu</k>); <k>venenizar</k> to put poison on (<k>ulo</k>); 
<k>rat veneno</k> rat poison.

<k>venerala</k> venereal (relating to the disease); <k>veneriko</k>, <k>venerika</k> (<ex>person</ex>) afflicted with 
v. disease; <k>venerala monto</k> (<ex>anat.</ex>) pubes, mons veneris.

<k>veneracar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to venerate, reverence; <k>veneracinda</k> venerable; <k>veneracema</k> reverent. 
Def.: Veneraco: projunda respekto religioza o religiatra; III-328.
<k>veniala</k> venial: that may be forgiven; excusable; <k>veniala peko</k> v. sin.

<k>venjar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to avenge, revenge; <k>venjar su</k> to revenge oneself (<k>su</k>, <k>ulu</k>, <k>kontre 
 ulu</k>, <k>pri ulo</k>); <k>venjo</k> revenge, vengeance; <k>venjema</k> revengeful, vindicative; <k>venjemeso</k> 
vindictiveness; <k>venjanto</k>, <k>venjero</k> avenger. V. exp.: Venjar ulu esas punisar, pro rankoro, altru qua 
facis domajo od ofenso ad «ulu». Venjar esas tranzitiva; on povaos venjar <k>su</k> od altru; 
on povas anke venjar <k>ulo</k> (ex. l’ocido di sua patro). Pluse la venjo aplikesas, ne nur al 
autoro di la domajo od ofeso, ma anke a lua familio o havajo. Exemple, en Korsika, la venjo (<k>vendetta</k>) 
praktikesas inter du familii: se A ocidis B, la filio di B ocidas A; pose la filo di A ocidas la filio 
di B, . . . e tale senfine, o ti la destrukto di la du familii; VI-143; kp. <k>revanchar</k>, <k>reprezalar</k>.

<k>ventar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to blow, be windy; <k>ventas</k> (<ex>impers.</ex>) it is windy, the wind 
is blowing, there is a (high) wind; <k>vento</k> wind; <k>ventego</k> strong wind, gale; <k>ventstroko</k> 
squall, gust of wind; <k>ventoza</k> windy; <k>ventizar</k> to give wind to; <k>ventizilo</k> fan or fan-like 
instrument; <k>para vento</k> w. screen; <k>ventomuelilo</k> w. mill; <k>ventoflecho</k>, <k>ventflago</k> weathervane; 
<k>ventorozo</k> (<ex>nav.</ex>) compass card.

<k>ventro</k> belly, paunch, stomach; (<ex>of bottles, etc.</ex>) belly, body; (cf. <k>abdomeno</k>, <k>stomako</k>); <k>ventrala</k> ventral: relating to the b.; <k>ventroza</k> paunchy, big bellied; <k>ventredo</k> 
bellyful; <k>ventrzono</k> b. band; girth (of a horse); <k>ventrdoloro</k> b. ache.

<k>vera</k> true, veritable; (cf. <k>reala</k>, <k>autentika</k>); <k>vereso</k> (quality) truth; <k>verajo</k> 
a truth; <k>la vera</k> (abstract) the truth; <k>vere</k> verily, truly (cf. <k>advere</k>); 
<k>versimila</k> likely, plausible, true seeming; <k>versimilajo</k>, <k>vereso</k> likelihood, versimilitude 
(cf. <k>probablajo</k>); <k>versemblanta</k> ostensible, apparent; <k>versembleso</k> speciousness; 
<k>verigar</k> to make (<k>ulo</k>) true; (<ex>math.</ex>) to prove; <k>neverajo</k>, <k>vereso</k> falsehood, 
falseness. Ex.: Vera diamanto. Vu ne dicas la verajo. Esas nula vereso en to quon vu dicas. Matematikala 
verajo. Fato vere tragediala. Ulfoye la verso povas semblar tre neversimila. La deskovro di lo vera ofte 
dependas de la komparo di versimilaji. Lu esas verdicanta homo. La verdicemeso di historiisto.

<k>verda</k> (<ex>color</ex>) green, verdant; <k>verdeso</k> green(ness); <k>verdajo</k> a g. object; verdure; 
(<ex>pl., fig.</ex>) salad-herbs, pot-herbs; <k>verdigar</k>, <k>verdizar</k> to make, cover with, g.; <k>verdeskar</k> 
to turn g.
<k>verdikto</k> (<ex>jur.</ex>) verdict; finding; <k>facar verdikto</k> to render a v.

<k>vergo</k> rod, wand; ferule or birch (used for punishment); <k>vergeto</k> small rod, switch; <k>vergagar</k> 
(<ex>tr.</ex>) to flog (with a birch), to cane; <k>vergomarko</k> mark of a rod. Ex.: La vergo di Moses, 
di magiisto. Frapar ulu per vergeto.

<k>verifikar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to verify (by examination), to confirm; to try, test (weights and measures); 
to audit; to prove (a will); <k>verifik(ad)o</k> verification, examining, auditing; (of wills) probate; 
<k>verifikisto</k>, <k>verifikero</k> verifier, inspector, auditor. Def.: Kontrolar l’exakteso, justeso di kalkulo, di 
mezuro o mezurilo; III-203. Ex.: L’evento verifikas lua predico. Verifikar aserto, signaturo.

<k>verjuso</k> verjuice: the sour juice of unripe or green fruits; (<ex>fig.</ex>) acid liquor. V. exp.: 
Dicesas metafore pri vino tro yuna od acida; IV-646.

<k>verko</k> (<ex>lit., artist., moral, social</ex>) work; <k>verketo</k> essay, pamphlet; small deed; 
<k>verkaro</k> literature (= books in general; cf. <k>literaturo</k>); <k>verkaro ciencala</k> scientific 
works (books). Ex.: Verki da Molière. La merito di bona verki. On opinionis ne vivar vane quankam 
lua verki apene lasas traci.

<k>vermo</k> worm: any small creeping animal; maggot, grub Z(cf. <k>larvo</k>, <k>lombriko</k>, <k>silkoraupo</k>, <k>tenio</k>); <k>vermoza</k> wormy; <k>vermorodita</k> w. eaten; <k>vermoforma</k> w. shaped; (<ex>anat.</ex>) 
vermiform; <k>vermetoza</k> (<ex>arch.</ex>) vermicular.

<k>vers</k> (<ex>prep., physical sense</ex>) toward(s): in the direction of (cf. <k>ad</k>); <k>vers 
 la nordo</k> t. the north; <k>levar la manui vers la cielo</k> to hold up the hands to heaven; <k>lu 
 turnis sua kapo vers me</k> he turned hes head toward me. Def.: Directiono en la spaco; VI-144.

<k>verso</k> verse (in poetry; also of Bible); <k>versajo</k>, <k>versaro</k> a piece of poetry, verse(s), poem; 
<k>verso senrima</k> blank v.; <k>versifar</k> to write v.; <k>versigar</k> to versify (<k>ulo</k>).

<k>versiono</k> version: manner of relating a fact (cf. <k>tradukuro</k>). Ex.: Existas plura versioni 
pri l’acidento.

<k>vertebro</k> vertebra: joint or bone of spine; <k>vertebrala kolono</k> vertebral column; <k>vertebroza</k>, <k>vertebrozo</k> 
vertebrate animal; <k>sen vertebra</k>, <k>vertebro</k> invertebrate (animal).

<k>vertijar</k>, <k>vertijeskar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to be dizzy, have a swimming, whirling sensation; (cf. <k>aturdar</k>); 
<k>vertijo</k> vertigo, dizziness, giddiness; <k>vertijanta</k> dizzy (sensation, head); (<ex>med.</ex>) vertiginous; 
<k>vertijigiva</k>, <k>vertijiganta</k> causing dizziness (heights, etc.).

<k>vertikala</k> vertical, perpendicular, plumb; <k>vertikalo</k> v. line; <k>vertikaleso</k> verticalness (cf. 
<k>perpendikleso</k>).

<k>vertuo</k> vrtue; (cf. <k>chasteso</k>); <k>vertuoza</k> virtuous; <k>esar vertuoza pro neceseso</k> 
to make a virtue of necessity. Def.: Etikala tendenco facar lo bona ed evitar lo mala. Ex.: Vertui 
kardinala. Vertuoza homo, ago. Ant.: <k>vicio</k>.

<k>vervo</k> verve: animation, spirit, go; <k>vervoza</k> animated, spirited, racy; <k>vervoza stilo</k> 
animated style; <k>vervo poeziala</k> poetic spirit. Def.: Ardoro di imaginado, di la spirito, qua anmizas 
la poeto, l’oratoro, la konversanto, e.c. V. exp.: vid. <k>entuziasmo</k>.

<k>vespero</k> evening; <k>vesperala</k> evening, vesper (star, prayer, etc.); <k>vespere</k> in the evening; 
<k>vesperfesto</k>, <k>vesperkunveno</k> evening party, soiree; <k>ca vespere</k> this evening; <k>pasar la vespero</k> to 
spend the e.; <k>dicar</k> (od, <k>dezirar</k>) <k>bon vespero</k> (<k>ad ulu</k>): to say good e.

<k>vesto</k> garment: article of clothing, vestment; <k>vestaro</k> clothes, attire, dress, toilet, 
garb, habiliment; raiment, wearing apparel; <k>vesteyo</k>, <k>vestizeyo</k> dressing-place, -room; <k>vestizar</k> 
to clothe, dress, array (<k>ulu</k>, <k>per ulo</k>) (cf. <k>metar</k>); <k>vestizita</k> dressed, clad; <k>vestizachar</k> 
to rig out in, bedizen (ridiculously); <k>vestodono regulierala</k> taking the habit or veil (friars 
or nuns); <k>vestovendisto</k> clothier; <k>sub vesto</k> undergarment; <k>trauro vesto</k> mourning 
garment.
<k>vestio</k> round jackets (without tails, as for waiters, fencing, etc.).
<k>vestibulo</k> vestibule: front hall of an edifice, anteroom, lobby.
<k>vetar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to veto, negative (<k>ulo</k>); <k>vetoyuro</k> right of veto.
<k>veterano</k> veteran: old soldier; (<ex>fig.</ex>) any one of long practice.
<k>vetrino</k> glass case (for showing objects, as in museums, shops, etc.), show-case.

<k>veturo</k> vehicle (serving to transport persons or merchandise, carriage, wagon, conveyance; 
<k>veturirar</k> (od, <k>veturvehar</k>)<k /> to go, travel, drive in a v.; <k>veturagar</k>, <k>veturtransportar</k> 
to carry in vehicle (cf. <k>vehigar</k>); <k>veturedo</k> wagonful; <k>quarrota veturo</k> four wheeled v.; 
<k>manu</k>, <k>hom veturo</k> hand-cart; <k>lokac veturo</k> v. for hire, fly.

<k>vexar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to vex, provoke, irritate; (cf. <k>despitar</k>, <k>molestar</k>); <k>vexetar</k> 
to tease, plague, tantalize; <k>vexetema</k> teasing (person); <k>la deskomforto jenas me; me esas 
 vexata pro to</k> the inconvenience annoys me; I am vexed because of it; <k>la pueruli vexetas la 
 puerini</k> the boys tease the girls.

<k>veziko</k> (<ex>anat., zool.</ex>) bladder; <k>veziketo</k> small b.; (of skin) vesicle; <k>vezikigar</k> 
to vesicate: blister; <k>vezikigiva</k> vesicatory.

<k>viatiko</k> money or provisions given for a journey; (<ex>R.C. rel.</ex>) viaticum, last sacrament. 
V. exp.: La primitiva senco esas voyajo-subvenciono, de qua venas la religiala senco; IV-646.

<k>vibr(ad)ar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to vibrate. Ex.: Vibrado di la violin-kordi, di la aero, di 
pendulo.

<k>vice()</k> (<ex>prep. and prefix</ex>) vice, instead of; <k>vice( ke</k> (<ex>conj.</ex>) instead that. 
Ex.: Vice Iphigenia cervino sakrifikesis ad Artemis. Vice laborar, vu dormis..

<k>vicero</k> (<ex>anat.</ex>) viscus; <k>viceri</k>, <k>viceraro</k> viscera; <k>vicerala</k> visceral. V. exp.: <k>Vicero</k> 
havas senco diferanta de <k>intestino</k>, e plu vasta: ex. la kordio esas vicero; IV-81.

<k>vicio</k> vice: fault of character (cf. <k>defekto</k>, <k>manko</k>); <k>viciozeso</k> viciousness, depravity; 
<k>vicioza</k> vicious (cf. <k>perversa</k>); <k>vicioza cirklo</k> (<ex>fig.</ex>) vicious circle; <k>viciizar</k> 
to vitiate: taint, contaminate; to sully (the character of); (<ex>jur.</ex>) to render defective or void. 
Ex.: Ebriemeso esas vicio. Vici-zar legal akto. Ant.: <k>vertuo</k>.

<k>vicina</k> (<ex>esp. of people</ex>) neighboring, bordering, contiguous, adjacent (cf. <k>proxima</k>, <k>apuda</k>, <k>kontigua</k>); <k>vicin(ul)o</k> neighbor; <k>vicinaro</k> neighborhood: neighbors; <k>vicineso</k> 
(<ex>state</ex>) neighborhood: nearness, vicinity (of); <k>vicinajo</k> vicinity: (place); something neighboring 
(cf. <k>cirkumajo</k>); <k>vicinesar</k> to be contiguous.

<k>vidar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to see; <k>vidigar</k> (<k>ulo da ulu</k>)<k /> to cause someone to see 
something; <k>vid(ad)o</k> sight, vision: act of seeing; <k>vidajo</k> what is seen, a sight, a view; 
<k>videyo</k> (locality) viewpoint; <k>vidpunto</k> (mental) viewpoint, point of view; <k>vidala</k> visual; 
<k>videbla</k> visible, apparent (cf. <k>aparanta</k>, <k>semblanta</k>); <k>vidinda</k> worth seeing; <k>vidindajo</k> 
something worth seeing; <k>videnda</k> what ought or must be seen; <k>vidorgano</k> organ of vision; 
<k>mi vidar</k> to catch a glimpse of, see imperfectly; <k>inter vido</k> interview: meeting for conference. 
Ex.: La lasis me vidar nulo, ma lu vidis omno vidinda. Konocar ulu per la vido. Pagebla ye vido. V. exp.: 
vid. <k>regardar</k>.

<k>vidva</k> widowed; <k>vidvulo</k> widower; <k>vidvino</k> widow; <k>vidveso</k> widowhood; <k>vidveskar</k> 
to become a widow(er).

<k>vielo</k> vielle: a stringed instrument played upon with a wheel; (cf. <k>turnorgeno</k>). Def.: 
Instrumento muzkala kun kordi, quan on pleas per manivelo e klavi.

<k>vigilar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to abstain from sleep; to watch; to sit up; (cf. <k>vekar</k>); <k>vigil(ad)o</k> 
vigil: being awake; on the alert; watching; (<ex>act.</ex>) vigilance; <k>vigilanta</k> wide-awake, vigilant (act); 
<k>vigilema</k> (<ex>tendency</ex>) watchful, vigilant; <k>vigilemeso</k> vigilance; <k>vigilanto</k>, <k>vigilero</k>, <k>vigilisto</k> 
watcher; <k>armo vigilo</k> armed watch; <k>vigilar por malado</k> to sit up for (with) a sick person; <k>vigilar til 
 jorno (lumo)</k> to sit up, stay up, keep awake until daylight; <k>vigilanta patrulo di la familio</k> 
a watchful father fo the family; <k>vigilanta sorgo</k> vigilant care.

<k>vigilio</k> vigil; eve of a feast pf R.C. church. V. exp.: La dio ante la dio, quan on konsideras. 
Necesa ed internaciona en la religial uzo; IV-646.

<k>vigoro</k> vigor; <k>vigoroza</k>, <k>vigoroze</k> vigorous (ly). Ex.: Vigoro di yuneso, di la mento. Agar 
vigoroze.

<k>vikario</k> vicar: substitue in office; curate; <k>vikarieso</k> vicariate; curacy; <k>la vikario di Iesu 
 Kristo</k> the v. of Jesus Christ, the pope; <k>grand vikario</k> (od, <k>vikariogeneralo</k>)<k /> 
v. general.

<k>viktimo</k> victim: person or animal sacrificed; (<ex>fig.</ex>) sufferer, dupe; <k>viktimigar</k> to 
victimize (<k>ulu</k>); <k>viktimohoma</k> human v.
<k>viktualio</k> victuals, provisions; (<ex>nav.</ex>) stores. Def.: Provizuri por manjar; IV-646.
<k>vilo</k> (<ex>bot., anat.</ex>) villosity: coating of hairs; <k>viloza</k> villous; (cf. <k>vilozito</k>).
<k>vilanelo</k> villanelle: a kind of rustic ballad or dance.

<k>vildo</k> (wild) game; <k>vildoza</k> full of g.; <k>vildizar</k> to stock with g.: <k>vildchasar</k>, <k>vildkaptar</k> 
to hunt; <k>vildkaptisto</k>, <k>vendisto</k> fowler, sportsman; dealer in g.; <k>vildokarno</k> flesh of g.; 
<k>vildosako</k> g. bag; <k>plum vildo</k> feathered g.; wild fowl.
<k>vilejar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to rusticate; <k>vilej(ad)o</k> sojourn in the country.

<k>vino</k> wine; <k>vinala</k>, <k>vinoza</k>, <k>vinatra</k> vinous; <k>vinea</k> w. colored; <k>vinifado</k> vnification, 
w. making; <k>vinvendeyo</k>, <k>vinerio</k> w. shop; <k>vino nefermentacinta</k> unfermented w., sweet w.; <k>vino 
 sensukra</k> dry w.

<k>vinagro</k> vinegar; <k>vinagrifar</k> to make v.; <k>vinagrizar</k> to put v. on; <k>vinagruyo</k> v. cruet; 
-holder.
<k>vindar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to reel up; to wind or hoist (as with a windlass; cf. <k>spular</k>, <k>hisar</k>, <k>envolvar</k>); <k>vindilo</k> windlass, winch.

<k>vinkar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to overcome, vanquish, conquer, master, defeat, get the bette of; (<ex>intr.</ex>) 
to win; be victorious; <k>vinko</k> victory; <k>vinkanto</k>, <k>vinkero</k> conquerer, victor; <k>vinkanta</k>, <k>vinkema</k>, <k>vinkoza</k> 
victorious; <k>vinkala kanto</k> song of vicory.
<k>vintro</k> winter; <k>vintrala</k> windtry; <k>vintre</k> in w.; <k>en meza vintro</k> in the depth of w.
<k>vinyeto</k> (engraved) vignette (of books, papers); <k>vinyetoza papero</k> paper with ornamented borders.

<k>violo</k> (<ex>bot.</ex>) violet; <k>violea</k>, <k>violkolora</k> v. colored, purple; <k>violatra</k> v. like; 
purplish.

<k>violacar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to violate: to infringe, transgress, break a law, one’s oath); 
to ravish, rape (a female); <k>violaco</k> rape; violation; <k>violacante la reguli</k> in violation of the 
rules.

<k>violentar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to violate: do or use violence to, to ill use, force (<k>ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>); <k>violent(ad)o</k> 
violating, violence; (<ex>jur.</ex>) force; <k>violentala morto</k> violent death; <k>violentoza</k>, <k>violentema</k> violent: 
(persons, winds, passions, etc.); <k>violentesar</k> to suffer violence (<k>da</k>). Ex.: Violentar la koncienco.

<k>violino</k> violin, fiddle; <k>violinplear</k> to play the v.; <k>violinagar</k> to play (<k>ulo</k>) on 
the v.; <k>violin(ple)ero</k>, <k>violinisto</k> v. player.

<k>vipero</k> viper: venemous reptile, as adder; (<ex>fig.</ex>) malignant person; <k>viperala</k>, <k>viperatra</k> 
viperine; <k>viperlango</k> (<ex>fig.</ex>) an evil tongue.

<k>viro</k> a (grown) man, a manly person: male adult possessing masculine qualities, as a soldier, 
etc.; <k>virala</k>, <k>viratra</k> virile, manly (of voice, sexual organs, etc.); <k>vireso</k> virility, manliness, 
manhood, man's estate, vigor; <k>viraro</k> crew (of a ship), squad of men, etc.; <k>viratra muliero</k> 
virago; <k>virizar</k> to man, provide men for.

<k>virga</k> virgin(al: entirely chaste, also in fig. sense; <k>virga tero</k> v. soil; <k>virga foresto</k> 
untrodden forest; <k>virga metalo</k> native, v. metal; <k>virgulo</k> a chaste man or male; <k>virgino</k> 
virgin; <k>virgala</k>, <k>virginala</k> virginal, maidenly; <k>virgeso</k>, <k>virgineso</k> virginity, maidenhood.

<k>virtuala</k> (<ex>philos., opt., mechan.</ex>) virtual, potental; <k>virtuale</k> virtually; <k>virtualeso</k>, <k>virtualajo</k> 
virtuality, potentiality; <k>virtuala rapideso</k> v. velocity; <k>virtuala foko</k> v. focus. Def.: Qua esas 
en potencialo, ma ne en efekto aktuala. Ex.: Armeo virtuale vinkita.

<k>virtuoza</k> (<ex>highly</ex>) skilled, artistic, masterly; <k>virtuoz(ul)o</k> virtuoso; <k>virtuozeso</k> virtuosity, 
virtuosoship: professional or consummate skill, artistic perfection, masterly style or play.

<k>visar</k> (<ex>tr., intr.</ex>) to screw in: turn in a screw; <k>vis(ad)o</k> screwing (of screws); <k>visilo</k> 
screw-driver; <k>visilo ajustebla</k> a spanner, stillson or monkey wrench. V. exp.: On <k>visas</k> skrubi. 
On <k>skrubagas</k>, <k>skrubligas</k> ulo, quale kesto, buxo, e.c.

<k>vishar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to wipe (off), wipe dry by rubbing; (cf. <k>sikigar</k>); <k>manu vishilo</k> 
towel; <k>plum ilo</k> pen-wiper.

<k>vistar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to visé: to endorse, countersign; <k>visto</k> visé: official signature. Def.: 
Oficale signatar o autentikigar dokumento od akto. Ex.: La visto di konsulo sur pasporto.

<k>vito</k> (<ex>bot.</ex>) vine; <k>viteyo</k>, <k>vitagro</k> vineyard; <k>vitfolio</k> leaf of the v.; <k>vitkultivado</k> 
v. culture; (<ex>fig.</ex>) wine-growing; <k>vitbero</k> grape; <k>sika vitbero</k> raisin; <k>vitograpo</k> 
bunch of grapes; <k>vitrekoltar</k> to gather the vintage; <k>vito Virginiana</k> Virginia creeper.

<k>vitro</k> (<ex>the material</ex>) glass; <k>vitra</k> (made of) g.; <k>vitrala</k>, <k>vitratra</k> glass, vitreous; <k>vitrizar</k> 
to furnish or cover (<k>ulo</k>) with g. (windows, etc.); <k>vitrizisto</k> glazier (cf. <k>glezar</k>); 
<k>vitrigar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>), <k>vitreskar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>)<k /> to vitrify; <k>vitrifar</k> to make g.; 
<k>vitriferio</k> g. works; <k>vitrifisto</k> g. maker; <k>vitrokarelo</k> pane (as of a window); <k>vitrotekto</k> 
g. roof; <k>vitropapero</k> sand-paper; <k>vitroparieto</k> g. partition; <k>vitroplako</k> plate g.; 
<k>vitrachajo</k>, <k>vitraji</k> glass trinkets, g. beads.

<k>vitralio (fenestro)</k>stained-glass window (as in churches). Def.: Vitro artala, kolorizita, 
dekoriva, qua klozas fenestro (quale en kelka kirki e laika edifici); IV-646.

<k>viulo</k> (<ex>mus.</ex>) viol; name for instruments of violin family; <k>bas viulo</k> bass-viol 
(cf. <k>violoncelo</k>). Def.: Anciena formo d grosa violino de qua developesis la moderna speci di 
violini).

<k>vivar</k> (<ex>intr., tr.</ex>) to live: be living, be alive (cf. <k>habitar</k>, <k>kondutar</k>); <k>vivo</k> 
life; <k>vivala</k> vital (cf. <k>esenca</k>, <k>nekareebla</k>); <k>vivanto</k> living person; <k>vivanta</k> 
alive, living; <k>vivoza</k>, <k>vivema</k> full of life, animated, lively, vivacious; <k>vivozeso</k> vitality; <k>vivemeso</k> 
vivacity (cf. <k>vivaca</k>); <k>vivetar</k>, <k>vivachar</k> to make shift to live, live from hand to mouth; <k>vivigar</k> 
to vivify, quicken, give life to, animate (cf. <k>anmizar</k>); <k>viviva</k>, <k>vivkapabla</k> likely to live, 
capable of living; <k>vivez! viv klamo</k> vive! long live! hurrah, cheer; <k>trans vivar</k> to survive: 
remain alive; <k>bonvivanto</k> bon-vivant, high-liver; <k>gaya vivanto</k> lively, good-humored 
person; <k>dumviva</k> (od, <k>vivduranta</k>) <k>rento</k> life annuity. Ex.: Fishi povas vivar 
nur en l’aquo. Lu vivas mizerosa vivo. Lasar ulu vivar. Vivar sua vivo. Qua vivos vidos. La tempo 
dum qua lu vivis. Vivar quale ermito. Dum la vivo di. Vivala povo, principo. Vivozeso di forta viro. Vivemeso 
di pueri. La mediko dicas, ke ica infanto esas viviva. La mento vivigas la korpo. Ant.: <k>mortar</k>.

<k>vivaca</k> lively, nimble, vivacious, sprightly, brisk; <k>vivaceso</k> vivacity: liveliness; <k>ta infanto esas tre vivaca</k> 
that child is very lively; <k>il vivacigas omno quon il agas</k> he puts life into whatever he does.
<k>vivdissekar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to vivisect: to dissect living beings.

<k>vizar</k> (<ex>tr., intr.</ex>) to aim at, to take aim (cf. <k>intencar</k>, <k>tendencar</k>, <k>ambiciar</k>); <k>vizo</k> 
aim: direction of the sight toward an object; <k>vizar (vers) ucelo</k> to aim at a bird; <k>vizograno</k> 
sight (of a gun); <k>vizlineo</k> line of aim.

<k>vizajo</k> visage: face of a person. Def.: L’avana parto di la homala kapo, konsiderata de 
extere ed en lua expresiveso; V-679.
<k>viziero</k> visor (of a helmet, a cap); <k>okul viziero</k> eye-shade (for the head).

<k>viziono</k> vision, apparition; <k>vizionera</k>, <k>vizionema; vizionero</k>, <k>emo</k> visionary (person). Ex.: Imaginar 
sua vizioni esar realaji. La vizioni di la profeti. Unesme la populo nomizis Columbus kom vizionero.

<k>vizitar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to visit, pay a v. to, call upon (<k>ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>); <k>vizitkarto</k> visiting 
card; <k>vizitfesto</k> (<ex>rel.</ex>) visitation.

<k>voco</k> (<ex>also gram.</ex>) voice; (<ex>fig.</ex>) expression of opinion; <k>voco alta</k>, <k>basa</k>, <k>klara</k>, <k>obskura</k>, <k>ruptosona</k> high, low clear, unclear, broken v.; <k>mi voce</k> in an undertone; <k>voce</k> 
by word of mouth; <k>voca voto</k> viva voce vote; <k>vocala</k> vocal, verbal, oral, uttered or relating 
to the v.; <k>vocokonduktilo</k> v. conductor (cf. <k>paroltubo</k>); <k>la voco publika</k> (<ex>fig.</ex>) 
public opinion; <k>la voco di koncienco</k> (<ex>fig.</ex>) the v. of conscience; <k>elektita per 7 voci 
 ek 12</k> elected by 7 out of 12 (viva voce) votes; <k>vocoreflektilo</k> sounding board (as for pulpit); 
<k>senvoceso</k> loss of voice, aphonia.

<k>(ad)vokar</k> (<ex>tr., intr., also fig.</ex>) to call (to) (<k>ulu</k>), ask to come, summons; <k>(ad)vokeso</k> 
vocation. Ex.: (Ad-)vokar la hundo per lua nomo. (Ad-)vokar la guardo. Vokar por helpo. Kun-vokar la 
rezervo-trupi a la militala servado. Vokar (a) Deo por helpo. Mea patrio esas en danjero, la honoro 
vokas. V. exp.: vid. <k>klamar</k>.
<k>vokalizar</k> (<ex>intr., tr., mus.</ex>) to vocalize: to sing a vowel sound without uttering words.

<k>volar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to will: determine in the mind, to decide, resolve, exercise volition (cf. <k>dezirar</k>, <k>voluntar</k>); <k>volo</k> (<ex>act</ex>) will, volition; <k>volado</k> (<k>faculty</k>) the will, volition; 
<k>voleto</k>, <k>volesko</k> low degree of will, fancy, mind, slight degree of inclination, caprice, humor; <k>volala</k> 
willful: relating to will; <k>volata</k>, <k>volita</k> willed, willful, intended, voluntary (cf. <k>voluntar</k>); 
<k>vole</k> willfully; -anta: voluntary: proceeding from free-will; <k>senvola</k> involuntary; <k>segunvola</k> 
optional; <k>segunvole</k> at pleasure, at will; <k>segunvola pafado</k> firing at will; <k>bon</k>, <k>mal volvolo</k> 
good, ill will; <k>me volas vidar il</k> I will (am determined) to see him; <k>me volas facar ol</k> 
I mean to (will) do it; <k>me ne volas</k> I won’t, I do not mean to; <k>volo neflexebla</k> 
inflexible will; <k>la reflexi esas nedependanta de la volado</k> the reflexes are independent of the 
will (volition); <k>me havas voleto refuzar</k> I have a mind to refuse; <k>volala</k>(od, <k>volanta</k>) 
<k>ago</k>, <k>movo</k> voluntary act, motion; <k>volita eroro</k> willful error.
<k>volatila</k> volatile; <k>volatileso</k> volatility. Def.: Vaporeskema ye l’ordinara temperaturo; IV-4.

<k>volkano</k> volcano; <k>volkanala</k>, <k>volkanatra</k> volcanic (stone, etc.); <k>volkanoza</k> volcanic: full of v.s; 
<k>volkano extingita</k> extinct v.
<k>voltar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to volt: make a sudden turn or leap aside (as in fencing); (cf. <k>voltijar</k>).

<k>voltijar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to vault (on a horse, on a slack rope, etc.); <k>voltij(ad)o</k> vaulting, 
leaping, tumbling; <k>voltijanto</k>, <k>voltijisto</k> leaper, vaulter, tumbler; <k>voltijero</k> (<ex>fig.</ex>) voltigeur: 
F. light-infantry soldier.

<k>voluntar</k> (<ex>tr., intr.</ex>) to be willing (to); to have no objection (to); (in polite phrases) 
to be so kind as, be pleased to; <k>volunto</k> willingness, good-will; <k>volunta</k>, <k>voluntala</k>, <k>voluntanta</k> voluntary, 
willingly; <k>voluntez</k> please; <k>volunte</k> gladly, readily, willingly. Ex.: Me voluntas facar to. Voluntez 
enirar, sioro. Voluntez dicar a me. Me akompanos vu tre volunte. On volunte (E. readily) kredas to quon 
on deziras kredar. V. exp.: <k>Voluntez</k> esas vicina a komplezez, degnez, ma min forta; VI-213. La 
tri vorti: <k>voluntar</k>, <k>komplezar</k>, <k>degnar</k> formacas gradaro: <k>komplezo</k> esas ulo plu kam volunto; 
<k>degno</k> esas komplezo o favoro di altranga persono; II-648.

<k>volupto</k> voluptuousness; <k>voluptoza</k> voluptuous (sensation, etc.); <k>voluptema</k>, <k>voluptemo</k> voluptuous 
(person). Def.: Granda plezuro sensala.

<k>(en)volvar</k> (<ex>tr.</ex>) to roll up, wrap around; to coil (a rope); <k>(enar su</k> to wrap up 
oneself; (cf. <k>spular</k>). Ex.: (En-)volvar standardo cirkum lua shafto. Volvar kordo cirkum la korpo. 
(En-)volvar peco de stofo. V. exp.: vid. <k>envelopar</k>.

<k>vomar</k>(<ex>tr., intr.</ex>) to vomit, throw up, belch out (wind, gas, etc.); <k>vomajo</k> vomit: 
what is thrown up; <k>vomigiva</k>, <k>vomigivo</k> vomitive, emetic. Ex.: Vomar sango. La volkano vomas flamo.
<k>vomiko*</k> (<ex>med.</ex>) vomica: abscess cavity in the lungs.
<k>vomiknuco</k> nux-vomica, vomic-nut; <k>vomiknuciero</k> n. v. tree (Strychnos Nux-vomica).

<k>vomitorio</k> (<ex>anc. arch.</ex>) vomitory. Def.: Arkeologiala termino: enireyo ed ekireyo en la 
teatri ed amfi-teatri; IV-647.

<k>vorto</k> (written, printed) word (cf. <k>parolo</k>); <k>vortaro</k> collection of words; vocabulary; 
<k>vortolibro</k> word-book, dictionary; <k>vortope</k>, <k>vortopa</k> verbatim, word for word, literal (translation); 
<k>vortifar</k> to build words; <k>vortif(ad)o</k> word building.

<k>vorticar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to whirl, rotate rapidly; <k>vortico</k> whirling, vortex; <k>aer vortico</k> 
whirlwind; <k>aquo vortico</k> whirlpool; <k>vortico di aferi</k> rush of business; <k>polvo vortico</k> 
cloud of dust.

<k>votar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to vote (either viva voce or by ballot) (<k>por</k>, <k>kontre</k>)<k /> (<ex>tr.</ex>) 
to v. for (<k>ulu</k>); to enact (<k>ulo</k>); <k>vot(ad)o</k> vote, voting; voice, suffrage, ballot; 
<k>votanto</k>, <k>votinto</k> voter; <k>votyuro</k> right to v.; <k>balotvoto</k> vote by (second) ballot; <k>listo voto</k> ballot by list; 
<k>votokonto</k> polling: count of votes; <k>voto per manui</k> show of hands; <k>votado universala</k> universal suffrage; 
<k>votar por lego</k> to vote for a law; <k>votar lego</k> to enact a law.

<k>vovar</k> (<ex>tr., intr.</ex>) to vow, make a v. (of); <k>vovo</k> vow; <k>vovajo</k> votive offering; 
<k>vovala</k> votive. Ex.: Vovar absteno. Vovar templo a deo.

<k>voyo</k> (<k>tera</k>, <k>fera</k>, <k>mara</k>) way, road; (<ex>R.R.</ex>) track, route; 
<k>voyeto</k> path(way), footpath; <k>voyego</k> broad road, highway; <k>voyifar</k> to make a road; 
<k>mi voyo (ye)</k> half-way; <k>lakto voyo</k> (<ex>astron.</ex>) Milky Way; <k>fer voyo</k> railroad; 
<k>kargoletro fervoyala</k> way-bill; <k>voyadministrado</k> administration of public ways; 
<k>voylaboristo</k> road worker.

<k>voyajar</k> (<ex>intr.</ex>) to travel; (by water) to voyage; <k>voyajeskar</k> to start on a journey; 
<k>voyajo</k> travel(ing); trip (cf. <k>turo</k>); <k>voyajado</k> frequent or continued travel; 
<k>voyajanta; voyajero</k> traveling, traveler, passenger; <k>voyajema; voyajemo</k> (person) fond of t.; itinerant, strolling; 
<k>voyajospensi</k> traveling expenses; <k>vivo voyajo</k> (<ex>fig.</ex>) life’s journey; 
<k>komerc voyajisto</k> commercial traveler; <k>voyajera kolombo</k> carrier pigeon. Ex.: Voyajar en Azia, 
de London a New York.

<k>vu (</k><ex>pl</ex>. <k>vi)</k> you; (for familiar usage cf. <k>tu</k>); <k>vua</k> (<ex>pl.</ex> <k>via</k> 
or <k>vui</k>)<k /> your(s), your own; <k>vua relati</k> your relations; <k>mea esas verda</k>, <k>vua 
 esas reda</k> mine is green, yours (<ex>pl.</ex>) are red; <k>ube esas la kamizi? Vui esas en l’armoro 
 e mei esas en la laveyo</k> where are the shirts? yours are in the press and mine are in the wash; 
<k>prenez elia manteli kun vii</k> take their cloaks with your own (<ex>pl.</ex>).

<k>vulgara</k> vulgar: used or done by the common run of people, common, popular, unrefined; (N.B. 
for low, coarse sense, cf. <k>grosiera</k>, <k>nepolita</k>, <k>malgusta</k>); (noun form = <k>populo</k>, <k>turbo</k>, <k>plebeyaro</k>); 
<k>vulgareso</k> (<ex>quality</ex>) vulgarism: commonness, unrefinedness (N.B. not «low» cf. <k>grosierajo</k>); 
<k>vulgarigar</k> to vulgarize: make popular; <k>vulgariganto</k>, <k>vulgarero</k> popularizer; <k>vulgara traduko di Biblo</k> 
vulgar version of the Bible (cf. <k>vulgato</k>); <k>vulgara parolado</k>, <k>opiniono</k>, <k>prejudiki</k> vulgar tongue, 
opinion, prejudices.
<k>vulgato</k> Vulgate: Latin version of the Bible.

<k>vulto</k> (<ex>arch.</ex>) vault; (cf. <k>masonita tombo</k>, <k>kelero</k>); <k>vultatra</k> v. like, archlike; 
<k>vultizar</k> to cover with a v.; <k>vultigar</k> to arch; <k>vultizita</k>, <k>vultigita</k> vaulted, arched.
<k>xenio*</k> satirical epigram (first introduced by Goethe and Schiller); (<ex>biol.</ex>) xenia.
<k>xilofaga</k>, <k>xilofago</k> xylophagous (insect, bivalve). Def.: Una de la multa speci de insekti, qui rodas la ligno; IV-647.
<k>xilografar</k> (<ex>tr., intr.</ex>) to engrave on wood or print from wood engravings.

<k>o(d)</k> (The «d» is omitted before
consonants) <ex>(conj.)</ex> or; <k>o(d) . . o(d)</k> either …
or; <k>il devos o submisar o demisar</k> he should either submit
or resign (cf. <k>sive</k>).

<k>obediar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to obey; <k>obediesar</k> to be
obeyed; <k>obedi(ad)o</k> obedience, obeying, observance (of a law,
command, etc.); <k>obediema</k> (tendency) obedient. Ex.: La soldato
obedias sua chefo.

<k>obeza</k> obese (cf. <k>korpulenta</k>, <k>repleta</k>); <k>obezeso</k>
obesity. Def.: Qua havas tro abunta graso, precipue en la ventro:
on qualifikas lu vulgare «ventroza». L’obezeso esas
maladeso e preske infirmeso; VI-601.

<k>objecionar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to object: adduce as an
objection. Ex.: On objecionis a Galileo ke, se la tero rotacas
…

<k>objekto</k> object: anything that comes within the
cognizance of the senses (cf. <k>skopo</k>, <k>komplemento</k>); <k>objektala</k>
objective (opp. to <k>subjektala</k>); <k>objektalo</k> <ex>(opt.)</ex>
object-glass; <k>objektaleso</k> objectivity.

<k>oblato</k> wafer. Def.: Dina tabuleto ek farinpasto (azimo)
uzata por siglar letri.

<k>obligar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to oblige: put (<k>ulu</k>) under
obligation to do or not to do something, to bind, constrain (by
duty, hono(u)r, etc.) (cf. <k>devar</k>, <k>koaktar</k>); <k>obligo</k>, <k>obligeso</k>
obligation (imposed by conscience, law, etc.); <k>obliganta</k>
obligatory (which obliges); <k>obligata</k> (which is) obligatory,
incumbent; <k>reciproka obligeso</k> joint liability, obligation; <k>neobligata</k>
optional; <k>obligesar ad ulu</k> to be beholden to someone; <k>obligar
 ulu per juro</k> to bind a person by oath; <k>me obligas me
 facar to</k> I assume the obligation, the responsibility to do
this.

<k>obligaciono</k> <ex>(fin.)</ex> debenture, bond: a legal
obligation (bond) bearing interest; <k>fervoyala obligacioni</k> railway
bonds; <k>obligacioniero</k>bond-, debenture-holder.

<k>obliqua</k> <ex>(also anat., gram.)</ex> oblique, aslant,
slanting; <ex>(fig.)</ex> indirect, not straightforward, insincere;
<k>obliqua angulo</k>, <k>lineo</k> oblique angle, line; <k>oblique tranchar
 stofo</k> to cut fabric slantingly, on the bias; <k>ta aleo esas
 obliqua</k> that lane runs slantingly; <ex>(gram.)</ex> -<k>a kazo</k>oblique
case; <ex>(fig.)</ex> -<k>a laudo</k> indirect praise; <k>obliqua
 homulo</k> an insincere (not straightforward) man.

<k>obliterar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to obliterate, blot out (little
by little or in a manner to leave traces). V. exp.: Nek <k>efacar</k>,
nek <k>nuligar</k>, ma nuligar per signo, qua igas ulo neuzebla
(ex. postal marko); IV-394. Ex.: La censuristo obliteris la
enskriburo.

<k>obliviar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to forget (cf. <k>neglijar</k>, <k>omisar</k>);
<k>obliviigar</k> to cause (<k>ulu</k>) to forget, to cause (<k>ulo</k>)
to be forgotten (<k>da</k> <k>ulu</k>); <k>oblivio</k> forgetting; <k>oblivieso</k>
forgetfulness, oblivion; <k>su oblivio</k> self-forgetfulness; <k>obliviema</k>
forgetful, oblivious, unmindful; <k>obliviokarcero</k> oubliette:
castle dungeon.
<k>oblonga</k> oblong. Def.: Qua esas plu longa kam larja.

<k>obolo</k> <ex>(Gr. coin)</ex> obol(us); any of several small
European coins; mite, groat, farthing; a very small sum; <k>obolo di
 vidvino</k> widow’s mite.

<k>obsedar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to beset: to haunt, importune; to
obsess, to worry; to possess (by fixed ideas); (cf. <k>persekutar</k>, <k>tedar</k>); <k>la kortani obsedas la princo</k> the courtiers
beset the prince; <k>la mento ofte obsedesas da sua propra erori</k>
the mind is often beset with its own errors; <k>ca viro obsedas
 me</k> that man worries me, or, importunes me. V. exp.: Obsedar
esas, etimologie, «siejar» persono, t.e. frequentar lu tedante
por solicitar lu pri ula kozo, o por vidar lu nediskrete;
figurale, to dicesas pri la pensi, imaji, pasioni qui okupas
konstante la mento, e quin on ne povas repulsar (la remorso
obsedas la kriminanto; teroriganta sonji obsedas lu); III-35.

<k>observar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to observe: look at, watch (with
attention and study); (cf. <k>obediar</k>, <k>remarker</k>); <k>observo</k>
observation <ex>(of an object)</ex>; <k>observanta</k>, <k>observema</k> observing,
observant; <k>observanto</k>, <k>observero</k>, <k>observisto</k> lookout, observer; <k>observeyo</k>, <k>observposteno</k> place of observation, lookout post; <k>observebla</k>
observable. Ex.: Observar naturo, la irado di la astri, la mori
di la diferenta nacioni. Astronomiala observado. Mento observema.

<k>obskura</k> <ex>(lit. and fig.)</ex> obscure: without
sufficient light to enable one to see objects, gloomy, dim,
somber (sombre); not easily understood; little known; (of
colo(u)rs) dark; <k>obskurigar</k> to obscure, dim, darken; <k>nokto
 obskura</k> a dark night; <k>stilo obskura</k> an unclear style; <k>vivar
 obskura vivo</k> to live an obscure life; <k>obskureso di lingui</k>
obscurity of language; <k>la nubi obskurigas la jorno</k> the
clouds intercept the daylight; <k>longa frazi obskurigas la
 senco</k> long sentences obscure the meaning. Ant.: <k>klara.</k>

<k>obskurantismo</k> obscurantism; <k>obskurantisto</k> obscurantist:
one who opposes enlightenment.

<k>obsoleta</k> obsolete (words, customs, etc.); <k>obsoleteskar</k>
to become obsolete; <k>obsoleteso</k> obsoleteness, desuetude, disuse.
Def.: Exter la uzado, la kustumo.

<k>obstaklo</k> <ex>(lit. and fig.)</ex> obstacle, hindrance,
obstruction, impediment, bar, clog: that which opposes; <k>obstaklokuro</k>
obstacle-race; <k>(kaval) kuro kun obstakli</k> steeple-chase.

<k>obstinar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to be obstinate (<k>en</k>, <k>pri</k>)
to persist, be firmly bent (on); <k>obstin(ad)o</k> obstinacy,
perinacity, stubborness (cf. <k>persistemeso</k>); <k>obstinanta</k>, <k>obstinera</k>, <k>obstinema</k> obstinate, self-willed, opiniated, headstrong,
stubborn; <k>obstinemo</k> an obstinate person; <k>il obstinas en
 taco</k> he keeps obstinately silent; <k>esar obstinanta pri
 projeto nerealigebla</k> to persist in an impractical project.
V. exp.: vid. <k>insistar.</k>

<k>obstruktar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to obstruct, block up, choke up;
be in the way of; <k>obstruktiva</k> obstructive. Ex.: Obstruktar voyo,
tubo. V. exp.: <k>inkombrar.</k>

<k>obtenar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to obtain, procure, get (u<k>lo</k>, <k>de
 ulu</k>). Ex.: Obtenar favoro de ulu. V. exp.: vid. <k>recevar</k>.

<k>obturar</k> <ex>(tr., tech.)</ex> to obturate: to stop or
close, as an opening.

<k>obtuza</k> obtuse: blunt, dull, (of edges, angles); <ex>(geom.)</ex>
larger than a right angle; <ex>(fig.)</ex> dull (in sensibility,
mentality); <k>obtuzigar</k> to blunt, dull (cf. <k>senpintigar</k>);
<k>obtuzangula</k> obtuse angular. Ex.: Hakilo obtuza. Il esas homo
mente obtuza. Ant.: <k>akuta.</k>

<k>oceano</k> acean; <ex>(fig.)</ex> sea, flood, great quantity
(cf. <k>maro</k>); <k>oceanido</k> <ex>(myth.)</ex> Oceanide,
sea-nymph.

<k>ociar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to be idle, be unoccupied; <k>ocio</k>
(temporary) idleness, unoccupation; <k>ociado</k> (pemanent,
habitual) idleness, leisure; <k>ocioza</k> unoccupied; <k>ociozega</k>, <k>ociema</k> lazy, slothful, indolent; <k>ocianto</k>, <k>ociero</k> idler,
person of leisure; <k>ociemo</k> loafer, sluggard. Def.: Esar en
stando di senlaboreso. Ociemeso esas la tendenco a ne laborar, a
facar nulo; ocioza signifikas la fakto, ne tendenco; IV-287. V.
exp.: On povas laborar dum sua <k>libertempi</k>, ma ne dum
periodo di <k>ocio</k> (cf. <k>chomar</k>, <k>flanar</k>).

<k>ocidar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to slay, murder: kill with violence;
<k>ocidar su</k> to commit suicide; <k>hom ocido</k> homicide; (cf. <k>rejocido</k>, <k>infantocido</k>, <k>suocido</k>); Def.: Mort-igar violente (intence o
ne, krimine o ne); III-697. V. exp.: On ocidas anke bestii, ne
nur en bucheyo (ube on buchas li), ma en chaso ed en mult altra
okazioni. Ni havas <k>asasinar</k> por la ocido esence krimina; <k>mortigar</k>
havas logikale la senco: igar mortar. ex.: ta yuno mortigis sua
gepatri pro chagreno; ta acidento mortigis plura personi pro
pavoro; III-697; on<k>masakras</k>plura personi kruele o
senbezone; III-698.

<k>ocilar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to oscillate: swing back and
forwards (cf. <k>vibrar</k>, <k>fluktuar</k>); <k>ocililo</k> swing (cf. <k>baskulilo</k>).

<k>ocipito</k> <ex>(anat.)</ex> occiput: back part of head or
skull; <k>ocipitala</k> occipital; <k>ocipitala osto</k>, <k>ocipitalo</k> occipital
bone.

<k>odiar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to hate (<k>ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>); <k>odiesar</k>
to be hated (<k>da</k>); <k>odiozeso</k> hatefulness; <k>odiema</k>, <k>odiiganta</k> invidious; <k>odiinda</k> odious; (cf. <k>abominar</k>).

<k>odorar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to have a smell or scent, smell
(fragrant, etc.), exhale odo(u)r; (cf. <k>flarar</k>); <k>odoro</k>
odor, scent, smell (cf. <k>parfumo</k>, <k>flaro</k>); <k>odoranta</k>, <k>odoroza</k>
odoriferous; <k>sen odora</k>, <k>ne odoroza</k> odorless; <k>bonodora</k>
fragrant, sweet-smelling; <k>mal odoro</k> bad odor.

<k>ofensar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to offend, give offense (offence)
to, shock (the sensibilities); <k>ofensesar</k> to be offended (<k>da</k>);
<k>ofenso</k> offense, affront (cf. <k>insulto</k>); <k>ofensanta</k>, <k>ofensiva</k>, <k>ofensema</k> offending, shocking, offensive, obnoxious.

<k>ofico</k> <ex>(function, duty, assigned service)</ex> office,
post (cf. <k>oficio</k>, <k>employo</k>); <k>oficala</k> functionary
relating to office, duty; (cf. <k>oficiala</k>); <k>oficisto</k> a
(civil) official (cf. <k>oficiro</k>); <k>oficestro</k> head of
(civil) office. Def.: Funciono administrala o direktala, sive en
la stato, sive en societo o grand entraprezo; III-697.

<k>oficiar</k> <ex>(intr., eccl.)</ex> to officiate: perform
divine service; <k>oficianta</k>, <k>oficianto</k> officiating (priest or
clergyman); <k>oficio</k> office (divine service); <k>oficiala</k>
relating to divine service (cf. <k>oficala</k>).

<k>oficiro</k> <ex>(milit. nav., of an order) </ex>officer (cf. <k>oficisto</k>);
<k>sub oficiro</k>subordinate officer, non-commissioned officer.

<k>ofrar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to offer, proffer, tender (<k>ulo ad
 ulu</k>), to offer (to do); to place at the service of (<k>ulu</k>);
<k>ofrar su</k> to offer, propose (oneself); <k>ofro</k> offering
(act), offer, tender, proposal, bid; <k>ofrajo</k> what is
offered; <k>ofro</k> <ex>(polit. econ)</ex> supply: what is offered;
Ex.: Ofrar helpo, sua brakio a siorino, sua manuo ad amiko,
viktimo en sakrifiko, acompanar ulu. La lego di l’ofro e di
la demando determinas la preco di la vari sur ula merkato. V.
exp.: Il <k>propozis</k> a me irar kun il en la teatro, ma il ne <k>ofris</k>
a me plaso. On povas <k>ofrar</k> la vari sen <k>prizentar</k>
li: en la komercal borso, on ne <k>prizentas</k> la vari ipsa,
same kam en la financal borso en ne <k>prizentas</k> la valori:
tamen on ofras li; II-79, 167.

<k>ofte</k> oft, often, oftentimes; <k>ofta</k> frequent; <k>maxim
 ofte</k> most often, very often; <k>ne ofte</k> rarely, seldom.
Ex.: Ofte on mustas facar ulo quon on ne deziras facar. V. exp.: <k>Ofta</k>
ne esas sinonima a <k>frequa.</k> <k>Ofta</k> dicesas pri ulo quo
eventas «ofte», t.e. multa foyi en ula intervalo. <k>Frequa</k>
esas utila en tekniko: ex. on bezonas parolar pri flui
(elektrala) di granda <k>frequeso</k>: on ne povas dicar: <k>di
 granda ofteso</k> to semblus signifikar, ke on uzas li ofte;
IV-237. Ant.: <k>rara.</k>

<k>oglar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to ogle: view with side glances; to
cast glances at slyly; <k>oglachar</k> to leer at (<k>ulu</k>).

<k>ok</k> eight; <k>okesma</k> (ordinal) eighth; <k>okopla</k>, <k>okoplo</k> eight-fold, octuple; <k>okimo</k> one-eighth; <k>okadek</k>
eighty, fourscore; <k>okadekyara</k>, <k>oko</k> octogenarian; <k>okima
 negro</k> octoroon: person one-eighth black; (cf. <k>du</k>).

<k>okaziono</k> occasion, opportunity; <k>okazione</k> occasionally,
at times; <k>okazione di</k> apropos (of); (cf. <k>kauzo</k>). Ex.: Me
kaptis la okaziono por parolar ad il. Kande okaziono prizentos
su, ni iros.

<k>oktanto</k> octant: eighth of a circle; <ex>(astron. instr.)</ex>
octant.

<k>okulo</k> eye; <k>okuleto</k> small eye; <ex>(tech.)</ex> eyelet
hole; <k>okulala</k> ocular; <k>okulalo</k> eye-piece, eye-glass; <k>okulisto</k>
oculist; <k>okulagar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to eye (<k>ulu</k>, <k>ulo</k>); <k>okulo
 nuda</k> naked eye; <k>okulo po okulo</k> eye for eye; <k>okulklapo</k>, <k>okulshirmilo</k> eye-shade; (for horses) blinker; <k>okuloskrubo</k>
a staple, eyebolt: screw with ringed head.

<k>okupar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to occupy (a place, time); <k>okupar
 su</k> to occupy oneself, employ oneself, be busy (<k>pri</k>); <k>okupesar</k>
to be occupied (<k>da</k>); <k>okupeso</k> occupancy (fact); <k>okup(ad)o</k>occupying;<k>okupantajo</k>, <k>okupivo</k> (that which occupies)
business, work, occupation; <k>okupanto</k>, <k>okupero</k> occupant; <k>okupata</k>
occupied, busy. Ex.: La lito okupas la tota spaco. La soldati
okupis la urbo. La diskutado okupis la tempo. Ca laboro okupis
dek yari di lua vivo. Il okupis su en (od, pri) sua gardeno. Esar
sen okupeso. La okupo di la urbo da la trupi. La okup-antajo,
-ivo di soldati, di komercisto.

<k>ol</k> (abbr. for <k>olu</k>; acus. <k>olun</k>) (neuter
pronoun referring to a definite object; cf. <k>lo</k>, <k>lu</k>) it; <k>oli</k>
they (cf. <k>li</k>); <k>olua</k> its; <k>olia</k> their (cf. <k>lia</k>).
Ex.: Ol esas tre bela. La afero semblas bona, ma forsan ol ne
esas tala. La kavalo esas tro fatigita; ol(u) ne povus tirar la
veturo, La viri e la bestii ne konkordas inter su, nam ili (la
viri) tiris ad-dextre, dum ke oli (la bestii) tiris adsinistre.

<k>olda</k> <ex>(of living beings)</ex> old, of advanced age; <k>oldo</k>, <k>oldulo</k>, <k>oldino</k> old person; <k>oldeso</k> oldness; <k>oldaro</k> <ex>(collect.)</ex>
aged persons; <k>oldeskar</k> to grow old; (<k>plu</k>-) -<k>igar</k>
to age, make look old. Def.: Di evo avanc-inta. V. exp.: vid. <k>anciena.</k>
Ant.: <k>yuna.</k>

<k>oleo</k> oil; <k>oleoza</k>, <k>oleatra</k> oleaginous; <k>oleizar</k>
to oil (<k>ulo</k>); <k>oleifar</k> to produce oil, give out oil; <k>oleuyo</k>
oil-holder, oilcan; cruet; <k>olelampo</k> Argand lamp: common oil
lamp for illumination; <k>olefarbo</k> oil paint; <k>olei santa</k>
<ex>(eccl.)</ex> holy oils; <k>brul oleo</k> lamp-oil, kerosene; <k>ricin
 oleo</k> castor oil; <k>oliv oleo</k> olive-oil.

<k>olfaktar*</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to perceiveby sense of smell; <k>olfakto</k>
olfaction. -<k>ala organo</k> olfactory organ.

<k>olim</k> formerly, in former times, once upon a time; <k>olima</k>
former; <k>olima tempo</k> in days of old. Ex.: Olim esis kustumo.
La homi di olima tempo. Olim ula princo regnis. Olima kustumo.
<k>olimpiado</k> Olympiad: a period of four years. <k />

<k>ombro</k> shadow, shade; <k>ombrizar</k> to shade, over shade;
put in, cover with shadows; <k>ombroza</k>, <k>ombrizanta</k> shadowy,
shady, umbrageous.

<k>omisar*</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to omit, leave out or undone, pass
over; <k>omiso</k>, <k>omisajo</k> omission (cf. <k>neglijar</k>). Ex.:
Omisar formalajo. Ne omisez facar to. Il omisis fakto importanta.

<k>omna</k> <ex>(collective sense)</ex> all, every; <k>omni</k>
all, everybody <ex>(collect.)</ex> -<k>o</k> everything; <k>omnu</k>
every one; <k>omna tri</k>, <k>omna quar</k> all three, all four; <k>il
 havas du filiuli</k>, <k>qui omna esas soldati</k> he has two sons who
are (both) soldiers; <k>de omna loki</k> from every place; <k>omnadie</k>, <k>omna</k> daily, every day; <k>omnofacanto</k> factotum; <k>omnakaze</k>
in any case, in any event; <k>omnafoye</k> every time; <k>omnaloke</k>
every place; <k>omnomanjanta</k> omnivorous (cf. <k>omnivora</k>);
<k>omnamonata</k>, <k>omne</k> every month, monthly; <k>omnamaniere</k> in
every way; <k>omnopovo</k> omnipotence; <k>omnopovanta</k>
omnipotent, all powerful; <k>omnosavo</k>omniscience; <k>omnosavanta</k>
omniscient; <k>omnasemena</k>, <k>omne</k> weekly, every week. -<k>osufranto</k>
<ex>(fig.)</ex> drudge; <k>omnasorta</k>, <k>omnspeca</k> every kind of; <k>omnotushero</k>
<ex>(fig.)</ex> meddler, busy-body; <k>omnube</k> wherever. V. exp.:
vid. <k>singla.</k>

<k>on</k> one <ex>(indefinite pronoun)</ex>: people, men, we, they
(when used vaguely for society), for people in general; <k>on
 dicas</k> people say, they say; <k>on devas amar sua gepatri</k>
we should love our parents; <k>on ne povas manjar sua kuko e
 konservar ol</k> you cannot eat your cake and have it. (Note: <k>Ni</k>
translates «we» only when a limited number of persons is
thought of with whom the speaker or writer is directly
associated: <k>ni qui kredas ke I.L. esas posibla</k>).

<k>onagro*</k> <ex>(zool.)</ex> onager: a wild ass (Equus
Onager); <ex>(hist.)</ex> onager: a stone-throwing machine.

<k>ondo</k> <ex>(lit. and fig.)</ex> (small) wave, swell, surge
(of water); undulation; <k>ondego</k> billow, breaker; <k>ondifar</k>
to rise in billow form or produce waves; to undulate, wave; <k>ondigar</k>, <k>ondizar</k> to cause waves on; to cover with waves; <k>ondifo</k>, <k>ondaro</k>
undulation, waves; <k>ondoza</k>, <k>ondatra</k>, <k>ondifanta</k>, <k>ondizita</k> wavy,
wavelike, undulating; <k>ondagitata</k> rough; <k>ondagiteso</k>
billowy. Ex.: Ondi di maro, di soni, di tero (sismala). La maro
ondifas. La vento ond-igas, -izas la maro. Ondoza surfaco.

<k>onyono</k> <ex>(plant and edible bulb)</ex> onion; <k>onyoneyo</k>
onion-bed; <k>onyonshelo</k> onion-skin, -peel.

<k>opaka</k> opaque. Def.: Qua ne esas diafana, ne permeebla
per lumo. Ant.: <k>diafana</k>, <k>translucida.</k>

<k>operacar</k> <ex>(tr., surg., mil., math., finan.)</ex> to
operate (upon); <k>operacato</k>, <k>operacito</k> person operated upon; <k>operacar
 malado</k>, <k>tumoro</k> to operate upon a sick person, a tumor. Ex.:
Subisar operaco. Financalo operaco. Operaco en sustraciono.
Militala operaco.

<k>opinionar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to opine, express one’s
opinion, be of the opinion. Def.: Expresar judiko pri temo. Ex.:
Me favore opinionas pri la projeto. Publika opiniono.

<k>oportar</k>, <k>oportas</k> <ex>(intr., impersonal)</ex> it is required,
it is necessary (<k>ke</k>); (cf. suffix: <k>oportend</k>); <k>oportas
 levar ni fru morge</k> it is necessary to get up early
to-morrow. V. exp.: Kande ica signifiko havas subjekto, on uzas <k>mustar:
 oportas</k> ke vu departez: vu <k>mustas</k> departar.

<k>oportuna</k> <ex>(of things)</ex> opportune, seasonable,
timely, convenient (cf. <k>favoroza</k>); <k>oportuneso</k>
opportuneness (cf. <k>okaziono</k>); <k>oportunismo</k> (politics)
opportunism; <k>oportunisto</k> opportunist; (N.B. «opportunity» is
translated by <k>okaziono</k> or <k>oportunajo</k>); Ex.:
Okaziono oportuna. Oportuneso di la sokurso.

<k>opozar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to oppose (<k>ulu ad ulo</k>, <k>ulu</k>, <k>ad
 ulu</k>), to put in opposition to, place (<k>ulo</k>) opposite; <k>opoz(ad)o</k>
opposition (resistance); <k>opozeso</k> opposition (contrast, state
of); <k>opozanto</k>, <k>opozero</k> opponent; <k>opozata</k>, <k>opozita</k> opposed,
opposite (<k>ad</k>); <k>opozantaro</k> the opposition; <k>opozato</k>
the opposite; <k>opozar spegulo a la fenestro</k> to set a glass
opposite a window; <k>opozar digo a la torento</k> to oppose a dike
(dyke) to a torrent; <k>opozar du motivi</k> to put two motives in
contrast; <k>la domo opozata</k> the house opposite. (N.B. the
basic idea of this word implies putting in contrast, opposing an
obstacle, rather than active opposition, therefore, «to
oppose»: act in opposition, is translated ordinarily by <k>kombatar</k>, <k>rezistar</k>).

<k>opresar</k> <ex>(tr., phys., mental, social)</ex> to oppress:
to lie heavy on; deject, treat with hardship; (cf. <k>charjegar</k>, <k>presegar</k>); Def.: Presar forte (fizike o etikale) kontre ulu.
V. exp.: On esas fizike opresata, kande on respiras kun peno; on
esas etikale opresata, kande on angoras pro desquieteso, en
expekto di trista evento od informo. La richuli opresas la
povruli. La konquestiti povas esar opresata da la konquestanti,
la laboristi da la patroni, e.c. III-223.

<k>optiko</k> (science of) optics; <k>optikisto</k> optician: one
skilled in optics (cf. <k>okulisto</k>).

<k>or</k> <ex>(conj.)</ex> now, but (in argument). V. exp.: <k>Or</k>
expresas ne nur intersequo di du propozicioni, ma induktas nova
argumento, plusa premiso, expliko, motivo. Ex.: Or, vua argumento
semblas bona, ma ...  Omno qua foligas esas veneno; or
l’alkoholo foligas; do ... Kande la premiso (motivo)
sequas la konkluzo, or vicesas da <k>nam</k>;  ex.:
L’alkoholo esas venono, <k>nam</k> ol foligas; kp. <k>nam</k>;
VI-141-2; Talmey’s Text Book, p. 113.

<k>oro</k> gold; <k>ora</k> (of gold thread, watch, etc.); <k>orea</k>
golden (of hair, etc.); <k>oroza</k> full of, rich in gold,
auriferous; <k>ormineyo</k> gold mine; <k>orizar</k> to gild,
plate (<k>ulo</k>) with gold; <k>orfolio</k>, <k>orpelikulo</k> gold
leaf; <k>orizitaarjento</k> silver-gilt.

<k>oraklo</k> oracle; <k>oraklatra</k> oracular (tone, etc.); <k>oraklifar</k>
to declare, utter an oracle.

<k>oranjo</k> orange; <k>oranjiero</k> orange tree; <k>oranjiereyo</k>
orange grove: <k>oranjea</k> orange colo(u)red; <k>oranjodrinkajo</k>
orangeade.

<k>ordeno</k> <ex>(eccl. and knighthood)</ex> order; <k>ordenizar</k>
to knight; <k>ordeninsigno</k> insignia, badge (of knighthood).

<k>ordinar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to order: put in, reduce to,
dispose in, order (cf. <k>rangizar</k>); <k>ordino</k>, <k>ordineso</k> order:
regular disposition, methodical arrangement; <k>ordinala</k>, <k>ordinalo</k>
ordinal: indicating order or succession; as, first, second, etc.;
<k>ordinema</k> orderly, tidy (person); <k>ordinemeso</k> orderliness;
<k>ordinita</k>, <k>ordinoza</k> ordered, regulated, orderly.

<k>ordinara</k> ordinary, common, usual; <k>ordinare</k> commonly,
ordinarily. Ex.: Vanitato esas kulpo tre ordinara. Ordinara
manjajo, homo. Ant.: <k>extraordinara.</k>

<k>ordonanco</k> <ex>(milit.)</ex> orderly; <k>ordonancoficiro</k>
ordinance officer. Def.: Soldato qua exekutas o transmisas la
komandi di oficiro; la ordinanc-oficiro ludas simila rolo apud
supera oficiro; III-266.

<k>orelo</k> ear, auricle; <ex>(fig.)</ex> hearing; <k>orelala</k>
auricular; <k>orelkovrilo</k>, <k>orelumo</k> ear-covering, ear-flap; <k>orelringo</k>
ear-ring; <k>orelfingro</k> little finger; <k>oreloza; grandorela</k>
big-eared; <ex>(horses)</ex> lop-eared; <k>orelkuracisto</k> aurist;
<k>orelzumado</k> buzzing, ringing in the ears; <k>askoltar per
 omna oreli</k> <ex>(fig.)</ex> to be all ears, to listen intently; <k>havar
 orelo justa</k> (od, <k>delikata</k>): to have a good (or, delicate)
ear (as for music); <k>levar</k> (od, <k>tensar</k>) <k>la oreli</k>
to prick up the ears.

<k>oreliono</k> <ex>(med.)</ex> mumps; an infectious inflammation
of various glands (cf. <k>parotidito</k>).

<k>orfana; o</k>, <k>ulo</k>, <k>ino</k> orphan; <k>ala</k> relating to
orphans; <k>erio</k> orphanage, orphan asylum.

<k>organo</k> organ (part of an organized body); <ex>(fig.)</ex>
instrument, means; (cf. <k>orgeno</k>); <k>organala</k> organic:
relative to organs or organized means; (cf. <k>organika</k>); <k>organizar</k>
to organize: furnish with organs; (cf. <k>aranjar</k>, <k>institucar</k>);
<k>organizo</k>, <k>organizeso</k>, <k>organizuro</k> organization (cf. <k>ordino</k>, <k>konstituciono</k>, <k>organismo</k>); <k>organizanto</k> organizer. Ex.:
L’okulo esas l’organo di vidado. Ca jurnalo esas
l’organo di demokratio; <ex>(fig.)</ex> La judiciisto esas la
organo di la lego. Organizar ministerio. Organizuro di la homala
korpo. Muzikala organizuro.

<k>organdio</k> <ex>(fabric)</ex> organdy. Def.: Speco di
muslino; IV-448.

<k>organismo</k> <ex>(lit. and fig.)</ex> organism. Def.: <ex>(lit.)</ex>
Ensemblo di la organi (la organaro) qui konstitucas ento vivanta.
Ex.: Homala organismo. <ex>(fig.)</ex> Politikala organismo.

<k>organzino</k> organzine: a double-thrown silk used in
weaving.

<k>oriento</k> Orient, the east; <k>orientala</k> oriental; <k>orientano</k>
an oriental; <k>orientalisto</k> orientalist; <k>orientizar</k> <ex>(pr.
and fig.)</ex> to orient: place or set toward the east; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
to give the correct aspect, the right direction to; <ex>(nav.)</ex>
to trim (sails); <k>orientizar</k> to adjust one’s bearings
toward the east; <ex>(fig.)</ex> to ascertain one’s position,
find out what one is about; <k>orientizar ulu en lua studiado</k> to
guide, set someone in the right direction in his studies; <k>esas
 nefacila orientizar su en la mezo di revoluciono</k> it is
difficult to get one’s bearings, find out one’s true
position, in the midst of revolution (cf. <k>esto</k>).

<k>origino</k> origin (cf. <k>fonto</k>); <k>originala</k>
original: relating to origin; not copied; (cf. <k>stranja</k>); <k>originaleso</k>
originality; <k>originalajo</k> (of things) the original, first
copy; <k>original(ul)o</k> eccentric person, odd fellow; <k>origine</k>, <k>originale</k>
originally, primitively; in the beginning, by origin. Ex.:
Origino di vorti, di la mondo. Originala edituro, penso, pikturo.
La pikturo montras originaleso. Kopiuro konforma a la
originalajo.

<k>orikalko</k> <ex>(met.)</ex> orichalk. Def.: Anciena nomo di
latuno.

<k>oripelo</k> tinsel; Dutch gold. Def.: Dina, oratra folieto,
quan on uzas por orizar diversa objekti; VI-142. V. exp.: <k>Orpelikulo</k>
(E. gold leaf) esas vera oro; <k>oripelo</k> imitas l’oro;
(kp. <k>flitro</k>); VI-142.

<k>orkestro</k> orchestra: a part in theater (theatre) nearest
the stage; a company of instrumental performers.

<k>orlar</k> <ex>(tr., needle-work)</ex> to hem: turn down and
sew the edge of (a garment, fabric); <k>orluro</k> hem; <ex>(arch.,
herald.)</ex> orlet, orle; (cf. <k>rifaldar</k>, <k>orluro</k>).

<k>ornar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to adorn, embellish, bedeck (<k>ulo</k>, <k>ulu</k>, <k>per ulo</k>); (cf. <k>dekorar</k>, <k>plubeligar</k>); <k>orno</k>
adorning; <k>ornivo</k> adornment, ornament (cf. <k>ornamento</k>);
<k>orniva</k> decorative, ornamental. Ex.: La domi esas neta,
komoda, ma li ne esas ornita. Ornar parko per statui. <ex>(fig.)</ex>
Ca viri esas ornivi di nia yarcento.

<k>ornamento</k> ornament, embellishment; <ex>(mus.)</ex>
grace-note; (cf. <k>ornivo</k>); <k>ornamentala</k> ornamental; <k>ornamentizar</k>
to ornament, decorate (cf. <k>ornar</k>, <k>dekorar</k>); <k>ornamento ek
 diamanti</k> diamond ornament.

<k>ornitoptero</k> ornithopter: a flying machine propelled by
flapping wings.

<k>orta</k> right (angle); (cf. <k>rekta</k>); <k>orto</k> a
right angle; <k>orte</k> at a right angle; <k>ortangula</k>
orthogonal, rectangular.

<k>ortodoxa</k> <ex>(rel. and fig.)</ex> orthodox; <k>ortodoxeso</k>
orthodoxy; <k>ortodox(ul)o</k> orthodox person. Ant.: <k>heterodoxa.</k>

<k>ortopedio</k> <ex>(surg.)</ex> orthopedics. Def.: L’arto
qua korektigas o preventas deformaji di la korpo.

<k>orvietano</k> orvietan: a pretended antidote or
counter-poison.

<k>osto</k> bone; <k>osteto</k> small bone, ossicle; <k>ostala</k>, <k>ostoza</k> osseous, bony; <ex>(fig.)</ex> large-boned; <k>ostaro</k>
bony frame-work (cf. <k>skeleto</k>); <k>ostigar</k> to ossify; <k>osteskar</k>
to become ossified; <k>ostifado</k>, <k>ostesko</k> ossification; <k>ostokarbono</k>
bone-black; <k>ludar per osteti</k> to play at knuckle-bones.

<k>ostentar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to do a thing out of
ostentation, show off, make a show (<k>pri</k>), parade (<k>ulo</k>);
<ex>(fig.)</ex> to swagger; <k>ostentanta</k>, <k>ostentoza</k>, <k>ostentema</k> ostentatious.
V. exp.: vid. <k>fanfaronar.</k>

<k>otario</k> otary: eared-seal. Def.: Speco di mar-hundo kun
oreli; V-341. (Otariidae).
<k>otomano</k> ottoman. Def.: Speco di divano; IV-395.

<k>otuso</k> <ex>(vulgara)</ex> common owl, long-eared owl
(Otus); <k>otuso penachetoza</k> short-eared owl (Otus brachyotus,
Asio accipitrinus, Strix brachyotus, Brachotus palustris). Def.:
Noktala ucelo di qua la kapo esas ornita per penacheti quaze
«oreleti»; IV-296.

<k>ovo</k> egg; <k>ovi</k> eggs; <ex>(of fish)</ex> roe; <k>ovoshelo</k>
egg-shell; <k>ovuyo</k> egg-cup, -holder; <k>ovajo</k> an egg
preparation; <k>ovifar</k> to lay eggs; <k>ovo (mole o harde o
 mimole) koquita</k> boiled egg; <k>ovo sur plado</k> fried egg;
<k>ovo mixita</k> scrambled egg; <k>ovo dispersita</k> poached
egg; <k>ovvendisto</k> egg-seller; <k>ovoplanto</k> egg-plant
(Solanum ovigerum) (cf. <k>berenjeno</k>).

<k>ovacionar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to give an ovation to, to receive
in triumph (<k>ulu</k>); <k>ovaciono</k> ovation.

<k>oxo*</k> oxygen (the scientific word; cf. <k>oxigeno</k>); <k>oxizar</k>
to oxygenate.

<k>oxalo</k> <ex>(bot.)</ex> sorrel (genus: Rumex); <k>oxalatacido</k>
o. acid; <k>oxalato</k> oxalate o. salt.

<k>oxido</k> <ex>(chem.)</ex> oxide; <k>oxidigar</k> to oxidate:
convert into an oxide.

<k>oxigeno</k> oxygen; <k>oxigenizar</k> oxygenize. V. exp.: <k>Oxigeno</k>
