 Francenemiko</k> enemy of the F.; francophobe; <k>la
 Franca</k> (linguo): the French (language); <k>Francatre</k>, <k>segun la Franca modo</k> in the F. fashion.

<k>francisko</k> <ex>(French)</ex> battle-axe. Def.: Armo di
l'antiqua Franki: hakilo kun du tranchivi; V

<k>frangulo</k> <ex>(bot.)</ex> black alder tree, alder buckthorn
Frangula (Rhamnus).

<k>franjo</k> fringe, border of loose threads; <k>franjizar</k> to
f. <k>(ulo)</k>: adorn, trim with a f.; <k>franjigar; franjeskar</k> to
fray out, become f.ed.
<k>franjipano</k> frangipane, jasmine perfume, also a liquor.
<k>Franko</k> member of a former German people.

<k>frankolino</k> <ex>(orni.)</ex> francolin: a species of
partridge (genus: Pternistes).

<k>frapar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to strike, knock, hit, slap, rap; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
to make an impression on <k>(ulu);</k> <k>frapetar</k> to pat, tap
lightly, strum; <k>frap(ad)o</k> strike, clapping (of hands,
rapping); (cf. <k>stroko</k>);<k>frapanta verajo</k> a
striking truth; <k>vento frapo</k> gust of wind; <k>pugno frapo</k>
blow of the fist; <k>manu frapo</k> clap (of hand); <k>pedo ar</k>
to knick (cf. <k>kikar</k>); <k>ondo frapo</k> beat of wave; <k>frapar
 pike e tranche</k> to cut and thrust. V. exp.: vid. <k>batar</k>.

<k>frato</k> <ex>(also relig.)</ex> brother or sister; <k>fratulo</k>
brother; <k>fratino</k> sister; <k>ge frati</k> brothers and
sisters; <k>frataro</k>, <k>frateso</k> brother- or -sisterhood; <k>fratala</k>, <k>atra</k> fraternal, sisterly, brotherly; <k>frateskar</k> to
fraternize <k>(kun)</k>; <k>armo fratulo</k>: brother-in-arms; <k>lakto
 fratulo</k> foster brother; <k>fratocido</k> fratricide (act.)

<k>fraudar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to defraud; cheat (in play);
<k>frauda</k>, <k>fraudoza</k> fraudulent; <k>fraudanto</k>, <k>fraudero</k> defrauder,
cheat; <k>fraude sustraktar</k> to embezzle; <k>fraudar parole</k> to
equivocate; <k>fraudar sua kreditanti</k> to defraud one's
creditors; <k>fraudar en exameno</k> to cheat in an examination. V.
exp. <k>furtar.</k>

<k>frayo</k> spawn, eggs of fish and also of frogs; <k>frayifar</k>
to s.

<k>frazar</k> <ex>(gram., mus.)</ex> phrase, sentence; <k>frazarifar</k>
to phrase, form sentences; <k>frazaroformo</k> a form of sentence; a
ready-made sentence, commonplace; <k>idiotismala frazo</k>
idiomatic sentence; <k>membro de frazaro</k> clause (cf. <k>klauzo</k>).

<k>fremisar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to shudder, quiver, tremble
(from passion; cf. <k>tremar</k>); <k>fremisigar</k> to cause to
shudder. Ex.: On fremisas de (pro) hororo, iraco, de multa
pasioni.

<k>freno</k> <ex>(tech.)</ex> brake; <k>fren(ag)isto</k> brakeman; <k>frenagar</k>
<ex>(intr.)</ex> to apply the b.s.; <k>par frenagar</k> to put the
b. full on;

<k>frenezio</k> frenzy, madness; <k>frenezioza</k>, <k>freneziika</k> furious,
frantic, frenzied, raving; <k>aceso de frenezio</k> a fit of f.;
<k>frenezioza homo</k> frantic person. Def.: Furioza deliro; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
eceso en ula pasiono.

<k>frequentar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to frequent, visit often, haunt;
attend (a school); <k>frequentata</k> frequented (road, etc.); <k>nur
 la Angli frequentas ta regioni</k> only the English frequent
these parts. V. exp.: <k>Frequentar</k> implikas 
(etimologie) l'ideo di <k>frequeso</k>, do di plura o multa
asisti. On <k>frequentas</k> skolo, kurso, ma on ne frequentas
diskurso (unfoye facita): on <k>asistas</k> ol; V.

<k>fresha</k> fresh, recently made, gathered, done, obtained;
not stale; sound, not impaired by time; <k>freshigar</k> to freshen,
refresh; <k>freshiganta</k> refreshing. Ex.: Fresha ovo (jus
pozita). Fresha aquo, karno, linjo. Freshe bakita, razita. La
fresheso di la rozo. La pluvo freshigas l'aero, la vejetantaro.
Drinkajo freshiganta.

<k>fretar</k> <ex>(tr., nav.)</ex> to charter (a
vessel); <k>fretanto</k>, <k>fretero</k> charterer; <k>fretopago</k>, <k>fretpreco</k> freight-, charter-cost; <k>fretokontrato</k>
charter-party. Def.: Lokacar navo por transporto di vari; II

<k>frezar</k> <ex>(tr., tech.)</ex> to countersink;
to widen, chamfer the upper part of a hole; <k>frezilo</k>
a c.

<k>friabla</k> friable. Def.: Qua esas facile
reduktebla a pulvero.

<k>frianda</k> (of objects) dainty, nice, toothsome,
savory; <k>friandajo</k> titbit, dainty morsel, sweetmeat,
table delicacy; <k>frianda disho;</k> a dainty dish. F

<k>fricionar</k> <ex>(tr., mechan., med.)</ex> to
rub; <k>friciono</k> rubbing, friction. V. exp. vid. <k>frotar.</k>

<k>frigoro</k> <ex>(tech.)</ex> cold: (cf. <k>koldeso</k>);
<k>frigoroizar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to refrigerate, preserve
bt cooling, <k>frigoroiz(ad)o</k> refrigeration; <k>frigoroizivo</k>, <k>frigoroilo</k> cooling, refrigerating apparatus; <k>frigoroifanta</k>, <k>frigoroiva</k> frigorific: producing cold; <k>frigoroifanta
 fasko</k> refrigerating coil, <k>freshaquala
 frigorizilo</k> fresh mater cooler.

<k>fripo</k>, <k>fripi</k> worn-out, old clothes or apparel,
frippery, trumpery; <k>fripeyo</k> old clothes place,
rag-fair; <k>fripisto</k> old clothes dealer; second hand
dealer.

<k>fripona</k> knavish, rascally; <k>fripon(ul)o</k>
knave, rogue, rascal; (cf. <k>raskalo</k>); <k>friponajo</k>, <k>friponeso</k> rascality, knavishness. F

<k>friskar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to frisk, w(r)iggle,
fidget; <k>friskema</k> frisky, nimble, fidgety; <k>ca
 fisho ankore friskas</k> this fish is still wriggling; <k>ta
 puero esas friskema</k> that child is fricky (or, fidgety); <k>el
 esas sempre friskanta per sua pedi</k> she is always fidgeting
with her feet. Def.: Agitar (su) per movi vivaca e kurta.

<k>fristo</k> <ex>(jur.)</ex> fixed space of time; <ex>(legal)</ex>
term; respite, delay, postponement. Def.: Tempo - quanto
grantenda o grantita por efektigar ulo; VI

<k>fritar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to fry; <k>fritajp</k>
thing fried, a fritter, fry; <k>fritita buio (de)</k>
croquette; <k>frito fritgraso</k> fat for frying.

<k>frivola</k> (of persons) frivolous, light-minded;
(of things, acts) trifling, futile, petty; <k>frivol(ul)o</k>
f. person; <k>frivolajo</k> frivolity (act); a futility; <k>frivola
 yuno</k> a gay young person; <k>dicar frivolaji</k>
to talk nonsense, fiddle-faddle. Ant.: <k>serioza</k>, <k>grava.</k>

<k>frizar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to curl, frizzle
(the hair of the head, beard, mustache, etc.);<k>frizeso</k>
curliness; <k>frizajo</k>, <k>frizloklo</k> a curl; <k>frizisto</k>
hair-curler, -dresser; <k>frizfero</k> curling iron; <k>papero</k>
curl-paper.

<k>frogo</k> frog: coarse braid or gallon crossing
the breasts of a coat. (Not amphib. cf. <k>rano</k>).

<k>froko</k> (monk's) cowl, hood (cf. <k>kapuco</k>);
(in an extensive sense) (monk's) frock, gown; <k>frokizar</k>
to enfrock; <k>abandonar la froko</k> <ex>(fig.)</ex> to
cease to be a monk.

<k>frolar</k> to graze, touch slightly in passing,
brush past. Ex.: La kuglo frolis mea kapo.

<k>frondo</k> a sling ( as for throwing stones); <ex>(surg.)</ex>
a sling (as used for arm) (cf. <k>sharpo</k>); <k>frondagar</k>
<ex>(tr.)</ex> to throw <k>(ulo)</k> with a s.

<k>fronto</k> <ex>(anat.)</ex> forehead; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
the fore part of anything; <k>frontala</k> frontal <ex>(anat.)</ex>;
front <ex>(fig.)</ex>; <k>frontalo</k> frontal-bone; <k>sam
 fronte</k> abreast; <k>frontolineo</k> <ex>(milit.)</ex>
front-line; <k>fronto larja</k> a wide forehead; a broad
front; <k>atakar la</k> <k>enemiko sur la fronto</k>
to attack the enemy on its front; <k>frontal atako</k> a front
attack;<k>la fronto di vesto</k> the front of a garment.

<k>frontiero</k> frontier. Def.: Limito inter du landi;
II

<k>frontispico</k> (book) frontispiece. Def.: Ilustruro qua
opozesas (E. faces) a titul-pagino di libro e libro-parto;
IV

<k>frontono</k> <ex>(arch.)</ex> fronton, pediment; -eto: a
little pediment over a door or window. Def.: Arkitektural ornivo
triangula o mi-cirkla super la enireyo di edifico.

<k>frostar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to freeze (cf. <k>glacieskar</k>);
<k>frostigar</k> to f. <k>(ulo);</k> (cf. <k>frigorizar; konjelar;
 pruinar);</k> <k>frostetar</k> to chill, benumb; <k>forta frosto</k> a
hard freeze; <k>frostopluvo</k> a freezing rain; <k>frostofendita</k>
split, cracked by frost; <k>des frostar</k> to thaw.

<k>frotar</k> <ex>(tr., household term)</ex> to rub, scrub, shine
up; polish <k>(ulo)</k> by rubbing; wax and polish (a floor,
furniture) (cf. <k>polisar</k>). V. exp.: <k>Frotar</k> esas
ekonomiala ago: on frotas parqueto, mobli, etc. <k>Fricionar</k>
havas teknikala senco, sive en medicino, sive en mekaniko;
II

<k>frua</k>, <k>frue</k> <ex>(adj. adv.)</ex> early; <k>frulevanta</k>, <k>fruanto</k>
rising early; early riser; <k>tro frue</k> too early; <k>plu
 frue</k> earlier; <k>maxim frue posible</k> as early as
possible.

<k>frugala</k> frugal; (cf. <k>sparema</k>) Ex.: Frugala homo.
Frugaleso di repasto.

<k>frukto</k> <ex>(pr. and fig.)</ex> fruit; <k>fruktifar</k> to
fructify, bear fruit; <k>fruktoza</k>, <k>fruktifanta</k> fruitful, prolific; <k>fruktarboro</k>
f. tree; <k>fruktogardeno</k>, <k>fruktarboreyo</k> f. garden; <k>fruktovendisto</k>
f. seller; <k>fruktomanjanta</k> frugivorous.

<k>frumento</k> wheat; <k>frumenta</k>, <k>frumentala</k>, <k>frumentatra</k> frumentaceous; <k>frumentizar</k>
to sow <k>(ulo)</k> with w., cover with w. <k /><ex /><k /><k /><k /><k /><k />

<k>frusta</k> worn out, defaced, corroded (of coins),
weather-beaten (of statues); <k>frusta medalio</k> a defaced medal; <k>konko
 frusta</k> a worn shell. V. exp.: <k>Frusta</k> esas vorto
mi-teknikala, utila in mikra faki, ex. pri arto (skulptado,
numismatiko); IV

<k>frustrar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to deprive unjustly <k>(ulu</k>, <k>de
 ulo)</k>, to defraud; (N.B. not E. frustrate; cf. <k>deceptar</k>, <k>faliigar</k>, <k>vanigar</k>). Def.: Privacar neyuste o neloyale;
III

<k>fudro</k> ton, large cask. Def.: Tre granda barelo (de 800
litri e plu multo); V

<k>fugar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to flee (from), run away; <k>fugeskar</k>
to take flight; <k>fugigar</k> to put <k>(ulu)</k> to flight,
drive away, rout; <k>fugo</k> running away, flight, rout; <ex>(mus.)</ex>
fugue; <k>fuganta</k>, <k>fuginta</k>, <k>fugema</k> fugitive, fleeting, transient; <k>fuganto</k>, <k>fugero</k> fugitive, runaway. Ex.: Ni fugas de la enemiko. Ni
fugigas la enemiko. Tempo fugas. La fugo ad Egiptia. Fuganta
sklavo. Ca vivo esas fuganta (E. transient).

<k>fuko</k> <ex>(bot.)</ex> fucus, sea-weed, kelp. Def.: Ordinara
genero di algo.

<k>fular</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to tread (grapes), trample on <k>(ulo)</k>;
to full (cloth) (cf. <k>tramplar</k>). Def.: Pedo-presar <k>(ulo)</k>
o marchar sur <k>(ulo)</k>; <ex>(fig.)</ex> specala maniero traktar
drapi; VI-114. Ex.: Fular la vitberi. La kavali fulis la gazono e
la flori.

<k>fulgurar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to fulgurate, flash as or like
lightning (cf. <k>fulminar</k>); <k>fulgurpulvero</k> <ex>(photog.)</ex>
flash-light powder.

<k>fulminar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to fulminate, to lighten;
to thunder and lighten; to flash; to blast <k>(ulu)</k>; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
to thunder forth (menaces, excommunication, etc. kontre ulu); <k>fulmin(ad)o</k>
lightning, flash, fulmination; <k>fulminstroko</k> thunderbolt,
lightning stroke; <k>fulminosilencoza</k> heat-lightning; <k>fulminanta</k>
fulminating; <k>para fulmino</k> lightning-rod.

<k>fumar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to smoke; <k>fumizar</k> to
cover with s.; to s. dry; <k>fumagar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to fumigate;
to s. out <k>(ulu)</k>; <k>fumagilo</k> fumigating apparatus; <k>fumoza;
 fumifanta</k> smoky; smoke-producing; <k>fumanto</k>, <k>fumero</k> smoker;
<k>fumfenduro</k> smoke fissure (cf. <k>fumarolo</k>); <k>fumkarbono</k>
smoking-coal, smoky bit of charcoal; <k>fumkonsumanta</k> s.
consuming; <k>fumonigro</k> lamp-black.

<k>funcionar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to function (all senses): to
function, act <k>(kom)</k>, to perform the duties, fill an
office, to work properly (of machinery, etc.); (cf. <k>agar</k>, <k>laborar</k>); <k>funcionigar</k> to make work, set going, put in play;
<k>funcion(ad)o</k> function(ing): execution, performance; discharge
(of duty); office, duty; <ex>(physiol., math.)</ex> function; <k>funcionala</k>
functional; <k>funcionero</k> functionary; <k>funcionerismo</k>
officalism, administrative system, founded on the existence of a
great number of functionaries.

<k>fundo</k> bottom, lowest part of something hollow, as b. of
a vase, a well; that which stands at the bottom, as a liquid at
the bottom of bottles; ground, solid substance under water, as of
sandy b.; <ex>(fig.)</ex> basis, essential part; <k>funde</k> at
bottom, in the main, in reality; <k>fundizar</k> to bottom (a
chair, etc.); <k>sen funda</k> bottomless; <k>en la fundo di la
 holdo</k> in the b. of the hold; <k>fundo di lito</k> b. of a bed;
<k>fundo di la maro</k> b. of the ocean; <k>tushar fundo</k> to touch
b.; <ex>(fig.)</ex> <k>la fundo di pikturo</k> the background of a
painting; <k>veluro kun oratra fundo</k> velvet with a gold(like)
background; <k>de l'fundo til la tekto</k> from the bottom to
the roof; <ex>(fig.)</ex> wholly, from top to bottom; <k>fundo di
 spegulo</k> back of a mirror.

<k>fundamento</k> <ex>(pr. and fig.)</ex> that on which anything
rests; foundation, groundwork, underpinning; <ex>(fig.)</ex> basis,
ground; (cf. <k>fonduro</k>, <k>basamento</k>); <k>fundamentala</k>
fundamental; <k>fundamentizar</k> to lay the f.s of (<k>ulo</k>). Ex.:
La fundamento di edifico. La fundamenti di la universo, di la
homala vivo, di la arti; Lua sistemo esas fundamentale nejusta.

<k>funelo</k> funnel; <k>funelagar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to pour (<k>ulo</k>)
through a f.; <k>funelego</k> (mill-)hopper; <k>funelfusilo</k>
(firearm) blunderbuss.

<k>funero</k> (ceremony) funeral, obsequies; <k>funerala</k>
funeral, funereal, mortuary; <k>funeristo</k> undertaker.

<k>funesta</k> baleful, disastrous, distressing, pernicious,
malign. Def.: Expresas ideo plu forta kam nociva, ma ne esas
exakte nek sempre mortigiva; signifikas kauzo od okaziono di
nefeliceso; IV-267. Ex.: Funesta evento, novajo, pasiono, milito.
Ant.: <k>favoroza</k>.

<k>fungo</k> <ex>(also med.)</ex> <ex>(bot.)</ex> fungus, mushroom,
(edible or poisonous as toadstool); <k>fungo manjebla</k> edible
(or common) m.; <k>fungajo</k> <ex>(med., bot.)</ex> f. growth; <k>fungoza</k>
fungous; <k>fungatra</k>, <k>fungoforma</k> f. like; f. shaped; <k>fungokultiveyo</k>
f. bed.

<k>funikulara</k> funicular, dependent upon the tension of a
cord, cable; <k>funikulara fervoyo</k> f. railroad.

<k>furo</k> fur (of animals; cf. <k>felo</k>); <k>furoza</k>, <k>furizita</k> furry, lined with fur; <k>furizar</k> to line, cover
with fur; <k>furisto</k> furrier; <k>furvesto</k>, <k>furajo</k> fur
garment, fur object.

<k>fureto</k> <ex>(zool.)</ex> ferret; (Putorius Furo); <ex>(fig.)</ex>
ferret(er), inquisitive person; <k>furetagar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to
hunt with a f.; <k>furetumar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to ferret out, pry
into (<k>ulo</k>); <k>furetumanto</k> a Paul Pry, searcher.

<k>furgono</k> closed van or goods wagon (cf. <k>kamiono</k>); <ex>(milit.)</ex>
baggage cart, ammunition wagon. Def.: Kargoveturo qua esas
konstitucita ek kestego klozita en qua on inkluzas la vari;
IV-291.

<k>furiar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to be in a state of extreme anger,
momentary madness, immoderate passion; <k>furiigar</k> to infuriate
(<k>ulu</k>); <k>furio</k> rage; <ex>(myth.)</ex> Fury; <k>furioza</k>
furious, enraged.

<k>furnelo</k> stove (for heating or cooking); kitchen-range; <k>furnelego</k>
furnace; <k>furnelifisto</k> stove-maker; <k>fuzo furnelo</k>
smelting-furnace. Def.: Aparato en qua on facas fairo; ol povas
kontenar forno; IV-135.

<k>furnisar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to furnish, supply (<k>ulo ad ulu</k>);
<k>furnisajo</k> thing supplied; <k>furnisanto</k>, <k>furnisero</k>, <k>furnisisto</k>
furnisher, purveyor; <ex>(theat.)</ex> property-man. Ex.: Furnisar
pano, mobli, informo. V. exp.: On <k>provizas</k> ulu per ulo; on
<k>furnisas</k> ulo ad ulu; kp. <k>livrar</k>.

<k>furtar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to steal, rob, purloin; <k>furtetar</k>
to pilfer; <k>furto</k> theft, larceny; <k>furtajo</k> thing stolen; <k>furtomanio</k>, <k>furtiko</k> kleptomani-a, -ac; <k>enirar furteme;</k> to steal in,
sneak in. V. exp.: <k>Furtar</k> esas prenar per ruzo la proprajo
di altru (generale kun nesavo di ica); <k>raptar</k> esas prenar
ol per violento sen celo; <k>fraudar</k> korespondas a <k>furtar</k>
(implikas deshonesta ruzo); II-647.
<k>furtocelo</k> the hiding or receiving of stolen goods: <k>furtoero</k>, <k>furtoisto</k> receiver of stolen goods; <ex>(colloq.)</ex> fence.

<k>fushar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to bungle, botch, scamp (work); <k>fush(ad)o</k>
botching; <ex>(fig.)</ex> sabotage; <k>fushajo</k> botch-work,
shoddy; <k>fushfabrikar</k> to make worthless merchandise, shoddy
goods.

<k>fusilo</k> musket, gun, rifle; <k>fusiliero</k> fusilier; <k>fusilagar</k>
<ex>(tr.)</ex> to shoot (down) (ulu); <k>fusilpafar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex>
to shoot (<k>ad ulo</k>); <k>fusilagado</k> firing, fusillade; <k>fusilpafo</k>
musket-shot; <k>chas fusilo</k> hunting gun, fowling-piece; <k>duopla
 fusilo</k> double-barreled gun; <k>glata fusilo</k> shotgun; <k>iteranta
 fusilo</k> a repeating or magazine rifle.

<k>fusto</k> <ex>(arch.)</ex> fust: shaft of a column; <ex>(of a
cannon)</ex> chase.

<k>futura</k>, <k>futuro</k> <ex>(also gram.)</ex> future; <k>predicar la
 futuro</k> to foretell the f. - DEF

<k>fuzar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to melt, fuze, smelt; <k>fuzo</k>, <k>fuzeso</k>
melting, fusion, blend; <k>fuzanta</k>, <k>fuziva</k>, <k>fuzema</k> melting,
dissolving; <k>fuzerio</k> foundry, smelting establ.; <k>fuzkaldrono</k>
melting-pot; <k>fuzarto</k> art of smelting; <k>fuztemperaturo</k>
melting point; <k>fuzebla</k> fusible; <k>kun fuz ar</k> to melt
together, amalgamate, blend.

<k>fuzeo</k> rocket (as in fireworks); fuse (to a bomb, etc.); <k>signal
 fuzeo</k> sky-, signal-rocket.

<k>fuzelo</k> <ex>(geom.)</ex> spindle: a solid generated by the
revolution of a curved line about its base; a fusiform figure;

<k>fuzeno</k> <ex>(bot.)</ex> prickwood, spindle tree, (genus:
Evonymus); <k>fuzenkarbono</k>, <k>fuzenkrayono</k> charcoal pencil; <k>fuzendesegnuro</k>, <k>fuzenuro</k> charcoal sketch.

<k>ca</k> (abbr. if <k>ica</k>)<k /> this (cf. <k>(i)ta</k>);
<k>cao</k> this; <k>cai</k> these; <k>cadie</k> today; <k>cahore</k>
at this hour; <k>camaniere</k> in this manner; <k>camatine</k>
this morning; <k>camonate</k> (during, in this month); <k>canokte</k>
tonight; <k>catempe</k> at this time; <k>cayare</k> in this
year. <k>Note</k> »This« in Ido is often translated by <k>(i)ta</k>,
but when it is necessary to point out a near object or emphasize
a particular object <k>ica</k> is used: <k>Kad vu preferas ica od
 ita kavalo?</k> When <k>ica</k> comes after two nouns, it refers
to the latter, <k>ita</k> to the first. When necessary or
desirable to indicate the gender of the object referred to, <k>ica</k>
is preceded by the proper personal pronoun: <k>ilca</k>, <k>ilci</k>, <k>elca</k>, <k>elci</k>, <k>olca</k>, <k /> etc. Ex.: La Yuni e la oldi tre deziras lo: iti
(la yuni), pro ke li pensas, ke ol amuzos li, ed ici (la oldi),
pro ke li pensas, ke ol esos utila por li. Quon drinkas blanka
vino ed elti drinkas nigra kafeo.

<k>car(ul)o</k> czar, tsar; <k>carino</k> czarina; <k>carido</k>
child of c.; czarevitch; <k>carala</k> relating to the c.

<k>cedar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to cede, yield (up); give (up); to
assign (property);(cf. <k>alienar</k>); <k>cedo</k> yielding,
relinquishment; <k>cedema</k> conciliatory; <k>cedebla</k>
transferable, assignable; <k>cedario</k> grantee, assignee.

<k>cedrato</k> (fruit) cedrate: a kind of citron (cf. <k>citrono</k>);
<k>cedratiero</k> c. tree; <k>cedratkonfitajo</k> candied c.

<k>celar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to hide, secrete, conceal, keep
secret; <ex>-ita:</ex> hidden, clandestine; <k>cele</k>, <k>celeme</k>
secretly, by stealth; <k>celetar</k>, <k>celachar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to be
sly, affect mystery; <k>celachem(ul)o</k> a sly or mysterious
person; <k>cele pafar</k> to shoot from cover; <k>celotrovo</k>
<ex>(game)</ex> hide and seek; <k>ludar ye celotrovo</k> to play
at hide-and seek. Ant.: <k>revelar</k>, <k>montrar</k>, <k>divulgar.</k>

<k>celebrar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to celebrate, commemorate. Ex.:
Celebrar mariajo, funero, jubileo, aniversario, meso; (III-199).

<k>celiba</k> celibate, unmarried; <k>celibo</k>, <k>celibulo</k>, <k>celibino</k> a c.;
<k>celibeso</k> celibacy, single life; <k>celibuleyo</k> bachelor's
room(s).

<k>celulo</k> cell: small room in convent, prison, etc.; small
cavity (as in a honey-comb); <k>celulala</k>, <k>celuloza</k> cellular,
cellulous.

<k>cemento</k> cement: kind of mortar for building, as Portland
c.; <k>cementizar</k> to c.; (of teeth) to fill a cavity with c.

<k>cementacar</k> <ex>(tr., metall.)</ex> to cement: to convert
iron into steel, to case-harden; <k>cementaco</k> cementation.

<k>ceno</k> scene, scenery <ex>(theat.)</ex>; <k>cenala</k>
scenic: theatrical, dramatic; <k>ceneyo</k> stage; <k>cenoplano</k>, <k>cenaro</k> scenario; <k>en cenigar</k> to put <k>(ulo)</k> on the
stage; <k>la ceno chanjas</k> the s. changes; <k>la ceno esas en
 Roma</k> the s. is in Rome.

<k>censo</k> »cense«: amount of taxes, income, which entitles
a person to vote; <k>censo elektala</k> electoral qualification.
Def.: La revenuo evaluata da la statal autoritati, sive por taxo,
sive por ula yuro (elektiveso); III-137.

<k>cento</k> one hundred; (in reckoning interest or fractional
parts) cent.; <k>centopla</k>, <k>cento</k> centuple, a hundredfold; <k>centimo</k>
a hundredth part (for other derivatives cf. <k>duo</k>); <k>centesma
 aniversario</k> centenary; <k>centyara</k> centennial; <k>centyarulo</k>, <k>centino</k>, <k>centiero</k> centenarian; <k>yarcento</k> a century; <k>miyar
 cento</k> a half-century; <k>tri po cento</k> three per cent.

<k>centro</k> <ex>(also fig.)</ex> center; <k>centrala</k>
central; <k>centraligar</k> to centralise; <k>centralig(ad)o</k>
centralization; <k>centraliganta</k>, <k>centrema</k> centralizing.

<k>centrifugar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to act on something
by centrifugal force; <k>centrifugala</k> centrifugal. Def.:
Agar, traktar per centrifugala forco; IV

<k>ceremonio</k> ceremony, formalities prescribed by
authority or etiquette; <k>ceremoniala</k> ceremonial; <k>ceremoniema</k>, <k>ceremonioza</k> ceremonious, formal; <k>ceremoniaro</k>, <k>i</k>
ceremonial, etiquette; <k>facar ceremonii</k> to stand upon
ceremonies.

<k>cerizo</k> cherry; <k>ceriziero</k> c.
tree; <k>cerizea</k> cerise, c. colored; <k>ceriziereyo</k>c.
orchard.

<k>cernar</k> <ex>(tr., milit., and fig.)</ex> to
make a circle or ring around, encircle, to beset on all sides,
besiege, beleaguer, blockade, invest, hem in; to cut or dig
around (a tree); <k>okuli blucernita</k> eyes with
dark circles. V.exp: <k>Cernar</k> ne esas simple <k>cirkondar</k>,
ma enemike cirkondar ed enklozar, por kaptar. Vorto necesa, ne
nur en milital arto, ma metefore en la komuna linguo; IV

<k>certa</k> certain, sure, indubitable, positive; <k>certe</k>
certainly, surely, assuredly (cf. <k>sendube</k>); <k>certajo</k>
a certainty; <k>certeso</k> certitude, assurance; <k>certigar</k>
to certify: make certain, assure, guarantee; <k>certigo</k>
certification; <k>certigajo</k>, <k>certuro</k> certificate,
testimonal; <k>certiganto</k> certifier, guarantee.

<k>ceruzo</k> ceruse: white-lead. Def.: Sub-karbato
di plombo, uzata kom farbo blanka; IV

<k>cervo</k> deer; <k>cervino</k> hind, roe; <k>cervulo</k>
stag, hart; <k>cervyuno</k> young d.

<k>cesar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to cease; to come
to an end, leave off, stop; <k>cesigar</k> to put a stop
or an end to, discontinue; <k>ceso</k> cessation; <k>cesigo</k>
discontinuation; <k>sen cesa</k> unceasing.

<k>cetero</k>, <k>ceteri</k> rest, remainder; <k>cetere</k>
besides, moreover, for that matter, in other respects; <k>e
 ceteri</k>, <k>cetere</k> (e.c.) et cetera (etc.)

<k>chagrenar</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to grieve, to have sorrow; <k>chagrenigar</k>
to grieve, render gloomy, sadden; <k>chagreno</k> grief, sorrow:
mental suffering (cf. <k>doloro</k>); <k>chagrenanta</k> sorrowful,
sad. Ant. <k>chagreno: joyo</k>, <k>gayeso.</k>

<k>chalenjo</k> challenge-cup (N.B. not the E. »challenge«
(cf. <k>defio</k>). Def.: (Premio en) konkurso en qua la premio
ne donesas, ma prestesas dum tempo a la vinkinto, til ke altra
partiso vinkas ica e konquestas la premio; VII-198.

<k>chamo</k> <ex>(zool.)</ex> chamois (Rupicapra tragus); <k>chamopelo</k>
shammy-skin, chamois-leather; <k>chamea</k> shammy color, buff.
<k>chamado</k> chamade: trumpet or drum signal for parley.

<k>chamaro</k> <ex>(coat)</ex> polonaise. Def.: Speco di
redingoto kun transversa kordoni avane, polona vesto de
revolucional epoko dil XIX yarcento; V-222.

<k>chambro</k> chamber, room; <ex>(fig.)</ex> a house of
parliament; <k>chambreto</k> small room; <k>chambraro</k> rooms <ex>(collect.)</ex>,
a suite; <k>chambro moblizita</k> a furnished room; <k>chambro di
 komerco</k> c. of commerce; <k>chambro di deputati</k> c. of
deputies; <k>chambrorobo</k> dressing-gown; <k>chambroservisto</k>
valet; <k>chambro(serv)istino</k> chambermaid; <k>manjo chambro</k>
dining room; <k>balno chambro</k> bath-room.

<k>championo</k> champion; <k>championeso</k> championship; <k>championo per
 libereso</k> c. of liberty; <k>lukto championo</k> c.wrestler.

<k>chanco</k> (good or bad) chance, luck, fortune; possibility;
<k>la chanci di milito</k> the fortunes of war; <k>probar la chanco</k>
to run the risk, take a chance; <k>la chanci di morto en la diversa
 evi</k> the chances (probabilities) of death at different ages.

<k>chanfreno</k> face of a horse (or other animal, from ears to
nostrils). Def.: Avana parto di kapo di kavalo; VII-198.

<k>chanjar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to change, shift; (cf. <k>kambiar</k>, <k>permutar</k>, <k>alterar</k>); <k>chanjebla</k>, <k>chanjema</k> changeable, mutable,
fickle. Def.: Substitucar ula kozo ad altra en un sama loko o
funciono, anke prenar un kozo vice altra, o pos altra; VII-203.
Ulo chanjas, kande, restante la sama esence, ol recevas altra
stando, figuro, o qulaeso; III-37. Ex.: Me chanjas mea vesti. Me
chanjas la tapiso. El chanjas sua kofio. On chanjas sua fako,
vagono, treno, lojeyo (co nule signifikas ke on alteras ta kozi o
transformas li; on livas li generale nealterita). Ant.: <k>mantenar</k>, <k>restar</k>, <k>konservar.</k>

<k>chanto</k> the small side or edge of a large flat body; <k>libro
 pozita sur chanto</k> a book placed on end or edge. Def.:
Laterala, streta edro di korpo larja e plata; III-420.

<k>chapelo</k> hat (with brim all around, for man or woman); <k>chapeluyo</k>, <k>chapelbuxo</k> hat-holder, -box; <k>chapelifisto</k> hat-maker; <k>chapelvendisto</k>
hat-seller; <k>chapellevo</k>, <k>chapelsaluto</k> a lifting of hat; <k>deprenar
 la chapelo</k> to take off, remove the hat; <k>chapelo trikorna</k> a
three-cornered hat; <k>klerik chapelo</k> clerical hat.

<k>charo</k> <ex>(antiq.)</ex> chariot; <ex>(modern)</ex> a two
wheeled cart or a four wheeled ornamented car; <k>chareto</k> any
light two wheeled cart, jaunting-car, cariole; <k>charedo</k>
cart-load; <k>duktisto</k> carter; <k>char(et)agar</k>
to cart <k>(ulo)</k>; <k>bovo charo</k>
ox-cart; <k>funerala charo</k> hearse; <k>triumfala
 charo</k> triumphal car.

<k>charioto</k> good van, truck: four-wheeled sided
wagon for carrying goods; <k>chariotagar</k> to cart, truck.
Def.: Kargo-veturo kun quar roti; IV

<k>charjar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to load, burden
(somebody or something with something), to load (a gun), lade (a
vehicle); <k>charjobestio</k> beast of burden; <k>charjegita</k>
overloaded; <k>super charjar</k> to overload. V. exp.: On
<k>kargas</k> vari sur veturo e <k>charjas</k>
veturo per vari; (V

<k>charmar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to charm: delight,
captivate, enchant; (cf. <k>ravisar</k>, <k>facinar</k>, <k>sorcar</k>);<k>charmo</k>, <k>charmeso</k> charm, enchantment; <k>charmanto</k>, <k>charmero</k>
charmer; <k>charmanta</k>, <k>charmiva</k> charming, delightful,
pleasing; <k>charmegar</k> to ravish, greatly enchant.

<k>charniro</k> hinge (of a door, a box, etc.); <ex>(mechan.)</ex>
joint (as compasses); <k>universal charniro</k> <ex>(mechan.)</ex>
universal joint (cf. <k>gondo</k>).

<k>charto</k> charter: document granting special
rights or privileges.

<k>chasar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to chase: hunt; <k>chasajo</k>
game; <k>chasantaro</k> hunting party; <k>chaserino</k>
huntress; <k>chasfusilo</k> fowling-piece; <k>chasgardisto</k>
gamekeeper; <k>chashundo</k> hunting-dog.

<k>chasta</k> chaste: untainted by lewdness; <ex>(fig.)</ex>
refined, pure (in taste, style); <k>chasteso</k> chastity.

<k>che</k> <ex>(prep)</ex> at, to, in (somebody's
house, home, or place), with (to indicate customs); <k>che
 la bakisto</k> at the baker's; <k>venez che me</k>
come to my house; <k>hiere me esis che mea onklulo</k>
yesterday I was at my uncle's; <k>che la Spartani esis
 kustumo expozar febla infanti</k> it was customary with the
Spartans to expose weakly infants.

<k>chefo</k> chief, leader, head; <k>chefa</k>
chief (of things; cf. <k>precipua</k>); <k>chefala</k>
chief's, relating to the leader; chief; <k>chefeso</k>
(position, authority) leadership; <k>chefesar</k> to be
chief, be in command; <k>chefinjerioro</k> chief
engineer; <k>chefa klefo</k> master-key; <k>chefkontrolisto</k>
superintendent, comptroller, overseer; <k>chefministro</k>
prime minister, premier; <k>chefsacerdoto</k> chief
priest; <k>chefurbo</k> chief town, capital (cf. <k>metropolo</k>).

<k>chelato</k> <ex>(helmet)</ex> sallet. Def.: Speco
di kasko uzata en la mezepoko e 16a yarcento;
IV

<k>chera</k> dear (in price), costly; <k>chereso</k>
dearness, high price; <k>(plu) cherigar</k> to cause <k>(ulo)</k>
to raise in price; <k>chereskar</k> to become, grow
dearer. Def.: Multe kustanta; IV<k />

<k>cherpar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to draw liquids; (cf. <k>rakar</k>);
<ex>(fig.)</ex> to take, borrow. Ex.: Cherpar aquo de fonto, de
rivero. Cherpar vino de barelo. La autoro cherpas peco de altra
autoro.

<k>chevrono</k> <ex>(arch.)</ex> chevron <ex>(fig.)</ex>
any inverted V-shaped object, as a rafter.

<k>chifrar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to write in secret
cipher (cf. <k>kriptografar)</k>; <k>chifro</k>
cipher: secret mode of writing; <k>des chifrar</k> to
translate from cipher; (cf. <k>dechifrar</k>). V. exp.:
<k>Chifrar</k> expresas l'ago kompozar kriptografuro,
t.e. sekreta texto, qua tradukas la vera texto per ula moyeno o
regulo nomita klefo. <k>Dechifrado</k> ne esas
l'inversa ago di chifrar, ma la deskrovo di la klefo e la traduko
di la kriptografuro; V

<k>chika</k> chic, stylish and original, natty,
smart; <k>chikeso</k> chic, knack, skill, address (in
doing anything); originality and taste (as in dress).
<k>chiniono</k> chignon: back hair of a woman.

<k>chipa</k> cheap, low (in price). Def.: Poke kustanta;
IV-690. Ant.: <k>chera.</k>

<k>chomar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to be out of work, to suspend
work on, to rest from work; <k>chom(ad)o</k> remaining idle from
want of work; <k>chomeso</k> (state) cessation or want of work.
Ex.: On chomas la sundii. La laboristi chomas pro blokal exkluzo.

<k>chopino</k> a beer glass (containing about a pint); <ex>(fig.)</ex>
a pint; <k>chopinedo</k> a pintful.

<k>choseo</k> roadway, causeway, travelling part (for horses,
carriages, etc.).

<k>cibolo</k> <ex>(bot.)</ex> cibol, a kind of onion. (Allium
fistulosum).

<k>cicisbeo</k>: cicisbeo. Def.: Amoranto di siorino, qua esas
quaze oficale agnoskata e servas el publike; V-621.

<k>cielo</k> <ex>(pr. and fig.)</ex> sky, heaven; <k>cielala</k>
celestial, heavenly; <k>danko a la cielo</k> thanks to heaven, to
God! <k>cielblua</k> sky-blue; <k>cielskrapero</k> sky-scraper; <k>cielvulto</k>
the celestial vault.

<k>cienco</k> science; <k>ciencoala</k> scientific; <k>ciencooz(ul)o</k>, <k>isto</k> scientist, savant; learned or erudite person in any
branch of knowledge; <k>ciencoistacho</k> pedant; <k>ciencoozega</k>
most learned. Def.: Savo exakta e sistemigita pri ula temo o
grupo di temi, qua relatas la arti libera (gramatiko, logiko,
muziko, e.c.).

<k>cifro</k> digit (1, 2, 3, 4; I, II, III, etc.); <k>cifroplako</k>
dial-plate (with numbers; cf. <k>skaloplato</k>); <k>cifreto</k>
small number at side of a larger number, as 32.
Def.: Tipo o signo qua reprezentas nombro (Araba o Romana).

<k>cikatro</k> scar, cicatrice: mark remaining from wound or
ulcer; <k>cikatrigar</k>, <k>cikatreskar</k> to cicatrize.

<k>ciklono</k> cyclone, tornado, typhoon; a violent rotary
wind.

<k>cikuto</k> <ex>(bot. tree or poison)</ex> hemlock (Conium
maculatum and species of Cicuta).

<k>cinabro</k> cinnabar, (in the Fine Arts)
vermilion; <k>cinabrea</k>, <k>cinabroreda</k> vermilion colored.

<k>cindro</k> ash(es), cinders (of coal); embers (of
wood); dust: remains of the dead; (cf. <k>eskarbilo</k>;
<k>cindrea</k> ash colored; <k>cindroblonda</k>
pale ashburn; <k>cindroza</k>, <k>cindratra</k> ashy; <k>cindruyo</k>
ash-holder, -pan, -box; <k>cindrigar</k> to reduce <k>(ulo)</k>
to ashes, incinerate (cf. <k>kremacar</k>; <k>cindrigo</k>
incineration; <k>cindrizar</k> to cover with ashes; <k>cindromerkurdio</k>
Ash-Wednesday.

<k>cinemo</k> popular abbr. for <k>cinematografilo</k>
or, more especially a moving-picture theater, cinema,
picture-house.

<k>cinematografar</k> <ex>(tr., intr.)</ex> to show
moving pictures; <k>cinematografuro</k> moving picture; <k>cinematografilo</k>
kinetoscope, bioscope, cinematograph.

<k>cintilo</k> spark (of fire); sparkle (of anything
shining or vivid); <k>cintilifar</k> to emit sparks, to
shine brightly, glitter, glisten, sparkle, flash, twinkle,
scintillate.

<k>ciprino</k> <ex>(ich.)</ex> cyprinoid, scientific
name for the carp: genus: Cyprinus.

<k>cirajo</k> polish (as for boots), (boot-)blacking;
<k>cirajizar</k> to black or polish (boots); <k>cirajizisto</k>
bootblack.

<k>circinata</k> circinate, rolled up like a young
fern leaf.

<k>cirklo</k> circle (cf. <k>rondo</k>); <k>cirkla</k>, <k>cirklala</k>, <k>cirklatra</k> circular, round; <k>cirklokurvo</k>, <k>periferio</k> circumference of a c.; <k>quadratigo di
 la cirklo</k> squaring of c.; <k>jirar cirkle</k> to
turn in a c.

<k>cirkondar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to surround, embrace,
encompass (cf. <k>cernar</k>); <k>cirkondanta</k>
surrounding; <k>cirkondata</k>, <k>cirkondita</k> surrounded, enclosed; <k>cirkondanti</k>
<ex>(fig.)</ex> confidants, friends, relations; Ex.: Me vidas
oldi cirkondita da infanti.

<k>cirkonspekta</k> circumspect, wary, cautious; <k>cirkonspekte</k>
cautiously. V. exp.:<k>Cirkonspekta</k> ne esas simple
<k>prudenta</k>, <k /> ma predenteso desfidema, qua
»regardas cirkum su«, konsideras omna lateri od elementi ante
decidar od agar; III<k />

<k>cirkonstanco</k> circumstance: a fact, occurence,
or condition attending something else; <k>cirkonstancala</k>
circumstantial; <k>cirkonstanci tenuiganta</k> extenuating
circumstances.

<k>cirkonvoluciono*</k> cirkumvolution; that which is
rolled around something (cf. <k>parafrazo</k>).

<k>cirkuito</k> circuit: circumference, compass;
roundabout way; (Eng. and U.S.) circuit (of judges); <k>kurta
 cirkuito</k> <ex>(elec.)</ex> short c. Ex.: La cirkuito di ca
urbo esas kin kilometri. Irar en cirkuito.

<k>cirkular</k> <ex>(intr.)</ex> to circulate: to
move around, to flow in a circuitous channel; <ex>(of money,
etc.)</ex> to pass from hand to hand; <k>cirkuligar</k> to
cause to c., move around; (money) put into circulation, issue.
Ex.: La sango cirkulas en la korpo. La tero cirkulas cirkum la
suno. Cirkulado di idei.

<k>cirkum</k>, <k>cirkume</k> (prep., adv.) around, about,
roundabout (place, time, quantity); (cf. <k>proxim</k>);
<k>cirkumajo</k>, <k>cirkumaji</k> surroundings, environment, frame,
setting; (cf. <k>medio</k>) <k>cirkumirar</k> <ex>(tr.,
intr.)</ex> to go or wind around (as an obstacle); <k>cirkumiro</k>, <k>cirkumturno</k> circuitous way, detour; <k>cirkumklozar</k>
<ex>(tr.)</ex> to fence around, inclose; <k>cirkumlekar</k>
to lick around (one's chops), <ex>(fig).</ex> to gloat over; <k>cirkummuro</k>
inclosure-wall; <k>cirkumnavig(ad)o</k> circumnavigation; <k>cirkumpola</k>
circumpolar; <k>cirkumskribar</k> <ex>(tr., geom.)</ex> to
circumscribe; <k>cirkumvicina</k>, <k>cirkumjacanta</k> circumjacent.
Ex.: Vu mustas vartar cirkume un horo. Vi departos cirkum tri
kloki. El spensis cirkume duadek dollar-i. Me promenis en la tre
interesant cirkumajo.

<k>cis</k> <ex>(prep.)</ex> on this side of
(anything); <k>cise</k> this side; <k>cisa</k>
hither; <k>cisalpa</k> cisalpine; <k>cis la ponto</k>
on this side of the bridge

<k>citar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to cite, quote; <k>cit(ad)o</k>
citing, citation (act); <k>citajo</k> text cited,
citation; <k>citato</k> author cited; <k>citohoketo</k>
quotation mark. V. exp.: On <k>citas</k> autoro
repetante lua paroli o texto; on <k>mencionas</k>
autoro o libro, kande on nomas li sen citar li. On <k>referas</k>
ad autoro, libro, e.c. kande on indikas la loko, en qua trovos
ulo aludata o benzonata. On <k>alegas</k> fakti,
argumenti, atesti, motivi, por pruvar o por justifikar ulo;
II

<k>citrono</k> <ex>(fruit)</ex> citron, lime; (cf. <k>limono</k>, <k>cedrato</k>); <k>citron iero</k> citron-tree,
lime-tree (Citrus); <k>citronsuko</k> lime-juice; <k>citronliquoro</k>
citron-water (cf. <k>limonado</k>).

<k>civila</k> civil: pertaining to a citizen and his
rights (not milit., or criminal) lay (opposed to ecclesiastical);
<k>civil(ul)o</k> civilian; <k>civila kodexo</k> c.
code; <k>civila mariajo</k> c. marriage; <k>civila
 stando</k> civil condition: social state of persons,
whether married or single, living or dead, etc. Def.: Civila
stando: Ensemblo di la docukumenti, relativa a la sociala stando
di singla civitani. IV

<k>civilizar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to civilize; <k>civilizeso</k>
civilization: state of advancement in the arts and sciences (cf. <k>kulturo</k>).

<k>civismo</k> civism: civic spirit; <k>civismala</k>
civic. V. exp.: <k>Civismo</k> esas devoteso di homo a
sua sam-civitani o sam-statani; <k>patriotismo</k>
esas devoteso, amo a patrio.

<k>civito</k> city: the older, most ancient part of a
town (cf. <k>urbo</k>); <k>civitano</k> citizen;
<k>civitaneso</k> citizenship; <k>civitanigar</k>
to confer the rights of a citizen, (cf. <k>nacionaligar</k>):
<k>civitanigo</k> naturalization; <k>civitanala milito</k>
civil war; <k>civitanala yuro</k> common law.

<k>cizelar</k> <ex>(tr.)</ex> to chisel, chase; <k>cizelilo</k>
chisel; <k>kava cizelilo</k> gouge (cf. <k>skultar</k>).

<k>«corpus juris»</k> <ex>(jur.)</ex> corpus juris:
body of the law.
